At the Junction with the Miners Ridge Trail, stay straight on the PCT rather than heading uphill, which will cross Miners Creek after a mile and then slowly switchback up Middle Ridge in shady forest. 5.1 miles after the Miners Ridge Junction take a right onto the Buck Creek Pass Trail to rejoin the loop at mile 64.6. Chiwawa River Trailheads The Chiwawa River Road offers access to the east side of the Glacier Peak Wilderness via the Little Giant, Buck Creek, and Phelps Creek Trailheads. The main advantage of starting here is the ability to avoid the High Pass High Route by accessing the Napeequa Valley via Little Giant Pass and exiting the loop via the Buck Creek or Phelps Creek trails. The High Pass High Route may be treacherous and require crampons and ice-ax early in the summer. In late summer and early fall the snow has usually melted but some route finding may still be required to descend into the Napeequa valley. Add 12.4 miles and 2,600 feet of elevation gain and loss to bypass the scenic and adventurous 8.3 mile High Pass High Route from Buck Creek Pass to the Napeequa Valley. Start the Glacier Peak circumnavigation at the Little Giant Pass Trailhead. Immediately ford the Chiwawa River, which can be deep and swift in early summer, and climb 4,200 feet in 4.1 miles to Little Giant Pass. From the pass, lose 2,500 feet of the elevation you just gained following 3 miles of narrow and unmaintained switchbacks to reach the junction with the Boulder Pass Trail along the Napeequa River at mile 77.6 in the standard loop. Good camps with water can be found on the far shore of the Chiwawa just after fording the river and 0.6 miles before reaching Little Giant Pass where the trail crosses a small creek. To complete the loop, take the Buck Creek Trail at Buck Creek Pass (mile 69.3 in the standard loop) downhill for 10.2 easy miles to the Chiwawa River Road at Trinity and then hike south along the gravel road for 3.5 miles to your starting point at the Little Giant Pass Trailhead. Exiting via the Lyman Lakes and Phelps Meadows will add 16.9 miles and 4,400 feet of elevation gain and lose to the standard loop while winding through open country past alpine lakes and permanent snowfields. At mile 62.4 in the standard loop, take a left when you reach the PCT toward Cloudy Pass, rather than a right; the mileages that follow are given from this junction. Head NE on the PCT for 0.6 miles then take a right onto the Cloudy Pass Trail. Head uphill, reaching Cloudy Pass with views of Lyman Lake at 1.6 miles. The way then switchbacks down into the Lower Lyman Lake valley reaching established camps at 3.0 miles. Follow the trail around the east end of the Lyman Lakes to Upper Lyman with more camps at 4.4 miles. From Upper Lyman Lakes follow a faint trail or cairns to the Spider gap at 5.7 miles and the high point of this route at 7040 feet. Descend the rocks or the Spider Glacier to its snout where hanging camps (With a privy!) are available with views overlooking the meadowed basin of Phelps Creek at 6.4 miles. Descend into the Phelps Creek valley where dispersed camping is abundant and follow the trail, which eventually becomes a road to the Phelps Creek Trailhead at 13.4 miles. Walk the approach road downhill to the Chiwawa River Road and follow it south to the Little Giant Pass Trailhead at 18.6 miles. Good camps can be found at the Phelps Creek and Alpine Meadows Forest Service campgrounds along the Chiwawa River Road. A bike left at one of the trailheads or a car shuttle can negate the road walk. Hike Description Written by Kyle Pomraning , WTA Correspondent
column106: We did Glacier Peak circumnavigation as a 9-day hike with a few long days and a few shorter days Aug. 25-Sept. 2. First, a debt of gratitude: Anyone who hiked this trail in July must have endured a whole lot of suffering. Respect and thanks to the early-season hikers who beat paths around 7ft tall logs (lying down) and through thick brush that obscured the trail and created trip hazards on sketchy cliffsides, and to the tireless trail crews who helped make Indian Creek passable. There were just a few sections, outlined below, that gave us pause. Second, a gripe: the PCT is such an awesome trail. But with so many people burning the miles, there is A LOT of surface pooping going on. Be careful where you step in any of the campsites, or what rock you turn over. I get it: folks are pushing 30mi days and are probably too tired to poop at all, much less bury it. But we encountered a young man who’d traveled to WA for Section K, and fallen violently ill with norovirus or Giardia. He hadn't kept anything in or down in 2 days and was trying to bail off on the Suiattle River Trail. (We offered to walk him to Sulphur Creek CG, at a social distance, carrying his stuff, but he managed to keep water down overnight, said he could do it on his own and had SOS on his iphone, just in case.) Additionally, horse people use campsites below Boulder Pass, and you have to walk around A LOT of horse pee and poo. We weren’t sure our water filters would protect us. (That was our last night, so we’ll wait a couple days and hope for the best.) Please, people. Do better by your fellow hikers and this beautiful part of our state!!! Otherwise, this trip was amazing!!! We’d been wanting to do it for years, and seemed to run into wildfire closures every August. So, this was the year! Day 1 – White River TH to White Pass via Indian Creek. Thanks to trail crews who brushed the trail for the first several miles. If the last 4-5mi were any indication of how bad it had been, your work saved us tons of energy. Those miles were hard, but we never lost the trail, just a lot of pushing through. Once on the PCT, the miles to White Pass went quickly and we enjoyed a beautiful sunset in camp. (About 15mi and 3800ft) Day 2 – White Pass to Glacier Creek. The hike to Red Pass was gorgeous, and we got to scramble Portal Peak (left side of Red Pass heading north). It was fun, ledgy and had great views. After that, we continued down to Glacier Meadows, a lush camping area, and then kept going down to the Whitechuck River, which is milk-white – I’d never seen anything like it – then farther, across the broken but sturdy bridge at Baekos Creek. There are some pretty riverside campsites at Baekos, but we pressed onward past Sitkum, which had a log and a rock hop and some sandy campsites on the other side. Then we crossed Kennedy Creek, which was harrowing. My partner is a field & stream guy, and we had some good beta from a young woman hiking the opposite direction, so we made it across and had a bath – thigh-high on 6’2” Nate and stomach-high on 5’3” me. We got a lot of gravel in our shoes while crossing. I recommend Crocs or something similar. My Xero sandals would not have offered enough stability, so I wore my trail runners and the cleanup was really something!. After that, we switchbacked up Kennedy Ridge and camped at Glacier Creek, a nothing camp spot, but next to water. (About 16mi/4000ft) Day 3 – Glacier Creek to Mica Lake. This was one of the prettiest days on the trail, though thunder and lightning were forecast for the afternoon.We could see the big glaciers on Glacier Peak up close for a while. Fire Creek Pass is stupendous and has some great, but dry, camp spots. We continued down to the lake, where there are a few excellent campsites. We got in at 1pm, and the rain started at 2. But we still got to swim and explore after it passed. It also rained at night. (About 6mi/2600ft) Day 4 – Mica Lake to Milk Creek. I think this was about 11mi, not sure of elevation gain and loss, but it was hard travel in drizzle with wet veg soaking our shoes and rain gear. About 1/2mi and a few hundred feet below Mica Lake is some good camping with a toilet. Continuing down are switchbacks and lots of blowdown to a brushy section on Milk Creek. Before and after the bridge, there’s brush and slippery, rocky trail with steep drop-offs until the switchback trail that goes up about 2000ft. The switchbacks are in decent shape and lead up to the area before Vista Ridge, where there are a couple good but dry campsites. Nate reached Milk Creek’s east fork before I did and was enchanted. I found him blissed out in a campsite, so we made it a shorter day and enjoyed the afternoon, including a bit of rain. Day 5 – East Fork Milk Creek to PCT. A few hundred feet up from our camp was the turnoff to Grassy Point and iconic view of Glacier Peak. You can camp there, but it’s dry. A few hundred feet down is Dolly Creek, with some nothing campsites, but near water. We kept going down, down, down, and through the worst of the blowdown (think jungle gyms) to the Suiattle River through some wonderful old and second growth forest. We had planned for an 18mi day but stopped after 13 to camp on Miner’s Creek next to a big new bridge, after a significant blowdown that required gymnastics. This used to be the Suiattle River crossing before the old bridge blew out, and it was once a great campground, but tree fall decimated all but 2 campsites. We took one, in which a PCTer had left a sacred heart made of sticks (trail magic). The young man with stomach issues came later and took the other site. Day 6 – PCT to Buck Creek trail, up to Buck Creek Pass. After ascertaining that our camp mate could hike on his own, we parted ways, he for Sulphur Creek (and hopefully urgent care and a hotel room), and Nate and I for Buck Creek Pass. A couple big blowdowns on the PCT and the Buck Creek trail, but with workarounds. Buck Creek Pass was empty because the TH is closed for the Pomas fire; we skirted the edge of the closure map and found an amazing campsite with a view of Glacier Peak. (Around 9.5mi and 4300ft up.) Day 7 – A short day up to High Pass, then down to a turquoise tarn on the other side. (4.5mi, 2000ft.) The first boulder field before High Pass required route finding. Like the trip reporter from Aug. 17, we took the lower route and turned up to the left of a big boulder. The route across the second boulder field was obvious. The tarn was one of our favorite sites, though it was full of algae, so we didn’t swim, and we found water sources above it. We took turns napping, reading and rock scrambling the rest of the day. Day 8 – High Pass tarn to Boulder Creek camp at 5200ft. This was another hard travel day! We’d heard about the slippery, steep, brushy slope down to the Napeequa, and we both landed on our butts twice, but it was nothing compared to the overgrown, hard-to-navigate, rocky, rooty 3.5mi on the Napeequa, across the river (again, thigh-high on Nate and stomach-high on me around 1pm) and up 1500ft toward Boulder Pass. Gazing on the Napeequa valley from above is magical, but I’ll be OK if I never visit that valley again. Once the trail busted out into the meadows below Boulder Pass (at 5700ft), my whole mood lightened. The switchbacks to Boulder Pass at 6300ft and down the other side were impressive. We thought we’d find water and camping 200ft below/beyond Boulder Pass, but we only saw one small, sloped campsite near a trickle of water, so we continued down to 5200 and the horse camp. Despite the manure, it was one of the prettiest campsites we stayed in. (12-ish miles, 2200ft?) Day 9 – We got an early start and watched the sunrise hit Clark Mountain - magnificent! 9.2mi down the impressive switchbacks and out the White River trail to our car without incident. We celebrated with warm TH near-beer, hemp milk lattes at the Sasquatch hut near Goldbar and delicious Southern Indian food in Monroe, the first real food we’d had, unless you count the cups and cups of berries we ate on the trail (blueberries, red and purple huckleberries, salmonberries, salal and the last of the thimbleberries). I'm beyond thrilled that we finally got this one done, and I highly recommend it to hardy hikers with backpacking, scrambling and fording experience and good cheer in tough conditions.

column60: Successful summit of Shuksan on Labor Day weekend via Sulphide glacier. Day 1: Started around 2pm with our party of 4. About a 5 hour hike to camp, 5 miles, 4500ft. Beautiful views of Baker and Baker lake on the way up. About a mile from camp, the trail turns North and becomes a climber’s trail heading straight toward the glacier. We roped up for the last 20 minutes of hiking to high camp, and navigated around several medium-sized crevasses. We camped on the plateau at around 6400ft. We didn’t see the composting toilet at camp, but the map shows it on the ridge to Southwest. Only saw one other party of 2 camping on the ridge. Day 2: Started hiking at 2:45am. We were happy we started at this time both for more stable snow and avoiding the brutal heat later in the day. The first steep section of the Sulphide had many large crevasses and moats with waterfalls running underneath, but this section can easily be avoided by sticking to the climber’s left side below the rock rib. We started a bit too far left and had to traverse across a couple of rock islands. The flat section of glacier above was easy walking with no visible crevasses and a clear bootpack to follow. We followed the ridge up the lefthand side close to the intersection with the Fischer chimneys route. Found a couple snow bridges to cross that were wide and holding up well. Near the summit pyramid there are some narrow cracks hidden beneath snow, and we punched through one of these waist deep. Otherwise the route is in great shape for this point in the season. Reached the summit pyramid and started climbing the gully around 6am as the sun was rising. This was a fun class 3 scramble with some interesting moves on solid rock. Be careful about knocking down loose rocks. It’s easy to get pulled too far right onto the SE ridge route, but if trying to follow the gully, stick to climber’s left. There are 2 options near the top to summit - a steeper gully on the right, or gaining the ridge on left and going around the summit block to the left. We were the first party on the summit at around 7:45am. Saw two more small parties on the way down, then a couple large, maybe guided, groups coming up around 11am. Spent about a half hour on the summit, then made 3 rappels, with some downclimbing in between, to the bottom of the gully. The first rap anchor is skier’s left, looking back toward the route, of the summit block. There were plenty of rap anchors and the ones on skier's right were in good condition with newer webbing, cord and rap rings. On the last section on the way down we found a path through the rocks on continuous snow, although some of the moats there will likely not hold up much longer. Back at camp at 12:30pm, then hiked out the same day. Fun trip with a great group, no crowds, and interesting climbing!
column98: Hiking Mount Shuksan A climb of Mount Shuksan via the Sulphide Glacier.
column106: This report is for a one day attempt on Mt. Shuksan via the Whitesalmon glacier. Warning depending on conditions avalanche danger on the Whitesalmon glacier itself and in the basin below the glacier can be extreme. The hillside leading from the ski area down to Whitesalmon creek is currently only partially snow covered. There is better snow coverage down in the basin. There are a ton of old avalanche debris in the lower end of the basin as well as directly under the glacier. These were frozen and difficult to get over, conditions for skiing were miserable. I ended up booting the entire time. Snow conditions were variable and not elevation dependent. They seemed more dependent on factors like sun, or lack there of, recieved during the day and windloading. At times icey with a non breakable crust and at others a breakable crust. The glacier was in fairly good condition, crevasses were filled in pretty well, but not as much as what one would normally expect this time of year. When I reached the top of the Whitesalmon I was about an hour away from my turn around time so I called that my high point for the day and turned around. I'll attempt this route again at some point with more daylight, January days are so short, and more low elevation snow pack to help with the approach, maybe not this year.. Gear used boots, crampons, trekking poles, ice axe.

column60: We always enjoy this quiet trail with marmots, small waterfalls and wildflowers along the path down to a spectacular view of the morraine and the Nisqually River.
column98: Hiking Moraine Trail From the stone staircase at Paradise, climb steeply on the asphalt Skyline Trail. Follow signs to stay on the Skyline Trail until, at half a mile, you see a sign for the Deadhorse Creek Trail . Veer left (north) at that junction to connect with Deadhorse. At the next junction, go hard left (southwest) on the Deadhorse Creek Trail. In 250 feet, a small sign on the right announces the Moraine Trail. Go right, leaving asphalt behind, shortly passing a sign reading “End of maintained trail. Travel safely causing minimum impact beyond here.” Pass through a small stand of trees, then descend gently into the open. A ridge to your right now separates you from the often crowded area you just left. Continue gently downhill on pleasant trail. When you see the trail divide, avoid the left (lower) trail. Both paths go to the same place, but the lower trail drops steeply through treacherously loose and slippery terrain. Instead, just continue straight on the upper trail. At 1 mile, step across the stream and walk to the edge of the moraine at 1.1 miles, where it connects with the lower trail. Before you wander the edge of the moraine for varied views, notice that the trail below is unsafe in places, simply too close to the loose gravelly edge of the moraine. Admire the broad Nisqually River valley and what remains of the Nisqually Glacier several hundred feet below, or just gaze at the summit. When you are ready, return to the asphalt paths the way you came, and then decide where to go next. WTA Pro Tip: You can obtain a free copy of the “Paradise Area Trails” map, featuring this hike and more, from the Longmire Wilderness Information Center or Paradise Visitor Center. Hike Description Written by Ken Giesbers , WTA Correspondent
column106: We hiked all the way to the top edge  of the moraine at 2 pm. The unmaintained trail to and back was mostly to ourselves. Not many hikers around. The trail has a magnificent display of wildflowers and at the end glacier melt rivers and water falls with fantastic glacier views. Not suitable for small children.

column60: Me (23M) and my partner (24F) did the Bailey range loop from July 17-21 Total mileage ~58 miles Sol Duc falls to Sol Duc Falls Birds: plenty of grouse, bald eagle, hawk, thrushes, and more Mammals: 2 bears from afar, 3 deer, and 1 shrew 7/17 Started at 11 am with 38lb and 29 lb packs respectively. I would recommend to really try to lighten your pack and if you can buy a lighter piece of gear before attempting this DO IT. We slogged up to heart lake and then took a long break including a swim. We worked up the catwalk and dirt gullies, the cat walk took longer than expected but the sidehilling was not as bad as expected. We got to Boston Charlie around 9pm. 7/18 We continued and found 11 bull basin to be a better looking campsite if you can make it there. The climb to drop down to Stephen lake was obvious and after we found the first snow of the trail. After Stephen lake the route finding becomes more tough, I had to refer to gps track on phone often as we climbed out of Stephen basin and then were on snow for a while. We did not use traction yet. We reached ferry basin after a long day around 6:45 pm. 7/19 Long day to camp pan We found two groups including one doing the same loop and followed them up the endless snow fields and rocky moonscape of the southern baileys. This part is all above tree line. We traversed the top of Childs glacier and dropped into queets basin. We trusted our gps track and followed game trail after game trail until reaching forested slopes and sliding down in to the stream that would take us to the humes. We hopped on the humes glacier which was bare ice for 500 feet before being snow covered until the pass to camp pan. We had brought a heavy ass 9.5 mm 60 meter rope and 2 pickets, the other team was unroped completely which seemed doable but not my style. 7/20 Camp pan had the best views of Milky Way. at night. We worked across the heavily crevasses Hoh glacier but nothing too scary. We climbed glacier pass which was super tiring and reached the blue. We had planned to summit Olympus but after ruining out of fuel the night before we decided that it would not be fun to have cold food for 2 days after such an effort. So we decided to try to get out a day early. We continued down the long Hoh River trail and ate endless berries along the way. If you are planning on exiting out the sol Duc and making it a loop, DONT underestimate the climb up the Hoh lake trail which was so demoralizing. 7/20 finally we climbed to the high divide and saw our first bears by Hoh lake. We scurried to the car and engorged on food on the way home
column98: Hiking Bailey Range Traverse A challenging, largely off-trail, multi-day backpacking scramble across the rough and rugged interior of the Olympic Mountains.
column106: After failing on the Bailey range back in 2023 via the snow finger to the sol duc, I came back for another attempt at the traverse but via a different route. This time we went in the sol duc and out the elwha via dodger point. I learned a lot 2 years ago and you really need to be dialed on the route description, coordinates, gps, and map study. We were much better prepared this time. Getting to Boston Charlie was a long day but very manageable. We summited Mount Carrie in the evening as a side trip. There is a good water source on the way down from Carrie (maybe 10 mins out of the way). Getting to ferry basin is a LONG day. Don’t let the short distance fool you. We went the cream lake route, above cream lake the trail completely disappeared and we spent hours getting cliffed out and bushwhacking our way in circles. We eventually bailed and took a diagonal traverse to the ridge below and past Stephen peak. It got a bit sketchy but it worked! Met some other hikers who claimed Stephan basin is way better than cream lake in terms of travel. Ferry basin was beautiful but it was getting late so we made our way up to the lower glacial lake and camped. We did 1 day out of the way to travel as much of the baileys as we could before descending down to dodger point. The goal was to explore and spend some more time up high. We went to Mount Childs and then back to ferry basin. We actually kept pushing all the way to the Scott ludden saddle and camped there. This section from Mount ferry to Scott ludden was so much harder and longer than we thought it would be. We even saw a cougar off In the distance!! The final .5 miles took us 2 hours to the Scott ludden saddle. It was a horrendous bushwhack worse than the snowfinger. We definitely lost the route but kept trying and couldn’t find anything. It was a similar situation to cream lake where the gps said we were on route but we simply were not and were cliffed out at times. After 2 hours of hard bushwhacking and constant up and down and traveling in circles, we found an upper meadow and rock ramp that we descended. We immediately threw up our tent and crashed for 10 hours in the meadow of the Scott ludden saddle! The next couple of days we took our time getting out as we had the time off and wanted to really enjoy our time in the mountains. The final couple of hours of off trail were hard but manageable. The route was much easier to find but still very challenging! Enjoyed our time at dodger point and humes ranch! epic trip and happy to have finally come back from the baileys victorious!

column60: This is such a pleasant trail! Since we were on a relaxed schedule, and only wanted to do a short hike, we waited for the sunshine and started our hike around 11. We took the Greywacke Trail to Subduction Trail to the summit. Great views with plenty of benches and picnic tables on the summit.  Along the trail there was an abundance of red berries on the Madrone trees. We logged roughly 3.5 miles and only saw a few other hikers near the summit. Loo at the TH was clean and had plenty of TP
column98: Hiking Mount Grant Preserve This location is one of San Juan Island's newest hiking destinations, boasting nearly five miles of trails to explore and accessible from the parking area at West Valley Road. From here, walk past the gate, and begin your hike in lowland Douglas-fir and Western redcedar forest. You will quickly gain the east side of this ridge as you walk up existing roads. As you gain the ridge crest of Mount Grant, you’ll see towering old-growth Douglas firs, rocky balds abounding with uncommon prairie wildflowers, and views, views, views like you won’t get anywhere else in the islands. On a clear day you may get a glimpse of three of Washington’s five volcanoes: Mount Baker, Glacier Peak, and Mount Rainier. The ridge top has ample areas to wander and delight in the surrounding islands and waterways, but please stick to existing trails…this is fragile habitat up here. You can continue on south along the ridge crest to make this hike a loop (1.9 miles round trip), or return on the road the way you came up. Note: It's also possible to walk the road to the top, but be aware that if the access gate at the trailhead is open, the road is open to vehicles (this is the case two days a week). Background Local conservation organizations have completed an ambitious project to permanently protect this 250-acre property and turned it into a publicly-accessible nature preserve. The area is still under development; read about the background and future plans for the preserve . Hike Description Written by Kathleen Foley, WTA Correspondent
column106: Followed the Lawsonite Trail to the top, and the (slightly longer) Greywacke Trail back down. Road Conditions. Paved road (all the way to the top), portable toilet at the lower parking lot. Trail Conditions. No obstacles. Highlights. Pleasant trail, nice views at the top, old-growth Douglas firs. Crowds. 3 cars in the downstairs parking lot at 1pm, plus a few more at the top (the road to the top is open Sundays during winter). The Greywacke Trail is open to mountain bikers and equestrians, but didn't see any evidence of either,

column8:
Dragontail Peak, Little Annapurna, Aasgard Pass —
              Jul. 24, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-07-26.184007423984)
column60: This was a beautiful but brutal car to car trek up and down Aasgard Pass and Dragontail and Little Annapurna. I wouldn’t recommend doing a car to car like I did, as the return down Aasgard Pass is probably the worst part of the trip. One previous report mentions it’s like “rollerballs under your feet,” which I think is a very accurate description. I understand why this is done as a traverse, or better yet, a backpacking trip . Watch for mountain goats, I met plenty at Aasgard Pass as well as ascending Dragontail. Little Annapurna is straightforward with minimal scrambling and exposure. Follow the cairns closely on Little Annapurna and through the Core Zone in general, as they will help you avoid backtracking and bushwhacking. The views from both Dragontail and Little Annapurna are stunning, with close views of Rainier, as well as the Enchantment Range including Mount Stuart, Colchuck, Argonaut, McClellan, and Prusik, the upper Enchantments basin as well as panoramic views of the Cascades both north and south. There’s also great views of the Teanaway; it was awesome to spy Bean, Earl, and Teanaway Peaks. There are plentiful water sources at Colchuck Lake as well as the Core Zone tarns, limited water at Aasgard pass, and on Dragontail and Little Annapurna sections. I brought 2.5L with me and filtered 3.5L more. On the Dragontail ascent there are cairns from the top of Aasgard marking a path higher up on the rockfield which helps to avoid the glacier/snowfield until you are at about 8300ft. I’d recommend downloading a .gpx from prior ascents or map the route on Caltopo. The crux of the ascent starts here and involves an approximately 200 ft ascent up the top lip of a steep snow climb. The snow is soft enough to kick steps, however the ascent requires a prolonged steep sidehill traverse. I strongly recommend crampons and an ice axe here, as the runout here drops 200+ feet steeply onto rock outcroppings. The ascent from the snowfield to the summit is pretty straightforward, and consists of a bootpath interspersed with easy scrambles. I used microspikes and hiking shoes for this section, and ascended relatively late at 12:15. This combo predictably led to a loss of traction on my descent down the snowfield traverse leading to a 100 ft slide. Thankfully I was able to self-arrest and came out with only a sprained ankle to show for my lack of caution, but learn from me - wear crampons and go early! Stats : distance 17 miles, elevation gain 7200 feet
column98: Hiking Little Annapurna Scramble to a scenic high point in the upper Enchantments.
column106: Larches are starting! We got lucky and experienced minimal wildfire smoke, but the Labor Mountain Fire burns on so check air quality reports before you go. Trail is in great shape and cairns mark the way well throughout the traverse and up Little Annapurna, which is a straightforward albeit steep climb with no scrambling required.

column8:
Pulaski Tunnel Trail, Pulaski Mountain —
              Jul. 10, 2022 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report.2022-07-11.9794097323)
column60: Today was a day of adventure and exploration. The Pulaski Tunnel is well established super fun trail, but Pulaski Mountain was going to require some serious route finding. After conferring with a Wallace local we decided an old mining road, heading up from Placer Creek was the way to go. In retrospect I believe this road was likely mining first but then used as the original lookout access in the thirties. Starting with the Pulaski Tunnel Trail we had a cool day with glorious sunshine. As a note of disgust the vandals who have wrecked some of the decorative features along this trail should be ashamed. As you cross the creek an old, blocked road turns off to the right. Though overgrown in spots this road is in remarkably good condition despite many decades of disuse. Follow this old road up to 3700’ where a newer road has cut across the hillside. The new road cut has pushed huge amounts of rock down onto your trail but this is quickly circumvented. Once on the new road look across the road and up the bank for the continuation of your trail/road. This type of road interruption will occur several more times on your way. Once the twenty year-old clear cut is reached the track becomes much harder to follow. We thrashed about a bit though aided by the resident elk population which has trails throughout this area. Following our Gaiagps mapping made life fairly easy and we were soon at point 4965’. From here the going was noticeably easier, though perhaps only because we could see where we were headed. When we gained the final 500’ slope a well defined miner’s rod had returned. Old burn was evident and the wild flowers were abundant. Near the summit we chatted with some friendly ATVers who’d come up from the west. Lounging at the summit we enjoyed expansive views and fantastic wildflowers. A few fire lookout remnants were extant. Our dreams turned to burgers and beers in Wallace and the 2700’ descent back into town.
column98: Hiking Pulaski Tunnel Trail This North Idaho interpretive trail is easily accessible from I-90 and is not-to-be missed for its rich history of the 1910 fires. WTA's volunteer trail workers are well versed in the use of the Pulaski as an all-around best grubbing tool for a variety of trail projects. They may even be aware of the man who designed the tool, Ed Pulaski, a forest service employee and firefighter based out of the mining town of Wallace. North Idaho's Pulaski Trail delves into the history of the man, the tool he designed, and the 1910 wildfires that still leave their mark on North Idaho. This is an interpretive trail, so plan to spend as much time reading the trailside signs as hiking on this four mile round-trip hike along a creek. At trails-end is the tunnel and commemorative markers indicating where Ed Pulaski saved all but six of the 45 firefighters under his command by holding them at gunpoint in a mine tunnel. His armed insistence on their remaining inside the tunnel saved them from smoke inhalation and the high temperatures outside their shelter. Due the significance of the events that happened here in August 1910, both the trail and the tunnel are listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Teachers and scout leaders, be sure to check out the educational materials provided by the Forest Service. The first 725 feet of this trail is barrier-free. Toilet Information Toilet at trailhead Accessible toilet More information about toilets Wheelchair Accessibility The first 725 feet of this trail are paved. Past that the trail narrows and becomes packed dirt. Hike Description Written by Multiple authors contributed to this report, WTA Community
column106: This is a nice little hike. It is not long, four miles out and back. But it does have some points of interest and a very nice history to it. There are some interpretive signs along the way that explain the story, which is a heroic one. The trail is named for the man who saved many lives during an extreme fire that swept the area in 1910. The trailhead is just outside the city limits of Wallace, Idaho, a very quaint town with a storied past. Mining was big here back in the day. The Sunday I hiked it the trail had many families with small kids and dogs. The trails end features a place to sit, some interpretive signs, and the entrance to an abandoned gold mine, where the story unfolded. No bugs along the way, trail in good shape. Cap off the hike with a visit to a very nice restaurant in Wallace called The Fainting Goat. Super pizza, and beer and wine. Moderate pricing.

column8:
Mosier Creek Falls and Mosier Plateau —
              Jun. 19, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-06-26.141819954886)
column51:
Mosier Creek Falls and Mosier Plateau —
              Jun. 28, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-06-30.224002760027)
column55: Mosier Creek Falls and Mosier Plateau
column60: In late June, the attraction here is the wide-open view down the Columbia from the Mosier plateau.  The wet season was long gone, so the stream flow in the Mosier Creek falls is down and there are many more spectacular falls further west in the Gorge.  Most of the wildflowers had faded, but on a sunny morning the view of the Gorge was still spectacular.  As noted in the WTA hike description, the Coyote Wall is just on the other side of the river.  The Wash. State DNR reports that the Coyate Wall is the head escarpment of a large landslide where a large block of Columbia River Basalt rotated and slid towards the river.  For those of you that are geologically inclined, the scenery is rife with synclines and anticlines, all visible due to the exposed basalt layers. And despite the hike description's claim that it is a 3.5-mile round trip, we found that the up and back clocked in only 2.4 miles.  Perhaps the missing 1.1 miles would appear if we had completed the entire loop going down the Mosier Plateaus from the high point, but we could not see the point of adding gratuitous elevation loss to our stroll.
column98: Hiking Mosier Creek Falls and Mosier Plateau This is a trail that starts in the small town of Mosier, Oregon. It starts on the east side of the old bridge on Highway 30 in town.  Several hundred yards up the trail, it passes a pioneer cemetery with graves dating from the 1800s. Climb through a gorge past a creek that feeds into the mighty Columbia to the top of a plateau that offers fantastic views down to the huge river making its way to the Pacific Ocean. Built by the Friends of the Gorge with assistance from WTA, the trail is a nice leg stretch for folks touring the Gorge. After hiking just 0.25 miles and about 100 feet of elevation gain, you will see beautiful, two-tiered Mosier Falls. The first level drops about 70 feet, while the upper falls is shorter, at just 10 feet high. The swirling pool between the two falls is inaccessible from the trail. Past the falls, the trail climbs steadily with switchbacks and three sets of stairs up a steep, open hillside to a viewpoint on the Mosier Plateau. The hillside and plateau are home to plentiful flowers, such as Columbia desert parsley, yellow bells, and grass widows. Across the river, the Coyote Wall trail is just visible on the Washington side. From here it is best to return the way you came. The trail does loop back down to highway 30, but you must then walk a half-mile along a busy highway back to your car. Hike Description Written by Multiple authors contributed to this report, WTA Community
column106: My partner planned a fun, quick anniversary trip to the Gorge and we did this hike on the way there. Its a very nice little trail that starts by going through an old cemetary - some of the headstones are really old! Next you go by a nice view of a waterfall before the trail goes uphill to the plateau. The blooms were gone, but the day was clear and really windy, and the views were beautiful as usual. Plus we saw a G I A N T garter snake on our way back to the car. So happy we finally stopped here after years of driving by!

column98: Hiking Dusty Ridge A long-abandoned trail that branches off the Upper Suiattle River Trail to Dusty Creek. The Upper Suiattle River Trail begins at the Pacific Crest Trail and drops to down to the Suiattle River. If you can cross Dusty Creek (difficult, as there is no bridge and the water can be dangerous), you can navigate five miles to a junction with the Dusty Creek and Triad Creek trails.
Hiking Cow Canyon
Hiking Lodgepole Creek

column8:
Little Spokane Wildlife Area: Rustler's Gulch - Holly Road Loop —
              Jan. 18, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-01-18.152520034989)
column51:
Little Spokane Wildlife Area: Rustler's Gulch - Holly Road Loop —
              Jun. 7, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-07-14.023954437958)
column55: Little Spokane Wildlife Area: Rustler's Gulch - Holly Road Loop
column60: one tree across the trail. intermittent snow with most at the beginning
column98: Hiking Little Spokane Wildlife Area: Rustler's Gulch - Holly Road Loop The West Branch Little Spokane River Wildlife Area is popularly referred to as Rustler's Gulch. The property is a relatively new acquisition for Fish & Wildlife, which purchased the 2,772 acre property in two phases in 2008 and 2009. Trailhead signage is improving, making it easier for visitors to locate the correct access points, but it is still a work in progress, so visitors need to come prepared with navigation tools. The Holly Road access point is one of three designated trail heads for the Wildlife Area. The trailhead is located at a high point on the property, just west of Fan Lake (a non-motorized lake that's great for a post-hike swim). Begin the hike by descending down a hill for approximately one mile on an old roadbed. Over the course of that one mile the trail passes through three distinct ecosystems. Initially, it's all pine trees with an open understory, blanketed in wildflowers in the springtime. In the middle section there's still some pine, but Doug-fir becomes the predominant tree. By the bottom of the hill, it's a lush cedar forest. It's also a wetland, and the mosquitoes may be fierce depending on when hikers visit. At the bottom of the hill, there's a single-track trail that breaks off to the left of the old roadbed and crosses a small stream. There are no trail markers, so keep careful watch for it. (Note Pruffer Barn across the wetland, as this is the landmark to watch for on the return portion of the loop.) This trail goes slightly uphill toward Horseshoe Lake for about a mile and a half. It's the prettiest section of the hike since it's all single-track, gorgeous forest, and wildflowers in season. It also boasts some seasonal muddy spots, so waterproof shoes are advised. At approximately the 2.5 mile mark, the trail comes out on Horseshoe Lake Road. To complete the loop hike, hikers need to hike the road for a few hundred feet to the West trailhead for the property, where there's a wide parking area along the road (an alternate access point for this loop), and a kiosk with a map of the property. The loop then continues on an old roadbed. There are some intersecting roadbeds and no trail signage, so this next part is a little trickier, but the trail here is basically an old farm road that gradually descends the wetland, roughly parallel to the single-track trail up the wetland. The roadbed has good views of the wetland, including an active beaver pond. Eventually, hikers will come to the old barn. From there, return to the intersection with the single-track trail and retrace the route of the first mile, ascending the roadbed back to the trailhead. Since this is a Wildlife Area, hikers need to be aware of various hunting seasons throughout the year, as hunting is a permitted activity on this property. This is also a popular equestrian area, so hikers who arrive in passenger cars should take care in how they park at the trailhead in order to allow trailers to turn around with ease.  Improvements to parking at Holly Road are currently being planned. Camping is not allowed. Hike Description Written by Holly Weiler, WTA Correspondent
column106: well worn trails, or old roads. lots of mosquitos, repellent advised.

column60: This is a nice easy trail along the river. A good place to stretch your legs if you have been driving for a while. Starting at the parking area, there are story boards along the trail that kids might enjoy.  If you do that, read them in the reverse direction.
column98: Hiking Irene Rinehart Riverfront Park This park is just outside the city of Ellensburg along the Yakima River. The park is a long, narrow parcel that stretches between the river and I-90 and has a parking area on both ends. At the southern end, a small parking area with a restroom is a good place to start walking along the forested riverbank. The trail starts here and parallels the river all the way to the other end of the park in just under 2 miles. The parking area on the northern end provides access to a boat launch and an off-leash dog park. From here, visitors can also connect to a paved path that leads under I-90 and into the town of Ellensburg, a great option for pedestrians or cyclists who want to access the river from the city or vice versa. Hike Description Written by Multiple authors contributed to this report, WTA Community
column106: Lots of visitors on the trail today. And it was easy to see why. I'm an E-burger and walked this trail nearly everyday this season. Lived here for 35 years and never recalled so much Fall foliage before. While it's normal for the trees to all turn, the Kittitas Valley is well known for its fairly regular high winds. A normal Fall presents nice colors but with the wind, it never gets much of a chance to fully present itself as it's continuously blowing away. Same with Spring. We haven't had much wind at all for a week or so and wow! It can do this? Anyway, looks like continued light breeze presence this coming week so now is an awesome time to get your Autumn fill. And if you're a fellow E-burger, get your butt down here and take in what can happen when it's actually calm for a while. Who knows when it will happen again.

column60: The short version: Reports of the demise of this trail have been greatly exaggerated, to paraphrase the Bard of Hannibal, Missouri. The medium version: Although the road to get to the Wynoochee Pass trailhead is rough, it is passable, and the trail itself is in pretty good shape all the way to the pass. There are maybe two or three blowdowns, and there are several creek crossings, but at present none is particularly difficult. After reaching the pass, it's a bit of a challenge to find the way trail that cuts across and meets up with the Graves Creek trail to get to Lake Sundown. But once you find the trail, it's not hard to follow, with or without the flagging that currently helps guide the way. The long version (and either buckle in or choose to move on to other trip reports, because this will indeed be a long version): The description of my actual hike will come towards the end, but I want to begin with some background about this trail. Let's start with the way this trail has been named and described by WTA. If you search the site for "Wynoochee Pass," you'll find many trip reports for a hike that was previously categorized by WTA as "Wynoochee Pass to Sundown Lake." A few years ago, for some reason, WTA changed the name to "Sundown Lake Way Trail" and updated the description to the current " This former route towards Sundown Lake in Olympic National Forest is no longer navigable." Regardless of what you think about finding the route all the way to Lake Sundown, the Wynoochee Pass trail is an active, maintained, navigable route, even if it doesn't see a lot of traffic. Both the Forest Service and the Park Service seem to have done work on this trail in the recent past. The bypass through the landslide area at the beginning of the trail (more on that later) in particular has been reworked and is far less sketchy than when I was last here four or five years ago. After you reach Wynoochee Pass on this trail -- the pass is the divide between the Wynoochee drainage and the Upper Quinault drainage via Graves Creek, and it is marked by two ponds on relatively flat ground at the top of the pass -- things get more interesting. There are two routes from here to get to Lake Sundown. First, as shown on most maps (Custom Correct, NatGeo, Gaia, the Park Service interactive map, and even on the Google Maps link from the page for this hike, if you zoom in enough), you can continue along the Wynoochee Pass trail, which descends about 1,000 feet until it meets up with the Graves Creek trail coming over from the Quinault area. Then the trail turns sharply and goes back uphill, switching back up 1,200 feet to the lake. The second route, which is what I think of as the "way trail," cuts off most of that down-and-up, contouring along the hillside at ~3,400' in elevation from just below the pass, to meet up with the trail coming back up from Graves Creek, joining it at the apex of the last switchback. This cuts off about 800' of gain coming back up from the junction with the Graves Creek trail, although to be sure this way trail is not without its own ups and downs. If you read through trip reports for this hike here and elsewhere, you'll see that there's a lot of confusion about which of these two options people are describing, and I believe WTA's change in the name and description of this hike has compounded the issue. Some are looking for the way trail but stumble along the main trail for the full down and up. Some hikers (including me, on my two previous tries) search in vain for the way trail and return the way they came, with a nice day hike to the pass and back under their belts. And some thru-hike it via Six Ridge to the North Fork of the Skokomish or via Sundown Pass to the South Fork. Now, I've hiked the Graves Creek trail from the trailhead shared with the Enchanted Valley hike, but not as far as the junction with the trail coming down from Wynoochee Pass, nor have I done the full down-and-up from Wynoochee Pass to the Graves Creek trail and back up to Lake Sundown. Therefore, I don't have first-hand knowledge, but my understanding is that this down-and-up, sometimes in conjunction with taking the Graves Creek trail past Success Creek, is what gives this area a reputation for endless blowdowns. The route I took had a few blowdowns, but not notably more than many other, more-traveled trails in the Olympics. The hike: Be careful about the route to the trailhead. As others have noted, Google Maps has a tendency to take you on a non-existent route. Adding to this confusion, Google also numbers the main road into the area variously FS-2270 and/or NF-2312. Stick with the directions on the WTA page, and you'll get there. I would add one detail to this portion of the directions: " Follow FS Road 2270 11.7 miles to the FS Spur Road #400 (2270-400)." Note that to stay on 2270, you have to take a left turn and cross a bridge over the Wynoochee. It's marked here, and it's clear that the forest road continuing straight ahead at this turn is of a diminished grade, but it's worth noting that you have to make this turn. There has been some work on 2270, so it's not a bad drive. There used to be suspension-killing potholes immediately after crossing the bridge, but those have been fixed, and large stretches before that have had fresh gravel added. The -400 spur, which is marked with a masonite sign and has a "WYNOOCHEE PASS" sign nailed to a tree above eye level, is considerably rougher, and this is where a high-clearance vehicle would be appreciated. The road eventually ends just before an old washout and widens into a small parking area with room for a handful of cars. There is newish trailhead signage here from the Forest Service. The first order of business is crossing the old slide area. As I recall, this used to be a bit precarious, but it has clearly been improved significantly, with some large-stone gravel used to regrade the trail. If you know the landslide area on Pyramid Mountain/Peak above Lake Crescent, this slide was never that bad, but it was a lot closer to that than it is now. I don't think anyone would be intimidated crossing it today. The trail continues on the old roadbed for a short while, and then it reaches what was the original trailhead, with a registration box. (The old roadbed switches back to the left here, and I believe that's an alternate route up Discovery Peak, but I haven't climbed it from this side.) You are now in the forest proper, and it's a lovely trail. Soon you encounter signage letting you know that you are entering the national park. This trail is obvious and easy to follow. It continues for about 2.5 miles up to the actual pass. The trail is varied along the way. There are steeper sections, often rooty, mixed with flat portions, and some swampier, grassy areas here and there. There are also several creek crossings. Some of these could be precarious in the spring thaw, but none presents a challenge currently. You have to pick your steps carefully getting down into and up out of a couple of the creek beds, but it's fine. There is a six- or seven-foot scramble out of one of the creeks that involves handholds, but even this is pretty tame. There are some beautiful old trees throughout this hike, including one giant guardian that, if I recall correctly, is nestled in the crook of the one big switchback on the trail, so you get to admire it from all angles. There were ripe and ripening berries throughout this part of the hike. I enjoyed all the salmonberries, blueberries and huckleberries I cared to sample. It looks like the thimbleberries have already come and gone, though. Eventually, you come out to Wynoochee Pass, which as noted above is distinguished by two ho-hum ponds. The trail skirts alongside these, and there is a relatively flat, rocky mound up here, which could be a good place for a break. I was surprised that it wasn't buggier, but I didn't stop to see whether they would home in on me. It was cloudy today, but I know from previous visits that this area isn't known for big views, which is partly why I chose it on an overcast day. OK, here's where it really gets interesting. If you want to use the way trail -- and for all of the reasons stated above, I believe you do -- go about 1/4 mile downhill beyond the pass. If you're looking carefully for it, there is a faint trail that leads down to the right into a lush green meadow. This meadow is marshy, so step carefully. The crux of this route is finding the correct exit from the meadow on the far side. I got turned around here looking for it, as you'll see on the map I've attached. The trick is that it's kind of a double meadow down and to the left, so you want to get all the way to the other side down there and look for the trail leading out of the area back into the trees. I went straight across and entered the woods too early, chasing game trails at first. If you pick up the trail again, to my mind, you're home free! It's not hard to follow, nor are there many obstacles on it. Shortly after exiting the meadow, there is a ravine to cross, but the trail angles down into it and then back out of it. In fact, this way trail is in better shape than the "real" trail you pick up on its far side. That trail is very brushy, a problem that the way trail doesn't share, because it's mostly forested without a lot of undergrowth. The worst of the blowdowns are also on that final portion of the "real" trail up to the lake, but nothing insurmountable if you're the intrepid type to take on this hike. Eventually you reach a split in the trail, with a sign for Sundown Pass and an arrow pointing right. Go left to get to Lake Sundown. Soon you cross a beautiful open meadow area, then pop back into the woods for a final push to the lake. Some reviews have said the lake isn't that impressive, but I found it gorgeous, especially with the lush green hillside arising out of it on the far side. The only animals I saw were grouse and one other hiker on the way trail. We were both quite surprised to see each other! There was a lot of bear and cougar scat around, though, as well as some elk prints up by the pass. The entire hike car-to-car is just about 10 miles roundtrip. Notes on the attached map image: I've included a screenshot from Gaia. I recorded my track only from the point of departure from the Wynoochee Pass trail to the lake. I have added four key waypoints. The two outermost waypoints were locations I grabbed from someone else's trip report. They show the locations where you exit and rejoin the main trail. The first one was spot on; the second was a little off, but close enough. This second one is important mainly to ensure you don't miss the turnoff on the return. First point: 47.53510, -123.53197 Second point: 47.53317, -123.52328 The inner waypoints are the entry into the meadow and the exit from the meadow back onto the way trail. I found the exit to be important on the way to the lake and the entry to be important on the return, to find your way back up to Wynoochee Pass. As you can see from my track, I wandered around for a bit before finding the correct exit. Entry: 47.53477, -123.53190 Exit: 47.53383, -123.52996 I plan to email this trip report to WTA and humbly suggest that they update how they characterize this trail. I think at the least, they should have a regular listing for the Wynoochee Pass trail, which is a route in good standing with both the Forest Service and the Park Service. The current "Sundown Lake Way Trail" entry might be more appropriate for the two routes outlined above that go from the pass to the lake. I would happily volunteer to lead a hike for anyone from WTA who wants to see the area and confirm this for themselves! If you've read this far, I hope you found it informative. I know it's a lot, but I wanted to write, if not the definitive description of the trail(s), at least a trip report that collects a lot of information and I hope resolves some of the confusion.
column98: Hiking Sundown Lake Way Trail The Sundown Lake Way Trail has faded into history over the years, and even veteran hikers have a hard time  following it. Formerly a "sister" to the Upper South Fork Skokomish trail, this route paralleled the Upper South Fork Skok, beginning in Olympic National Forest and then entering the National Park to join the trails near Sundown Lake. Now though, the Sundown Lake Way Trail has been reclaimed by the forest. Visitors will need route-finding and map reading skills, and a hardy disposition to navigate the former route. Toilet Information No toilet at trailhead More information about toilets WTA worked here in 2018! Hike Description Written by Multiple authors contributed to this report, WTA Community
column106: Finally checked this one off of my bucket list. We started at Wynoochee Pass TH and used the way trail to go on up to Sundown Lake for a few nights. Road: long, dusty and potholed. Better with high clearance vehicle. But if you go slow, everyone should be ok. Trail to Pass: Pretty easy. There is a rock slide at very beginning of trail. With the amount written about this, I expected a much worse scene. It was easy and no problem at all. About 2 miles in is a worse section. The trail was eroded at the point where it crosses a stream. It was difficult to get a footing because of loose dirt and rocks. I was very uncomfortable with my overnight pack going down. On the way back I ended up taking off my pack to climb up. It’s definitely doable just something to be aware of.  Also a few downed trees. All passable, some just take a moment to figure out how to go over/around/under. Before getting to the pass, the trail becomes overgrown. This really narrows the path and makes it very easy to take a misstep and slide down the hill. There were many sections where it was obvious someone did just that. Be careful. It’s difficult to see where you are stepping. The pass was very pretty. Wildflowers and berries everywhere. As well as mosquitos. Now on to the way trail. The report from Sabbaru below was a life saver. I saved the way points. I would have never found the entrance to the way trail without the first waypoint. We turned off and went down a pretty steep decline. A few pink flags marked the trail. It popped us out into the first meadow. There really wasn’t any path and again without the waypoint from Sabbaru below I would have wandered around in circles. When we entered the meadow I used my GPS to make my way diagonally across the meadow. Step carefully. It is very marshy.  Take note there are two meadows. You will go through a small wooded area to second meadow before getting to the outer edge of the final meadow. There is a pink flags marking a tree and almost directly behind it is the path leading up and out. Shortly you will come to a small ravine with a rope to help you get down. Not very steep at all. The rest of the trail is fairly easy to navigate. At this point it was the pink ribbons that helped me find the way. They are there. Just have to look really carefully. I think I would have eventually found my way because there is a trail. But it would have taken me way longer without the ribbons because there are game trails everywhere. If you plan to take way trail back I suggest recording your path so you can follow it back. It is very easy to miss the final trail up out of meadow back to main trail Finally we connected to the main trail. Now. Here is where it gets bad! Reports talk about overgrowth. This was overgrowth on steroids. I am unsure how much longer this trail will be navigable without some maintenance. The overgrowth completely takes over the trail and the brush on the cliff side is slowly eroding the trail. Also the woody trailing evergreens result in thick branches that are about an inch above the ground and completely hidden. Huge tripping hazards. The trail is very narrow. And there are even sections that have eroded leaving a hole on the trail which cannot be seen. Which could result in a very painful fall. This is a very dangerous section of trail. Be careful going through. Finally made it to intersection for Sundown Lake. The trail to Lake is absolutely stunning. Gorgeous meadows, wildflowers and views. The lake is beautiful. There is a campsite right at beginning of loop around lake. We walked as far as we could go for the second campsite. We were stopped at a significant slide. Someone rigged a rope but for the life of me I couldn’t see a way to make it work safely for me. So I turned back. I think the Park Service should NOT issue unlimited permits for this area. If one person is at the first established campsite you don’t have many other options. There is a gravely rocky flat area at the base of trail leading to Six Ridge. Not ideal. There is one flat spot on meadow area before entering the lake. Completely exposed. So if someone is in the one established site. And you cannot navigate to second campsite. Well. Not many other options. I even used a raft to search the edges of entire lake and never saw a second campsite. Also. The campsite has no lake access. You can’t even see the lake behind the vegetation. You have to walk down and around, over a creek to get to the lake. Now the lake was beautiful. Fish were jumping. But I prefer a campsite where I can walk out my tent, sit in my chair and see/walk to the lake.  I am glad I checked this off my bucket list. But would not do it if I was looking for a relaxing lakeside backpack camp experience. One of the days we hiked to  Sundown Pass. Stunning views. The pass is literally a sign at a tree. We continued for another 1/4 mile and popped out into an amazing meadow with tarns and view for miles.definitely worth the extra 2 miles round trip on a fairly easy trail. Lastly the reported miles are off. I recorded 7 miles to lake and almost same exact mileage back. Making it about 14 miles round trip. I have never done the regular trail so I can’t say if it is easier or longer? The way trail is definitely doable and I am extremely grateful for Sabbaru (trip report below) for sharing the waypoints. Mosquitos and Horse flies: out in force. Armies of them. I hope this helps anyone considering this hike.

column60: What a great hike! Started out at 8:15 this morning in a heavy fog, but by the time I was about 3 miles into the hike the fog lifted and I was able to see the mountain. As people have mentioned your pretty much exposed the whole trip so make sure you have plenty of water. Another note is to make sure you have a good pair of fitted shoes, the trip back from Johnson Ridge Observatory is all down hill on a fairly steady decline and your toes will be hitting the inside of your toe box if they aren't. The trail is very well maintained and would make a great hike to see a sunrise. I believe the reason it gets moderate/hard rating is because of being exposed and if your not prepared for the heat you could find it hard.
column98: Hiking Hummocks Loop Try this day hike as an introduction to Mount St. Helens for visitors who’ve never been here, or if they haven't been in a long time. Head left from the trailhead and stop at the interpretive signs along the way that describe the formation of the hummocks — large mounds of volcanic rock and gravel. After a shy mile keep left on the Boundary Trail to ascend to Johnston Ridge, hiking three miles to the Loowit Viewpoint and another shy mile to the Johnston Ridge Observatory. The trail here is exposed, so bring plenty of sun protection and water. The views of the broken mountain and the bare plains surrounding it get more dramatic with every step! Escape the heat and refill your water bottle in the Observatory, or listen to a presentation by one of the knowledgeable rangers. On your way back, keep left at the junction with the Hummocks Trail to complete the loop along the North Fork Toutle River, and then through marshlands and young forest back to the parking lot. Going further : As you see early in your hike, the Hummocks Trail is also the start of the Boundary Trail, stretching to the east for 57 miles to Council Lake in the heart of the South Cascades. With some advance planning and permits in hand, experienced backpackers can include the Boundary Trail on loop trips of the Loowit Trail around Mount St. Helens itself, or the Lakes Trail through the Mount Margaret Backcountry. Hike Description Written by Steven Payne , WTA Correspondent
column106: Great weather. Trail conditions were great.Road is open past learning center all the way to parking for this trail. Sí if your trying to get directly and the map says the road is closed, you can get to the trail head.

column51:
Camp Brown, Champion Beach, Oxbow Loop Trail —
              Sep. 13, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-09-13.164648830361)
column60: Trail was clear and easy to follow. Outhouse could be cleaner but was good enough.
column98: Hiking Champion Beach It's a very short walk from the trailhead to Champion Beach. Along the way, you'll cross a couple of bridges and pass through typical lush Middle Fork forest. The big attraction is the beach, though. It's a big part of the river with beautiful green water and huge rocks. There's lots of room to spread out and tons of trails that lead away from the main beach. WTA worked here in 2023!
column106: We had warm weather and dry trails that were well maintained. The river isn't very high right now, but we did see many people fishing. The road is smooth and paved so anyone can drive out there.

column60: Left the car near the BP Heron Center, walked up and down the beach a bit, and checked out the half-mile Terrell Marsh loop trail. Trail Conditions. Not much beach with the tide at +9, but you can also walk along the road... The Terrell Marsh trail was well-maintained, no blowdowns or mud. Highlights. Ducks. Crowds. Couple of people on the beach around noon, plentiful parking, the campground looked mostly empty.
column98: Hiking Birch Bay State Park Terrell Creek Marsh is one of the few remaining saltwater/freshwater estuaries in northern Puget Sound. The half mile loop through a mixed forest of maple, alder, paper birch, cedars, and hemlock has 10 informative signs along the way. There are 1.5 miles of saltwater shoreline to explore. Hiking opportunities at Birch Bay SP include the 1/2 mile Terrell Marsh Loop and 1.5 miles of saltwater shoreline. Migratory waterfowl, American Bald Eagles, Great Blue Heron, and smaller song birds can be seen.
column106: Birch Bay is a nice place to spend some time. We camped here while doing some clamming. The atmosphere is typical for a state park, lots of RVs, school kids during the day, some great scenery, and camping prices that are too high. The Terrell Marsh trail was nice with a few wildflowers and a heavy west-side fern motif. The beach is easily reached from the camground. Sunset hosted a dozen people, views of the coastal range in Canada, and a tide 13’ higher than earlier in the day!

column8:
Sunrise Point Trail, Cirque Rim Nature Trail —
              Sep. 20, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-09-20.223221028907)
column51:
Klahhane Ridge, Sunrise Point Trail, High Ridge Trail, Hurricane Hill —
              Oct. 10, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-10-11.115411149311)
column60: Loop from the parking lot along the Cirque Rim Nature Trail to Sunrise Point. Road Conditions. Paved road and parking lot at Hurricane Hill. Restrooms and gift shop were being run out of containers. Tap with potable water. Trail Conditions. Except for the spur trail out to Sunrise Point, the trail was paved, and clear of obstacles. Highlights. Marmots in the meadows below the parking lot, and overly tame deer along the trail. Too hazy to see across the strait to Vancouver Island, but clear view of Mt Olympus and the Bear Gulch fire. Crowds. Expected a long line to get into the park on such a beautiful Saturday afternoon, but there was no wait at the entrance station. The parking lot was busy, but plenty of spots were available. The trails were busy, too, but no congestion. Post-Hike. Hand-rolled ice cream at Mix-It Shack in Port Angeles.
column98: Hiking Sunrise Point Trail A short dead end trail coming off the High Ridge trail at Hurricane Ridge in Olympic National Park.
column106: TLDR: Hurricane Ridge and Obstruction Point roads are closed, even though the park website doesn’t list any alerts—likely due to the government shutdown (details below). We didn’t hike Hurricane Hill, but I tagged this trail so others are aware. We set out to hike the Lillian Ridge Way Trail, but when we reached Hurricane Ridge and tried to turn onto Obstruction Point Road, the gate was down and the road was closed. At the restroom area, there was a sign saying all cars had to be off the ridge by 4:15 p.m., and they were enforcing it strictly. We got back to our car at 4:10, just as NPS staff were driving around the lot with loudspeakers telling everyone they had five minutes to leave. I checked the Hurricane Ridge webcam today and the parking lot is completely empty, so it looks like they may have closed it for the weekend or for the entire government shutdown. Once again, the park website hadn’t been updated with any notice. Our backup hike was Klahhane Ridge, and it didn’t disappoint. About 9.8 miles round trip with 2,700 feet of elevation gain from Hurricane Ridge. The fall colors were beautiful, and the views of the Bailey Range were incredible. Trekking poles are recommended since the ridge is narrow, steep, and rocky in sections. I’ve always overlooked the trails near PA, but they’re wonderful. We only saw three other hikers all day, and I’ll definitely be back for more.

column60: Toilet Paper Falls, a trip report by infodawg. The falls area was strewn with toilet paper, almost everywhere we could see, save for the shore near the river. It was heartbreaking to see. This is OUR public land people, can we not have decent access??? The smaller river channel leaving the pool below the falls contained human feces, and perhaps dog feces. This small channel was a fecund stew of nastiness, and contained quite noticeable algae(?) blooms and other nasty looking byproducts. Where the small channel rejoins the river, there was a whirlpool of heavy foam. I'm not including any pics of this mess because A, I was too disgusted to take any, and B, if you read this report, I don't want you to see what I saw. It was absolutely heartbreaking and disgusting. (trust me, we had to eat lunch here, it was either here or find another spot to cook.) However, in the photo I uploaded, you can see all the foam swirling in the water where the small channel returns to the river. My question is this: should we the public expect better of nature areas that we own and that we entrust the government to manage, and profit from? Should we expect a site like Wynoochee Falls to be functioning, welcoming and clean? Or should we rather resign ourselves to renaming it Toilet Paper Falls?
column98: Hiking Wynoochee Falls Wynoochee Falls will entice you to spend more time than you’d expect on a half-mile round-trip hike. The falls are pretty, and the pool at the bottom is nice for wading. There is a gravel bar that is perfect for picnics, and there are some good rock scrambling options. The trail to the falls is wide, and there are occasional mounds of dirt that narrow the trail. For the young (or young at heart), these are fun to run up and down. The trail quickly arrives at the falls, where several social trails make their way down to the gravel bar at the base of the falls. Pick one that looks safe and will minimize erosion and make your way down to the falls. When you’re done enjoying Wynoochee Falls, be sure to visit Maidenhair Falls. A few miles down the road, it’s accessible via another mile-long trail. Hike Description Written by Mike On A Hike , WTA Correspondent
column106: The road gate is closed, which ads about 2.3 miles (according to apple watch) to trailhead. The trailhead is very easy to miss, just look for an old sign post with the sign missing on the left. The trail is flat and easy with beautiful views. At the falls the mosquitoes let us know they were there but it wasn’t too bad. We were able to sit and have lunch without issue. It is also very clear that people use this spot as there were soiled childrens underwear and other human items left behind. Very happy we did this during the winter and we were able to avoid any crowds. No snow on road or trail on the day we were there.

column60: Great spot for a winter stroll with 3 generations of family (and all ability levels). The wind was a little biting but sunshine pretty welcome after days of rain. Spotted a harrier hawk and some other smaller songbirds. Definitely recommend dropping into the interpretive center. The woman staffing (volunteering?) it made our visit something special — made us hot tea and cocoa (really helped us warm up after the cold walk), set us up with some coloring sheets for the kiddo (there’s a small kid corner) and taught us about the history of the wetlands. The building is spectacular and has some cool indoor and outdoor interpretation. My in-laws are excited to return.
column98: Hiking Saltese Flats Wetland Historically an important wetland habitat in the Spokane Valley, Saltese Flats was drained for agricultural use in the late 1800s and served as farmland until recently. Spokane County, in partnership with Ducks Unlimited and the Inland Northwest Land Conservancy, purchased 126 acres of the former wetland with Washington Wildlife and Recreation Program funding and began the restoration process in 2019. After a few short years of restoration work, the wetland is well on its way to recovery and has become an important stopover site for migratory waterfowl, as well as a wide variety of other birds and animals that once again call the wetland home. Saltese Flats is also open to nonmotorized recreational use on the raised footpaths overlooking the wetlands. There are 4.5 miles of trails on Saltese Flats, and the area is directly adjacent to the 552-acre Saltese Uplands with several additional trails. Toilet Information Toilet at trailhead More information about toilets Wheelchair Accessibility All of the trails indicated on the map as "elevated walking trails" are wide trails consisting of crushed and packed gravel. Trails marked "walking trails" are dirt pathways adjacent to the wetland an may not be suitable for wheelchair access. Hike Description Written by Holly Weiler, WTA Correspondent
column106: Recent snow made keeping the path a bit difficult ultimately as someone who is not too familiar with the trail, but it was easy enough to navigate. Plenty of Northern Harriers hunting, among several other species of birds this time of year; notably, Black Billed Magpies, American Kestrels, Ringneck Pheasants, and Mallards.

column60: My month is off to a small start for the Hike-a-Thon thanks to work. I walk most weekday mornings in LBA Park in Olympia. A gem of a place. No big views or water. Just lovely walking in the woods with some really big trees in places. Perfect for littles or to get a few miles in when you can’t go big. This is my favorite tree. Sometimes there are deer and other critters if you go early or late. Before sunrise you can often hear the owls.
column98: Hiking LBA Park The LBA of LBA Park stands for Little Baseball Association, but there is much more to do than just play baseball at this urban park. The Little Baseball Association is Olympia’s version counterpart to youth Little League, and in 1974, they donated the land to the City of Olympia to guild the park facilities. There are 4 miles of gentle walking trails in the adjoining LBA Woods that are great for families with strollers. A recently-marked loop trail is barrier-free, though users may want to refer to trip reports to determine if recent conditions have make in inaccessible for wheelchairs. There is a specifically-labelled off-leash dog trail here, though please be respectful throughout the rest of the park and leash your pet everywhere else. You can also find picnic areas, a playground and athletic fields. Toilet Information No toilet at trailhead More information about toilets WTA worked here in 2022 and 2021! Hike Description Written by Claudia Lopez , WTA Community
column106: Happy New Year! I decided the perfect way to start would be with a little hike close to home - LBA Woods fit the bill perfectly! I’ve lived in the Olympia Area for 8 years and had never been, but this will definitely be a regular spot for my dog and I. There are tons of trails in the park, so you can out together your own route. There is even an off-leash trail for dogs! (We did not do that since my dog is a flight risk.) We tried to follow the Woods Loop on AllTrails, but missed some turns, leading to a 2.4mi trip instead of 2.9. There were a couple of blow downs, but they were easy enough to step over. It wasn’t really muddy, either. We saw a few people and dogs, but not too many. It was, after all, only 37 and somewhat drizzly! Parking is free and there is plenty of suave in the lot. The caveat is that during Little League season, this will get full and people will park on the street. All in all it was a good little hike and a good way to kick off the year!

column51:
High Hut Snowshoe, Bruni's Snow Bowl Hut —
              Feb. 5, 2026 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2026-02-05.222923622867)
column60: Got to the trailhead (Upper Lot) about 8:30, only 2 other cars in the lot. The rail is mostly snow free, with only a few spots where you’d need to walk on the snow (hard, crusty, and only a few inches deep at most). We hiked in trail runners and never needed even microspikes. A few spots on the way downhill where trekking poles were nice. Had a great time at the hut with only 5 people total showing up. Really nice weather and great views of Mt Rainer.
column98: Hiking Bruni's Snow Bowl Hut Access to the south district of the huts, managed by the Mount Tahoma Trails Association , is via a series of steep forest roads. Climbing almost the entire way, the trek can be tiring, but don’t let this discourage you. The views are well worth it. While hiking, be cautious of logging trucks driving on the forest road — a partnership between the Department of Natural Resources and the logging company allows provides us access to these amazing huts! The lower parking lot has a pit toilet facility for use before starting on your trek. Start up the road and pass by the Lower Yurt Trail after 0.88 mile. Stay on the main road throughout a series of switchbacks until you reach a low saddle at 1.33 miles from the middle parking lot. Here, the road veers right, where you can continue up to High Hut — closer, but a steeper hike. Following the trail around to the left, you'll enjoy a somewhat flatter grade for a short while. Look for peek-a-boo views of Mount Rainier to your left until the trail begins climbing again. You'll have another 0.8 mile of steep uphill before this section peaks beneath a banner of prayer flags strung up across the trail. From this colorful indicator, continue through more forest on a flat grade that begins descending downhill to a junction with the road leading to The Yurt — the furthest flung hut on the system. Stay to the right and begin the final moderate uphill jaunt, just 0.25 mile to Bruni's. The elevation of Snow Bowl is 42,50 feet and provides beautiful views of Mount St. Helens, Mount Adams, Mount Rainier and the Olympic Mountains. All huts have a wood stove, oven, stovetop, bunk beds/mattresses, outdoor pit toilet and cooking utensils. Reservations to stay overnight must be obtained via the Mount Tahoma Trails Association website . Popular day hikes include the Next of Kin Trail, Griffin Mountain and Anderson Lake.
