Hike Description Written by Heath Jones , WTA Correspondent
column106: I started Hiking at 12:05 pm. the Road is the same as I remember from last year. very much drive-able on a sedan. Trail to Bruni's snow bowl: 3.5 miles from the TH. not much snow, only 2-3 patches of snow. The last ½ mile to the Bruni's bowl has consistent snow, but there's none surrounding the Hut. Went to the Gazebo too, very beautiful, with so many interesting things inside. a huge thank you to Judy and her family and the volunteers who built this beautiful place. I could see St Helens, Adams in the distance and Rainier obviously was the star of the show. Only 2 people were living in the hut then, but on my way back saw another 5-6 people were heading to the Hut. Trail to High Hut: 3 miles from TH. Only snow is on the last stretch to the Hut. 0.3 miles only. slippery snow at the end of the day, but not too much deep. barely 2-3 inch deep at places. A group of 6 women were staying at the Hut, they welcomed me inside and we hung out there for an hour. my intention was to catch the sunset, and I wasn't disappointed at all. We saw a fiery sunset, the Mountain was glowing and the western sky was in fire! After the sunset, I walked back 3 miles to the TH in the dark. didn't see anyone in the dark. At 7pm, 10 cars parked at the Upper TH. Overall a great hike, although there's an extremely small amount of snow in the mountains. It almost felt like a spring day today. the thermometer at the Gazebo displaying 65 degrees today. but after 2:30 pm, clouds rolled in and got a little bit colder. After sunset, my car was showing 46 degrees at the Trailhead. 10.6 miles with 2625 feet of gain. Met very friendly and welcoming people in both the Huts! 😊

column8:
Liberty Lake Regional Park - Liberty Lake Loop Trail —
              Jun. 6, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-06-06.132747587400)
column51:
Liberty Lake Regional Park - Liberty Lake Loop Trail —
              Oct. 10, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-10-10.224005470899)
column55: Liberty Lake Regional Park - Liberty Lake Loop Trail
column60: We parked and hiked in via Pine Terrace Ln on the west of the trail system. From here it's about 1.25 miles to the bridge over Liberty Creek, which still features pretty high runoff from Mica Peak. You can also spot an old moonshine or whiskey still from bootleggers of long ago near the bridge. The trail in passes marsh and runs alongside the creek with excellent tree cover throughout. From there the cedar grove and lookout points are highlights. The trails are well-maintained throughout, with many sections shared by hikers, bikers, and horses. Beware mosquitoes near the marsh!
column98: Hiking Liberty Lake Regional Park - Liberty Lake Loop Trail Liberty Lake Regional Park has it all: lakeshore, wetlands, a campground, an ORV park, BBQ areas and playgrounds. But the draw for hikers is the network of excellent backcountry trails. There are ample opportunities for any number of out and back hikes but for the full tour of all the trail highlights, hike the Liberty Lake Loop Trail. Start out from the parking area on the Liberty Creek trail which officially begins just past the campground. You will have to walk from the parking area a short ways to the trailhead. After just under a mile you will come to a junction that marks the beginning of the loop. You can go either way since both trails eventually connect back to this same spot, but most hikers choose to take the left fork. From here the trail goes for just under half a mile before coming to another fork. Stay left to get close to the creek on the Split Creek Trail (revamped by WTA in 2019) or stay right to remain in the trees on the Liberty Creek Trail. Both trails closely parallel each other and are virtually the same length. These two trails merge after .85 miles to deliver hikers to a cedar grove, a good place to rest up and stare in awe at some tall trees. The trail quickly leaves this grove behind as it ascends up a dozen switchbacks to Sam Hill. As you near the top look out to views of Liberty Lake below. The tour of attractions continues ahead as you come to Liberty Falls and then, after rounding the corner and heading up another short section of switchbacks, the Camp Hughes Cabin. From the cabin, wind down and descend along the Edith Hansen Trail where you might encounter horseback riders. Stay straight at the junction for the Mica Peak Trail unless you want some additional mileage and elevation gain on this spur that makes for a good destination on its own. Keep on to meet back up with the trail to the parking lot. Note that Spokane County Parks charges a $10 vehicle parking fee during the summer months (see Driving Directions below for details). Discover Passes do not apply/are not necessary for County Parks. The loop can also be accessed via two other methods (which do not require paying the vehicle parking fee): Via the Idaho Road (equestrian) trailhead in Liberty Lake Regional Park. Via the Mackenzie Reserve , using the Zephyr Connector trail. Please note that the reserve's parking lot is small. WTA worked here in 2019! Hike Description Written by Charlie Wakenshaw, WTA Staff
column106: The road to the campground is closed, so you have to start at the lake. Nice colors

column60: I used a bicycle from Selkirk Lodge and turned right at the Nova Hut onto the Quartz Mtn Loop. I continued to the start of the Ragged Ridge Trail where I stashed the bike in the bushes and took a very nice trail to the summit of Ragged Mtn. There is some crusty snow on the road section but not enough to impede cycling. Unfortunately, views were obscured by low clouds when I got to the highpoint, but the forest is pleasant along the way. Clouds lifted and the sun came out right when I got back to the car. 10.4 miles RT and 2015' gain.
column98: Hiking Ragged Ridge A hike to Ragged Ridge is an all-day tour of the wide variety of trail experiences that Mount Spokane State Park offers. Begin at Selkirk Lodge, a place that is generally filled past capacity on a sunny weekend during Nordic ski season, but almost always devoid of cars come the warmer months of the year. Follow any of the Nordic Trails leading out to Nova Hut at Junction 3, passing through second-growth forests on old logging roads that have been converted to one of the state's best Nordic trail systems. Late summer users can expect to find huckleberries and could potentially see resident deer, moose, coyote, or black bear. The trail system here is open to non-motorized multi-use, but is rarely busy. From Junction 3, hikers should follow the Quartz Mountain Loop Trail (part of the Nordic system, and not the same trail as the one leading to the summit of nearby Quartz Mountain, home of a rentable fire lookout cabin). Approximately 1 mile into the hike along the loop, watch for the sign on the right indicating the way to Ragged Ridge. The trail drops down to a saddle, entering a Natural Forest Area (NFA) and quickly changing from an ecosystem that has been heavily impacted by human use into a near-wilderness. The NFA and Natural Area Preserve (NAP) beyond it are only open to hikers. Respect the special forest and the plant and animal species it protects by following LNT practices. The trail descends to a saddle, where a sign indicates the NAP. It then climbs a series of switchbacks along the lower portion of the ridge before coming out on top, where the views are spectacular in all directions. Look back and note the Quartz Mountain Lookout peeking out above the trees on Quartz Mountain; look to the south to see Newman Lake looking close enough to dive into; to the east, see numerous Idaho Lakes. The trail continues out to the edge of the NAP, where a fence marks a boundary that is slightly on the Idaho side of the border; here is where Mount Spokane State Park crosses state boundaries, even if only a little bit. Turn back here and retrace the route for a round trip hike of 15.1 miles. ** Note that bikes and horses are prohibited in the Natural Area Preserve. Signs indicate where horses and bikes are allowed. ** Hike Description Written by Holly Weiler, WTA Correspondent
column106: Every winter I wait for the perfect conditions for a Ragged Ridge trip! It doesn't often happen: it's only accessible via ski trails but it's off the groomed trail system. It needs to have fresh snow + cold enough conditions for powder + a sunny day since it's a long approach that's most worthwhile when there are views. Today was the day! It was absolutely gorgeous out there. Selkirk Lodge/the parking lot/and close-in Nordic trails were VERY busy today with the junior ski races happening this weekend, but once we were out on the trail to Ragged Ridge we had the only tracks save for the resident moose and some snowshoe hares. Today was also day #4 in a row for visiting my backyard trails, and I already have plans to be back up there tomorrow! Mount Spokane is amazing for being super close while still having a total backcountry feel. That's especially true of Ragged Ridge, a protected Natural Area within the park. #LoveLocalTrails #WTAStaff

column60: Very easy to get to from Spokane and the surrounding area. There's a nice network of trails. We started from the West Trailhead and followed what was called The Emerald Necklace. We used Organic Maps (Open Street Map app) and did a nice loop of the necklace that culminated with the peak, which isn't particularly interesting but a nice pause amidst the trail. Lots of signs of wildlife but we didn't see any aside from a single raven. Might make a great snowshoe trail in the wintertime.
column98: Hiking Antoine Peak Conservation Area Acquired in four phases through Spokane County’s Conservation Futures Program, with additional funding secured through the Washington State Recreation and Conservation Office, the Antoine Peak Conservation Area consists of 1296 acres of conservation land and offers fantastic views overlooking Liberty Lake, the Spokane Valley, and north to Mount Spokane and the Selkirk Range. The trail system consists of old logging roads converted to trails and newly constructed single track. Demonstrating the Conservation Futures Program’s commitment to benefiting wildlife, conserving natural resources, and improving opportunities for passive recreation in Spokane County, the Conservation Area is home to numerous wildlife and plant species. Hikers, snowshoers, skiers, birders, mountain bikers and equestrian users alike could potentially spot red-tail hawk soaring overhead, listen to pileated woodpeckers at work on surrounding trees, come across signs of the resident white-tailed deer, moose, and elk populations, or spot such locally rare trees as Pacific yew. Through additions and improvements over the years, there are now three different access points for the trail network on Antoine Peak. The west side access at Brevier Road offers the most direct route to the summit of Antione Peak, as well as the quickest connection to the Emerald Necklace route that travels around the base of the peak at approximately the 3000-foot level. This access point offers the best views of the Spokane Valley. From the trailhead visitors can choose to follow either the communications tower access road in the trees or a single-track trail crisscrossing a west-facing meadow as it climbs for just under a mile to an overlook. Royal Riblet’s Mansion, home of Arbor Crest Winery, is visible on the cliff overlooking the Spokane River to the southwest; Peone Prairie and its checkerboard of agricultural land lies to the northwest. Continue up trail to the first intersection and veer right for the Emerald Necklace loop, for a total of just over five miles round-trip and views of the east Spokane Valley all the way to Liberty Lake. The west side of the mountain is transformed into a sea of gold in the early spring, when arrowleaf balsamroot cover the hillsides on this generally dry side of the mountain. Adjacent to the trail, watch for rocky mountain junipers popping up among the larger Ponderosa pines and fir trees. For those who would prefer to summit rather than take the round-the-mountain route, veer left at the intersection and continue uphill just under half a mile along the old roadbed that also accesses the communications towers on the summit. At the second intersection, turn right and continue uphill for a half-mile to the summit; the left- hand trail is the return route for the Emerald Necklace loop. This route is also frequently traveled by workers accessing the communication towers at the summit, so watch for vehicles along the way. For those who access the property from the east at Canfield Gulch off Lincoln Road, the options consist of a longer, more gradual ascent via an old logging road converted to trail, or a slightly steeper single track option. Both connect to the Emerald Necklace at a main intersection, and then continue to ascend via single track to the summit of Antoine Peak. The old logging road option that leads northwest from the parking area passes Leland Pond enroute, offering the best chance for spotting a moose. The trails on this side of the peak follow the small streams that feed the pond, where hikers can view rare Pacific yew trees. Increased moisture on this side of the mountain yields increased diversity in plant life. In the spring, watch for trillium and shooting stars along seasonal seeps, giving way to lupine blooms and Indian paintbrush later in the season. The most recent addition to the Conservation Area is the Etter Ranch property, with a trailhead located in the Spokane Valley at Wellesley and Flora. Acquired in 2019 with the trailhead opening in 2021, trails here are still under construction. The completed Arrowleaf Trail is the main connector leading to the Emerald Necklace, with nearby Lost Apple Trail serving as a shorter and lower elevation option. Toilet Information Toilet at trailhead More information about toilets Wheelchair Accessibility Since several of the trails at Antoine Peak are converted road beds, portions of the Antoine Peak trail system can be accessed via wheelchair. Please note that none of the trails here are built to ADA standards, and visitors can expect steeper grades in some areas and varied surfaces. WTA worked here in 2025, 2024, 2023, 2022 and 2021! Hike Description Written by Holly Weiler, WTA Correspondent
column106: We only did a mile into the CA, but the trail was nice that we followed.

column8:
Iceberg Point, Upright Head Preserve, Point Colville, Shark Reef Sanctuary —
              Apr. 5, 2024 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report.2024-04-05.0340010687)
column51:
Chadwick Hill, Iceberg Point, Point Colville, Shark Reef Sanctuary —
              Jun. 15, 2024 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2024-06-16.151706157491)
column60: We had a full day to explore Lopez, starting with Iceberg Point. Trails are in great shape. A few flowers but more to come in the next few weeks. Don’t forget binoculars. Not the first time we saw baby seals here. Our next stop was Point Colville. Perfect spot for lunch, protected from the wind. Good spot for birds. We saw a kingfisher, heron, eagle and vultures here. Next stop was Shark Reef. I’ve been coming here for 40 years and didn’t think there was anything they could do to improve it until I saw they replaced the stinky old outhouse. Amazing job SJ Co! It’s fresh as a daisy in there. There was the usual collection of seals out on the rocks. We saw a family of sea lions pass through the channel, an eagle dive for its lunch, then, when we were fully satisfied with our trip, we saw an orca! We got in line but missed the 5:00 ferry because they only had room for about a dozen cars. This gave us a couple of hours for one more hike. Nice trails right by the ferry with an eagle nest and my first orchid this spring. Will try to update pics when I make it home.
column98: Hiking Point Colville Enjoy wildflowers, solitude, and gorgeous views of Puget Sound on this lovely little hike down a pretty trail to Watmaugh Bay Beach. The park is located off Watmough Head Road, and the beach is beautiful; perfect for a picnic. This is a beautiful forest walk ending at some open bluffs with stunning views. Walk along the bluffs all the way to the END OF PUBLIC LANDS sign and then turn around and head back the way you came. Be sure to turn left into the woods to complete the loop. There is an outhouse at the trailhead and at the beach.
column106: Hiked a series of short but beautiful trails along the coast of Lopez Island. Great weather. A bit windy but that took any bug away. The Shark Reef sanctuary is the one the locals recommended for looking at seals. And surely enough, there were many there. But we went there around 9am and that was likely the seals' breakfast time. We could see them munching across the sea weeds with our binoculars. There were also interesting, loud, black birds with red beaks, which we were told later were oyster catchers. The Iceberg point trail had wonderful scenery and felt the most peaceful. We finished at Watmough bay, ascending to Chadwick Hill for the views and then connecting to Point Colville via Watmough Hill. We returned through the road as the Watmough Hill part was fun to do once but didn't seem entertaining enough for a second pass at it. The trails were all dry and there were many ripe salmonberry bushes at the shark reef trailhead. We saw very few people in the morning. The only place that started to be a bit crowded was the Watmough bay area past noon. Fortunately we got some alone time at the top swing on Chadwick Hill. This was a great way to discover the island. But the next time I'd likely go with a bike instead of a car. There are hills but none of them seemed very painful and the roads are wide enough to feel reasonably safe.

column60: Kid friendly trail hidden in the middle of South Hill.
column98: Hiking Nathan Chapman Memorial Trail The Nathan Chapman Memorial Trail connects the Heritage Recreation Center to the South Hill Community Park via a wide paved trail. Along the way it passes by man-made wetlands and through a forested corridor. Dogs are allowed but they must be kept on leash. Hike Description Written by Charlie Wakenshaw, WTA Staff
column106: the  trail is well maintained and paved, once entering the forested area it just gave me a good feeling being surrounded by nature. there is some noise from street traffic close to the streets but overall it was nice and serene. mostly level w a short uphill walk at one point. it was a pleasant stroll, a nice "walk in the woods". i did the loop as well as the straightaway to the school, overall a little over 2 miles. there were not many others on the trail today, this was early am...

column8:
Carbon River to Ipsut Falls, Chenuis Falls, Carbon River Rain Forest Nature Trail, Old Mine Trail —
              Nov. 3, 2024 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2024-11-04.124923689312)
column60: With lots of road closures and heavy snowfall in the park, I decided to spend the morning in the beautiful Carbon River area. It's one of my favorite areas to visit in the fall and winter where you can immerse yourself in the quiet forest and enjoy the misty views along the river. I stopped by the Carbon River Ranger station on my way in to chat with the rangers and get an update on the bridges over the Carbon River heading out to the falls. If you're visiting the park for the first time or are not sure what current conditions are in the park, I definitely recommend stopping at one of the ranger stations/visitor centers. Staff there generally have the most up-to-date info and are happy to recommend hikes that will work well for you and your group's interests, gear and abilities. The bathrooms at the parking area were in great shape, fully stocked and very clean. There was plenty of parking on this rainy morning. There were lots of brochures and trail maps in the box at the info sign; be sure to grab one if you're unfamiliar with the area. I visited the Old Mine trail on my way to the falls. The trail was in great shape and worth the side trip. It's steep with a few large steps to navigate but only 0.3 miles. There is currently a large pile of gravel in front of the trailhead, making it a bit difficult to spot. You can walk behind the gravel pile and from there the trail should be obvious. The trail to the falls was generally in good shape, with some wet muddy areas to go through so waterproof boots were definitely helpful. All four bridges over the river to the falls were still in and in good condition. The trail across the river bed was clear and easy to follow without needing cairns. Before I left, I checked out the Rainforest Nature trail, a short loop that leaves right from the parking area behind the information board. WTA and park trail crews did great work this summer replacing some of the rotting boards, making the trail much easier to navigate. If you head left on the loop, you'll encounter the new boardwalks. If you head right, you'll still need to cross older boardwalks with boards missing/damaged in many areas. If you'd like to avoid that, an out and back hike along the left side is a great option. I passed about 15 people all day, all on the main Carbon River road trail. Just a reminder to travel carefully when heading to this section of the park, I had a deer bolt in front of my car just before the ranger station and a few months ago the same thing happened with an elk in the same area.
column98: Hiking Old Mine Trail An infrequently-visited trail off the Carbon River Road, the Old Mine Trail follows a short but steep roadbed to a mineshaft. It's a good outing for kids, if they're willing to make the short push up the steep section. Just past the Carbon River Ranger Station, at the northwest entrance to Mount Rainier National Park, park your car and make your way down the flat, wide road converted to trail surrounded by greenery and the rushing of the river. After a bit more than a mile of hiking, look for a trail off to your right. This is the route to the Old Mine, a steep push through close forests of Western Washington's signature western red cedar, Douglas fir, swordfern and fluffy moss. Luckily, the surroundings and the shortness of this uphill push make it bearable -- after just 0.3 miles you'll arrive at the mineshaft. A hole in the hillside framed with ferns, the mine entrance is gated about a hundred feet in, so kids and curious adults can explore a bit in relative safety. There are some beat-up tracks, marking the beginning of the carts' journey into the earth to extract ore. Look around the immediate area for other signs of human activity. Stumps and newer trees indicate areas that may have been cleared in the past as staging platforms for the exploratory mine activity. WTA worked here in 2013! Hike Description Written by Multiple authors contributed to this report, WTA Community
column106: The Carbon River area is one of our favorite places during the winter! We decided to traverse the Old Mine trail for a change of pace. My son really enjoys the climb up to the mine and peering inside to see the old rails. The trail is in great shape and you get to enjoy walking through the moss covered doug firs and the old growth. After the climb to the mine we walked back down to continue the carbon river road. We were looking for a shorter hike, so we walked to our lunch spot near the river. The road is really easy to walk. It's flat the entire way, which makes it a really easy day! We saw some elk on the way in. They were very close to the road! In all, we only did about 4  miles, but you can go really far on this one! It's about 4 miles to Ranger Falls and Greek Lake or you can walk all the way to Ipsut camp (5 miles) and beyond!

column51:
Eagle Cliff (Cypress Island), North Cypress Island —
              Jan. 7, 2024 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report.2024-01-08.6826060474)
column60: Hiked this trail with a friend on a Friday afternoon. We were part of a kayaking tour group and Pelican Beach was a pit stop to our day. The hike is doable for all abilities and well-defined, so you needn’t worry about getting lost. My friend was tuckered out by the time we reached the summit, but I think that had more to do with the fact that we had just spent the morning paddling through choppy waters to get there. There is an option for adding Duck Lake (and other trails past that) if you feel like adding on some mileage. The trail network on Cypress Island is actually quite impressive. One could spend a lot of time and energy exploring if time and conditions permitted. Would love to visit this island again. The view at the top of the hike is worth the paddle and climb.
column98: Hiking Eagle Cliff (Cypress Island) Cypress Island Natural Resources Conservation Area (NRCA) is the largest relatively undeveloped island in the San Juan Islands and is home to over 5,200 acres of protected forests, wetlands, grasslands and tidelands. WTA worked here in 2017!
column106: Started the hike at 9:00 from Smugglers Cove and headed east on Smugglers Cove Trail, to just past Duck Lake. There's a 15 foot stretch on the north side of Duck Lake where the trail is underwater, but it can be circumvented by going through the brush. Previously hiked the same route end of November 2023. Some blowdowns since then, but mainly small trees and branches. If there's significant wind in the next few weeks, I would be concerned that the number of blowdowns could block the trail. Headed south at the junction onto Duck Lake Loop straight down to Eagle Harbor (did not take the spur to the left which says "Eagle Harbor"), then straight up the road to Reed Lake. There are lots of rough-skinned newts (highly toxic) on the road, so be careful where you step. Didn't attempt to go around Reed Lake for fear of running into more standing water on the trail. Saw bald eagles. We headed back down the road and lunched at Eagle Harbor, then headed up the coast taking the right hand trail, Duck Lake Loop. As you're turning right to head onto the peninsula, there's a nice reader board with Cypress Island history on it. Just a bit further east is a splendid pit toilet. Continue up Duck Lake Loop about a mile to the intersection with Pelican Beach Trail says ".5 miles". Take a right and after a quarter mile, the entrance to Eagle Cliff is on the left. As you approach the top of the cliff, there will be several spots for great views, but don't give up - get to the top. After returning on the Eagle Cliff Trail, we headed left to Pelican Beach where we were picked up. 8.5 miles. 5.5 hours.

column51:
Spokane Gulch, Jack's Run, Methow Community Trail —
              Jan. 1, 2026 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2026-01-01.195949137900)
column60: Yesterday (and today), there is horizon-to-horizon blue sky day with lots of snow in the valley and even more higher up.  Perfect day for a hike up Spokane Gulch.  Two people had broken trail to the junction with the Flagg Peak trail (they went up Flagg Peak).  We broke trail the rest of the way to the highest initial lookout point.  There were two novel differences from my many other times up Spokane Gulch (>125 times). First: This has been an atypical, last two and half months.  From mid-October to mid-November, there were great snow storms above 4,000 feet (occasionally, in a promising fashion, lower).  Even in very early December, Washington and Rainy Passes and Highway 20 were open and the valley was snow free), then the warm rains began, Highway 20 was closed and even the higher elevation snow began to melt.  There were floods on the west side of the Cascades and rivers on the east side rose to flood levels. US 2 was closed.  In the 13 years that I have been hiking the Spokane Gulch trail, the e phemeral stream, which the trail crosses some 9 times, only flows during periods of rapid spring snow melt.  During these series of mild, atmospheric rivers, this ephemeral stream had volumes of water coming down the hill. A December 17th hike up Sagebrush and Flagg mountain, three days after peak flows on the Methow, this ephemeral stream had sufficient volume that each trail crossing required some careful foot work to avoid getting wet.  This was true all the way to above the junction with the Flagg Mountain trail. Yesterday, when we did this hike, there was still plenty of water flowing -- you could actually hear it before you saw it.  In the mid-summer to early March, I have never hiked the Spokane Gulch trail when there is water flowing in this stream.  Walking up the snow-covered trail (well over a foot in the valley and approaching two feet on the bench leading to the lookout point[s]) and dealing with flowing water was a new, but interesting experience! There was a second issue: this long, gray, wet, the mild fall ended about 8 or 9 days ago when a series of snow storms consistently reached at or below the 1,800 foot level.  This unusually high water content snow coated the trees and cold nights further cemented the snow on the trees, especially those near the valley floor.  Snow loads became so great that trees (generally those with poor diameter to height ratios and mostly ponderosa pine, bent over, bowed in some cases almost forming a shepherd's crook and then suddenly snapping at the base of the live crown. Some broke near ground level, some up-rooted [especially Douglas-fir]). I can walk out to the back porch of where we are staying and see 15 broken or up-rooted trees.  So the first part of the Spokane Gulch trail goes through this forested zone where trees were breaking or up-rooting.  It was an initial concern, but we encountered only one new tree across the trail (easily crossed).  This issue was not present in the forest reached in the upper third of this trail. The four of us and our one dog all enjoyed this hike and recommend it.  Right now there is a broken trail.  We used spikes, but I don't think those are critical now -- I like the sure-footed aspect they provide.
column98: Hiking Spokane Gulch A trail ascending from the Methow valley floor towards Goat Wall, Spokane Gulch is a local favorite. Trails and roads continue on up to Flagg Mountain to the south or Goat Peak's lookout 4000 feet above the valley floor. From a historian’s perspective, there is much to see along this trail. The modern day hiker will enjoy its diverse geology, seasonal changes, and wide-open views of the Upper Methow Valley. Open to hiking year-round makes viewing seasonal changes a real joy. The first half mile of trail cuts across the meadow east of Mazama’s center. The recently improved Corral Parking area is your trailhead. There are privies available here. Hike towards the base of the mountain housing the fire lookout atop Goat Peak. After a half mile, cross a dirt road and enter the woods. At the roads’ edge you will find signs for Spokane Gulch’s old trailhead. Entering the woods, the trail winds up, down, and around through small talus slopes, cliff bands, and occasional dry drainages. The first non-native users of this hillside were likely miners, and lining this route are remnants of those years gone by. A sharp eye reveals adits and prospects at several locations. The miners’ dreams of riches never materialized here nor at most of the areas’ mines. By the mid 1920s the US Forest Service was busy putting fire lookouts atop every viable highpoint throughout the west. Goat Peak, high above your head, got its first lookout in 1924. Access to the lookout back then, was the trail you're on, but today, this lookout is best reached via the Goat Peak Lookout Trail. The Spokane Gulch Trail today gains roughly 1100 feet in two miles (though most of that gain is in just one mile). At 3100 feet of elevation, the trail turns abruptly to the left (signed) onto an old logging road. From here the views improve, offering continuous sights of the Methow Valley, the eastern North Cascades, and the Paysaten Wilderness. At about two miles you will reach the end of the established trail. Dubbed by locals Sagebrush Flats, the climate in this landscape creates a mixed sagebrush steppe. Springtime brings flowers, and summertime the fragrance of sage. In wintertime, though the route is under snow, the trail is frequently broken to this point. WTA Pro Tip: When you return to the trail head, remain parked there and walk over to the Mazama Store. Baked goods or a frosty pint enjoyed in their airy courtyard is hard to beat. If you’re looking for car camping there are two nearby state parks, and many national forest campgrounds as well. Toilet Information Toilet at trailhead More information about toilets Hike Description Written by Austin Smith , WTA Correspondent
column106: We’ve been hiking Spokane Gulch and skiing Mazama’s trails all week! The coverage has been pretty damn amazing despite low snowfall😊 We are hoping for a little more tonight. Basecamp is open but skate only and it ends at the Bush School. Trees were coming down from the heavy snow last week but they’ve mostly been cleared. Community Trail is great from Tawkes Foster Bridge all the way to Jack’s.

column60: Just a few steps across a bridge and you get away from the hustle and bustle of Leavenworth on an early spring weekend. There was packed snow in patches and some mud and puddles, but easy enough to navigate. The directions in the hike description mention a parking area off Commercial, but we sure didn't see one. We parked on the street in town, which is primarily paid parking. Another option would be to start the hike at Enchantment Park (see separate hike description), which accesses the same tails and has some parking.
column98: Hiking Blackbird Island - Waterfront Park Walk around an island in beautiful Waterfront Park in Leavenworth. Enjoy the sounds of birds calling, fish jumping, and plenty of informative signs telling the history of the area.
column106: Easy beautiful walk along the Wenatchee River in Leavenworth. Suitable for all abilities.  Strolling distance from main town area. Sunny beautiful day today.

column8:
Bus Trail, Poo Poo Point, One-View Trail, Tiger Mountain Trail, Paw Print Connector, Bootleg Trail, Preston Trail, Dwight's Way, Lingering Trail, High Point Trail —
              Apr. 8, 2024 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report.2024-04-08.7576238432)
column51:
Bootleg Trail, Fifteenmile Creek Railroad Grade, Paw Print Connector, Preston Trail —
              May. 8, 2024 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2024-05-08.185744449852)
column60: We wanted something with a more gradual elevation gain today, and figured there would be no views, so we settled on what I am calling the "West Tiger No-Summit Loop". We went all the way around West Tiger without hitting any of the summits. This was about 12 miles with somewhere between 2200-2500' of elevation gain. We took a side trip to Poo Poo Point along the way - this adds 1.2 miles and about 250' of elevation. ROUTE : To be fair, it's not a complete loop, since we did not walk the connector trail and road back to our cars at the end. We started at the Tradition Plateau Trailhead and took the Bus Trail, then the Poo Poo Point Trail over to Poo Poo Point. From there, we returned back to the One View Trail and climbed that all the way to the junction with the TMT. We followed the TMT to where it crossed the 15 Mile Railroad Grade. This is really one of the nicer sections of the TMT, and tends to be drier than what you find on the north side. We then followed the 15 Mile Railroad Grade NE, where it crosses the Main Tiger Mountain Road and then becomes the "Bootleg Connector Trail". It used to be called the "Paw Print Connector" after the old rest stop next to the road, but apparently the name is changing. Upon reaching the Bootleg Trail, we followed that to its end at the Preston Trail, then took the Preston Trail down to Dwight's Way. We took Dwight's Way west to the Lingering Trail, following that down to the High Point Trail, past the nice bench at the Trail Dragon (don't miss it!). We then took the High Point Trail back to our cars waiting at the bottom, and drove to pick up our other car at Tradition Plateau. SPRING FLOWERS : It's still pretty early spring on Tiger Mountain and not a lot is out at elevation. The yellow violets and trillium are blooming pretty well, and the elderberry and salmonberry are all sprouting. There is a lot of Palmate Coltsfoot just starting to bloom where the 15 Mile Railroad Grade crosses the Tiger Mountain Road. Other than that, I'd say wait 3-4 weeks for all the ferns to start sprouting, and more of the perennials plants and flowers will be out. BLOWDOWNS : Thanks to the trail crews who cleared all the blowdowns on the One View Trail and the Lingering Trail! There are new blowdowns in the following locations: 1) Tiger Mountain Trail, just above where it crosses the 15 Mile Railroad Grade - a vine maple with about a dozen trunks fell across two parts of the trail at a switchback, and 2) Bootleg Trail, just inside the NRCA boundary at about 2050' - these are fairly minor and rotten, so could maybe be taken care of without a saw. MUD : Mud was a recurring theme today, as it had been raining most of the morning. The worst mud was on the One View Trail below the vine maple arch, then again before reaching 15 Mile Gap, then on the Bootleg Trail in the usual spot around 1800'. I wore my trail runners for the whole hike, but they were somewhat soggy by the end. On a warm sunny day, the mud would be a non-issue. PEOPLE : Almost all the people we saw today were on the Poo Poo Point Trail - about 10 perhaps. We saw two trail runners on One View up by 15 Mile Gap, but other than that we saw no one else until one party coming up the bottom of the High Point Trail. This route is sort of the "hind end" of Tiger Mountain, but the trails are in really nice shape and it is a great place for some quiet forest walking.
column98: Hiking Paw Print Connector A connector trail on Tiger Mountain. Access from Tiger Mountain Trail, 15 Mile Railroad Grade, East Tiger, and Upper and Middle Bootleg Trail.
column106: Did a quick out and back in somewhat random directions.  Started on the Preston trail (took the direct shortcut on the way up, and the full trail on the way down).   Switched to Bootleg Trail, then Bootleg Connector (I think WTA calls this the Paw Print Connector?  The signage says otherwise).  At the end of the connector I continued onto the 15 mile RR grade for just a few yards until it met the TMT on the South Side of Tiger Mtn.  Was thinking to walk on that, but it was closed for logging. The flowers were pretty.  Took a photo of a white/purple trillium whos leaves were 9" across. The trail was not too muddy, except for a couple of spots low on the Bootleg trail.

column51:
Obstruction Point Road Snowshoe, Deer Ridge —
              Nov. 8, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-11-08.204056466415)
column60: Report on Obstruction Point Road.  Road is gravel with wash-boarding, but few potholes or difficult ruts. Drove in a Jeep Wrangler Rubicon with no problems. Also OK for SUVs and sedans, but not with timid drivers. Road is narrow in places with steep drop-offs.  Vehicles can pass, but with care.  Many blind corners. Spectacular scenery and good hikes starting along the road. Generally a decent road, as it is only access Obstruction Point TH.  Vault toilets at TH. More details and pictures at - www.deetezellimountainstories.wordpress.com
column98: Hiking Obstruction Point Road Snowshoe To start this hike, first register at the visitor's center then backtrack down the road a bit to a hairpin turn in the road where there is a pull off spot to park on the left side of the road. Do not start this snowshoe trip at the beginning of the actual road where it is too steep and dangerous to get down to the road bed. Instead start from the parking area described above and cross the road, then hike a few hundred feet up the road. Keep in mind that it might be tricky to get up the embankment from the road. Once on the embankment, go straight down the steep hill a few hundred feet to the Obstruction Point Road. Again, use caution here, the hill can be quite steep. The hike along the road is mostly flat with a little ups and downs, until you come upon Steeple Rock, where avalanche risk is not unheard of. Check with the visitor's center before you start the hike to ensure that it's safe to hike the road. The road to Steeple Rock is uphill, narrow and very windy. WTA Pro Tip: During high traffic periods like holiday breaks or New Years, call ahead and ask about wait times. Parking is limited due to snow coverage (not all lots remain open) and there can be 1-3 hour wait at times.
column106: Unorganized planning lead me to Deer Ridge trail and a little bit of obstruction point trail (goal was Maiden peak but failed due to snowshoes breaking). I took snowshoes but did not need them for deer ridge. It was surprisingly snowless until a bit before the camp. Road for deer ridge was clear driving in (just Potholes) and trail was in great conditions. I didn't realize that road for the deer camp must not be used, it was so picture perfect when I arrived, it hadn't been touched since the snowfall. At the camp the snow is just ~shoe high Because I made good timing I decided to continue on to Obstruction point with Maiden as a goal. I once again didn't need snowshoes until perhaps just pass half way to Maiden. The snow became tiresome at perhaps 1700m, and then became progressively more tiresome. All but one strap on my snowshoes ruptured, thus the "tiresome", speaking from someone that is still healing from a torn labrum...oops. I started to wonder about avalanche possibilities around 1800m just before the 1926m point, there is one sloppy and bare section to cross (sorry, all my maps are metric). I bailed on the Maiden idea because the going became too slow so I tried for the point. I picked a terrible line and hope nobody will see my postholing disgrace. So I turned around a few meters from the top because although the snow felt it would hold me. Everything beneath me was a mystery, I am was mostly on what felt like slabby rock or buried trees and I did not like that too much. On the way back I went up to Blue mountain and that was really nice. I've spent so long in the cascades that I forget you can see the ocean so close! Also a very cute family of deer calling camp their home. On the way down I realized I didn't appreciate how nice the upper section of the deer ridge was. With easy terrain and perfect views of the Royal Basin edge, it was really something special. The forest was so so but the bottom where the Rhodos are is a haven :)

column8:
Sleepy Hollow Trail, Mount Zion —
              Jun. 23, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-06-24.182449620264)
column60: The road to the Sleepy Hollow trail was in better shape than many in Olympic National Forest, but still had some pretty good-sized potholes, so you needed to pay attention on the drive in. Both trails were in good condition.  Didn't see any other people on the Sleepy Hollow trail.  There were a few hikers on the Mt. Zion trail, but it didn't seem crowded.  Rhododendrons were very much in bloom all along the trails, but the best flowers were near the summit, as some were just emerging from the buds.  Great view from the rocky outcrop a half mile or so from the Mt. Zion summit.
column98: Hiking Sleepy Hollow Trail The Sleepy Hollow trailhead shares Road 28 with the Mount Zion trailhead, which is two miles north of Bon Jon Pass. The trail starts downhill immediately on an old road, turning gradually into new trail. Eventually, hikers pops out onto a more secluded route that winds down to Gold Creek. From the Gold Creek crossing the trail continues uphill in a westerly direction on an old road. After a mile it rounds the nose of the ridge and turns south, descending a bit. There are good views into the Upper Dungeness drainage from here. After this viewpoint, maintenance has apparently ceased. The alder closes in and there are blackberry bushes to contend with as well. WTA worked here in 2020!
column106: We were looking for a hike on a sunny Fourth of July where we hoped to not encounter a lot of other hikers, and this one fit the bill perfectly. No official trail sign, but easy to locate on the opposite side of the large parking lot from the Mt. Zion TH. No big elevation gains/losses, no grand views, but if you want mostly easy walking for some distance, this is your trail. Sections of the trail are quite overgrown, though the way is never completely obscured. Some flora (Red Columbine, wild strawberries, scrubby paintbrush) some fauna (ambassador deer on the road in, grouse, bear scat, garter snake) to keep you entertained and aware.

column60: Parked at Owyhigh Lake trailhead on Sunrise road for a trail run loop: Owyhigh Lake - Eastside - Cowlitz Divide - Wonderland (thru Indian Bar / Summerland). Owyhigh in great condition thanks to recent trail work that took care of many blowdowns. I think there was just one blowdown the whole route. Water plentiful and good berries higher up. Nice weather for a break at Indian Bar. The climb up from there has a few snowfields as you approach the gap but no spikes needed. Panhandle Gap: the traverse higher up has untracked snowfield - if you’re up there look below and you will see an alternate route through minor snow fields lower down. Enjoy!
column98: Hiking Indian Bar - Summerland Traverse One of the most popular routes on Mount Rainier for its varied terrain, wide-open meadows, and incredible views, this 17-mile one-way hike along the mountain’s eastern side showcases the kind of scenery that will have you doing happy little dances of joy from one stunning panorama to the next. And judging by how fast camping permits are snatched up for this area, it’s no secret. This trail can be engaged from a variety of starting points depending on time and interest. One popular starting point is the Wonderland Trail at Box Canyon, 10 miles west of the Stevens Canyon Entrance. The first mile is a moderate trek northeast to the Nickel Creek wilderness camp, followed by a vigorous 2,000-foot climb to the crest of the Cowlitz Divide. The trail undulates along the divide, meadows widening the higher you go, and eventually gains another 500 feet to views of Double and Shriner Peaks to the east and The Mountain rising immediately to the west. The trail then drops a quick 800 feet into the valley of the Ohanapecosh River and the wide meadows of Indian Bar. In early summer, numerous waterfalls stream down the walls of the valley, fed by the glaciers above. This makes a good halfway point before starting the next climb. From Indian Bar, the trail continues north, steeply climbing over 1,500 feet in the next 1.5 miles. It then levels somewhat while traversing the meadows of Ohanapecosh Park to the high point on the Wonderland: Panhandle Gap at 6,800 feet. Here you’ll find yourself in the alpine zone, a landscape dominated by rocky talus that often holds snow through the summer months. Rangers and guidebooks issue warnings about traversing the snowfields here in bad weather, so exercise caution and good judgement. This is a common location to spot mountain goats, and the Cowlitz Chimneys can be viewed to the east. From the gap, the trail descends 1.5 miles to the Summerland wilderness camp along Fryingpan Creek. Little Tahoma rises sharply above wide meadows brimming with wildflowers, and Goat Island Mountain dominates to the north. The route then descends steadily along Fryingpan Creek 4 miles to the trailhead at Sunrise Road. Extend Your Hike: Consider camping at one or more of the four campsites in the area: Nickel Creek (four sites), Olallie Creek, Indian Bar (five sites, one group site), and Summerland (six sites). It can be tough to get permits at these campsites due to the area’s popularity and the fact that you’ll be competing with weekend hikers as well as advance-planning Wonderland Trail hikers for the handful of wilderness campsites available through this section. To improve your chances of scoring a permit and savoring this idyllic location, consider a midweek trip. Hike Description Written by Eli Boschetto, WTA Community
column106: We weren't lucky enough to get Wonderland permits in the lottery this year, but managed to secure a short notice overnight permit from a cancellation. Easy drive in through the Sunrise entrance. We got to the park around 8:30AM and were able to drive right up to the gate, then immediately pick up permits at the ranger station. Frying Pan Creek trailhead was maybe 10 minutes down the road from the ranger station. Parking was full at the creek, but we parked on the side of the road close by at the ranger's suggestion. Start to finish the trail was in great shape. Heading from the trailhead to the Panhandle Gap, the climb is pretty steady with a couple spicier sections thrown in. Up until Summerland, the trail was a lovely, smooth, packed dirt. Between Summerland and the gap, the trail transitioned into a rock field until we started descending towards Indian Bar. The descent was steep but not technical, and a little brushy at times. The trail goes over several rivers/streams, and all of them were crossable without getting your feet wet. Water was easy to come by for filtering through almost all of the trail. On day 1, the views were incredible. Fun mushrooms poking up in the forest, raging streams and waterfalls, colorful sub-alpine meadows, and looming snow peaks in the background. Tons of ripe and delicious blueberries, particularly around Indian Bar. It started raining by the time we woke up on day 2, and kept going for our entire hike out.  The initial climb out of Indian Bar left us with wet pants and shoes from the tighter brush sections. The trail handled the rain well and some of the dustier sections, like the descent into Indian Bar, firmed up and had really good traction. It made the climb out feel as good as a 1800' climb in the rain could. Some of the rock sections were a little slick, but everything was manageable. The descent back to the trailhead generally went quickly. Trail traffic was pretty light, and we mostly ran into hikers doing the full Wonderland loop. Hike stats according to my watch:  Per usual, the campsites were fantastic in the national park. All of the individual sites were spacious, flat, and had soft dirt for staking. There was a bear pole for hangs, or leaving bear cans at the base. The individual campsite toilet was full, and closed by the rangers, but the group site toilet was still available and clean with plenty of room left. We ran into a couple rangers who were out checking permits. They warned us about a bear that had been close to the sites recently and said that we might encounter some elk as it's rutting season. Lots of chipmunks, and pika along the way. Near Indian Bar we saw 12-15 mountain goats, 2 on trail, and a handsome black bear in the meadow next to the camp sites who was much more interested in blueberries than people. We think we heard him romping around in the trees between the individual campsites. I thought that I heard some elks bugling in the morning but I did not see any. We also saw several joy-sparking american dippers in the river near camp. The flowers along the way were beautiful, the berries were ripe, and the rocks were surprisingly colorful. During the rain, some of the colors really came through and the gap turned into a stunning display of reds, greens, and blues in the rock. A few of the larger rock surfaces almost had a stained glass look from all of the different deposits in them. This hike is one of the prettier ones in Washington from start to finish. There's a fantastic mix of forest, meadows, peaks, and waterfalls that's tough to find anywhere else.

column60: Came to the park from North Bend. Lots of new home construction in the area so we didn’t find the actual parking area - but found a spot in a new section that gave access to the field and trail to river. Lovely spot. Lots of cars in the actual lot so everyone else seemed to have the right directions.
column98: Hiking Tanner Landing Park A pleasant walk along the Middle Fork Snoqualmie, as well as a large field and wildflowers. Great for a short hike or picnic. This large park along the Middle Fork Snoqualmie lets you easily walk a level, mile-long loop with a stretch along the river and the rest across a picturesque field or along the Snoqualmie Valley Trail. There are views of nearby Mount Si, Little Si, and across the valley to the profile of Rattlesnake Ledge. You'll see mention of this park as a place people park to hike Si and Little Si when those popular trail heads are full. There's one toilet a short distance from the parking lot. The Snoqualmie Valley Trail brushes by this park. You can extend your walk along this trail, or launch your Snoqualmie Valley Trail trip from this park.
column106: Walked the Tanner Landing park trails Sunday morning.  Parking is free and plentiful.  There is a single sanican at the main lot in decent condition.  Watch out for the access road - lots of big potholes, take it slow unless you have a stadium truck or something.  The trails around the property are in good condition with no specific issues.  There is also easy access to the Snoqualmie Valley trail here and makes a good jumping off point.  Lots of nice views of Mt Si, the middle fork of the Snoqualmie River, east farther up the valley etc.  The one major change from the last time I was here several years ago is that the whole southern border is a bunch of new condos where it was vacant previously - ahh, progress.  A nice little walk with river access and nice views if you are in the area.

column60: It's important to understand that Wind Mountain is divided into 4 separate parcels. The trail starts on private property owned by the Girl Scout camp, they built the trail and allow the public to access the public land above. The trail then proceeds to the public land managed by the State of Washington. The trail then crosses into another section of private property owned by the local mill (who also allow public access). Near the summit the trail enters public land federally managed by the NFS. Because of all the complexity of this arrangement there is no fee or permit needed for parking or accessing this amazing trail.
column98: Hiking Wind Mountain An old trail on Wind Mountain winds through land owned by various agencies. Storm damage and lack of maintenance has made this trail increasingly difficult, and the various land agencies encourage hikers to visit other Columbia Gorge hikes as an alternative to Wind Mountain. The Wind Mountain trail goes back 75 years or more as a user-created trail, It was likely created as an adventure by the Girl Scouts who have land and cabins just north of the mountain. The trail starts on an old logging road, then crosses through Girls Scouts of America land, then DNR land and finally on a small parcel of USFS land. The summit is a sacred space for Native American tribes, and has been designated a sensitive cultural resource site. The trail is not an official USFS system trail, and with the varying land owners and the sensitive site at the summit, hikers are encouraged to seek alternate summits in the Gorge that offer equally breathtaking views. WTA worked here in 2016!
column106: Wind Mountain is a fun fairly short hike up to the summit with some nice views of the Columbia Gorge, as it is 2.5 miles RT with 1200ft gain. Aferrenberg and I car camped at the large parking area just past the end of the pavement. The trailhead is down the steep road about 70 vertical ft, and there is room for one vehicle. It’s kind of hard to turn around at the trailhead, per what a local told us, so it’s best to park in the upper lot. The trailhead is very well built and is very nice. It’s appears to have had some maintenance done on some sections where it has sloughed off. Up high as the trailhead crosses a talus field there are some nice views of Dog Mountain, and even caught a glimpse of I believe Mount Adams. The summit area had some signs posted that there were some Tribal Sacred Lands on the summit, and there were some rock features and pits dug in the talus done by the tribal ancestors. In the west side of the summit were some nice views looking down to the Columbia River Gorge. We could also see Beacon Rock which we did the previous day after hiking up Dog Mountain, along with Mount Saint Helens. Fun hike to end our long weekend exploring the Columbia River Gorge area!

column51:
Mount Rainier Summit, Camp Schurman —
              Jul. 5, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-07-12.184941759340)
column60: TL;DR : Only 1 mile snow-free then a messy situation! Skiers- you can start skinning about 2.8 miles in but it’s kind of awful for a while until you get closer to the basin. Snow bridge over the Inter Fork of the White River is there but going fast if you want to ski the Inter Glacier. Nice corn around 10/11am today! You’ll see our long glissade track from Camp Curtis. We hiked the Glacier Basin Trail to climb Mount Rainier, entering 5/27/25 and exiting 5/30/25. The trail is snow-free for the first mile then intermittently snow-covered for a short stretch then continuously snow-covered to the Glacier Basin meadows area. The snow is covered with pine needles, branches, and other organic debris… plus lumpy with some cavities over hollow spaces to watch out for and some treacherous spots where you could punch through the snow. There are 2 spots where the trail’s bridges aren’t fully accessible due to snow so you have to cross running streams on tricky snow bridges- which will only get sketchier as the snow melts. As you approach the end of the trail there’s a set of footprints that wander off route so keep that in mind! Easy to collect water from the river once you reach the Glacier Basin meadows area (totally under snow of course right now). Camp Schurman- one bathroom open and you can drop off your human waste bags in the barrel by the bathrooms. Lots of snow still there - see pictures.
column98: Hiking Camp Schurman
column106: Summited Tahoma via the Emmons route 7/6/25. Trip lasted 3 days in total, the first of which being a hike-in to Camp Schurman, followed by summit day, and then finally the hike out. Although we were warned about crevasses appearing at the top of the Interglacier, we didn't see any. The scramble section down from the Interglacier to the Emmons was a little spicy with a heavy pack; the climbing ranger told us this has been the case in recent years due to melt out. A couple members of our group expressed surprise at the difference compared to the last time they climbed this route. The climb from Camp Schurman to the Summit was not bad, other than a stiff wind in the late morning (was wearing all of my layers) followed by scorching heat on the way down (was in a single layer by this point). We left around 12:30-1 am and hit the summit around 8 am. I believe we made it back to Camp Schurman around 1 or 1:30 pm, with our pace slightly slowed due to members of our team having altitude sickness. Be aware that the Alpine Meadow section (above The Corridor) gets dicey once the snow bridges soften in the mid-day sun; someone on another rope team punched through just ahead of us. All in all, this was a fun adventure. Nothing beats the sunsets at Camp Schurman, and we appreciated the good tent sites and welcoming climbing rangers!

column8:
Mailbox Peak - Old Trail, Dirtybox Peak —
              Sep. 15, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-09-15.214055755305)
column51:
Mailbox Peak - Old Trail, Dirtybox Peak, Mailbox Peak —
              Nov. 28, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-11-28.201614457999)
column60: This trip report is mainly about Dirtybox Peak. To get there you first have to climb Mailbox, so a couple of thoughts about that: I went up the old trail. This was a nice day for the old trail as the recent rain had dampened down all the dust and loose soil. That made for an easy ascent. It also brought out some mushrooms which were fun to see. I got to meet a nice search and rescue dog at the top too. Dirtybox Peak is the first peak to the east when you're standing at the mailbox. It requires some class 2 scrambling, a bit of bushwhacking, and especially route finding skills - GPS will only get you so far with this one. It probably goes without saying, but it's wise to be super comfortable with Mailbox before tackling this. The first part is a down-scramble to the ridge. Today this was dry, so pretty simple. There's some mild exposure and a little bit of route finding, but it's fairly clear where the trail goes. (Third pic is from the bottom of this part looking back up at Mailbox.) I find the middle of the ridge is the hardest part as the trail sometimes seems to disappear into the pines. There's a trail under there though. If you part the brush you can see it. If you can't see it or the brush seems impenetrable, chances are the trail has skipped back up to the ridge. There are a couple of rocky prominences with great views along the way which could make a good enough destination. There's only one part with serious exposure, but you're a little bit back from the edge. Today there was a lot of moisture on the branches, so I got fairly wet going through this part. It felt good though after climbing Mailbox. The last part is a lightly trodden, but somewhat clear trail through the woods up to the peak. Today there was a blow down just ten feet from the peak. It's an annoying one to cross, but totally worth the effort as there's a really nice flat rock at the top to sit on. Views are mostly south, but you can see the area around Thompson Point and Granite Lakes through the trees. There's a summit register in an ammo box. Overall Dirtybox Peak is a super fun obstacle course type hike. It's also a way to get more solitude than the main Mailbox summit. Some other stats: only saw three people on the old Mailbox trail. I saw around ten people on the other parts of Mailbox and at the summit. There was no one on the Dirtybox trail. Total elevation gain for this hike was right around 4200'. Old Mailbox to Dirtybox and back down came in at 8.2 miles.
column98: Hiking Dirtybox Peak If Mailbox Peak hasn't totally drained you, head along the ridge to the east up to Dirtybox Peak. The trail takes hikers through brush and over rocks, some of which may require some scrambling. Entering deep brush, the trail fades, at times disappearing completely. But stay on the ridge spine, and soon enter a forested section. Keeping in view of I-90, make your way up the shady hillside. Arrive at the summit, marked by a large rock nestled in trees. Take a well-deserved rest, and enjoy a view of Mailbox seldom seen. Further views of Mailbox, as well as Dirty Harry's Peak, Bandera Mountain, and Webb Mountain are possible by continuing east, but keep in mind that at this point the scramble becomes more dangerous, with several sections where a fall could be fatal. Experience is highly recommended for anyone exploring further.
column106: I went up the old trail, along the ridge to Dirtybox and back, then down the new trail. I haven’t done Mailbox since 2018. After reading a lot recently about the number of emergency services calls for people needing help on this trail, I decided on a revisit. I had never done the new trail so I wanted to have a look at that. Apparently, the old trail hasn’t been maintained since the new one was made in 2014 but there is so much hiker traffic that it’s become a supercharged boot path. That makes it easy to follow on the way up, but every hiker I met coming down was off the trail. Years of trail runners coming down quickly have extended all the false trails to make a rats’ nest of eroded soil tracks. The trail doesn’t seem like a huge injury hazard: Gunn Peak and the Kamikaze Trail are harder. What seems like the most difficult part starts at the scree after the old and the new trails join together when they meet at the end of the trees. From then on, the views are fabulous. The summit of Mailbox Peak has an ever-changing population of lunching hikers and hence a lot of Gray Jays.  Dirtybox Peak looks temptingly accessible along a half-mile ridge to the east. It’s not a difficult traverse, especially with AllTrails giving me a route. There’s a scramble down from Mailbox to the saddle that has some class 3 moves. However, in late November this is made harder by the ice that lingers until after midday. Because it’s a lightly used route, the trail is through densely-packed conifers. Squeezing through these gives you a constant wetting with ice-cold water. Still, it’s easy. There’s no real view from the summit of Dirtybox because of the trees, and absolutely no people or Gray Jays. I wanted to keep going along the ridge to Dirty Harry’s Peak, but it really didn’t look inviting, so I headed back to Mailbox. I decided to check out the new trail on the way down. It’s well-made and has no steep parts. It’s great for mycophiles because of the huge diversity of fungi along the whole trail. It has some sections that rival Hoh Rainforest for mossy grandeur. There are two beautifully constructed bridges. The problem is that few people seem to use it. It’s so much longer than the steep, muddy maze of the old trail. It took me a lot more time to go down than it did to get up, and with 4000 feet of elevation gain and loss, that shouldn’t be the case. There were people starting on the new trail after 2:30pm with absolutely no hope of making it to the summit and back before darkness. There is a warning sign at the start of the old trail about the duration of the hike, but not on the new trail. Maybe that needs to change.

column60: Slightly muddy trails but otherwise nice and wide, easy to navigate. Lots of people with dogs but not crowded. It’s easy to mix trails and get a good long loop with views of the blues
column98: Hiking Bennington Lake A local spot to cool down when the temperatures soar in Walla Walla, Bennington Lake is a favored spot for hikers, birders, anglers, runners, and lots of local wildlife. In spring, water is diverted from Mill Creek to the lake after the snowmelt has slowed and the lake is less likely to flood. The Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife stocks rainbow trout in the lake, and anglers flock for several relaxing hours of fishing. The Sun and Sage National Birding Trail is also here, and a huge variety of birds live here year round, or come through on their yearly migration. There are more than 20 miles of trails at Bennington Lake, whether you want a long perimeter walk, or just a quick out and back for views of the lake. The Whitetail Trail is the longest, clocking in at 4.8 mile, with moderate elevation gain. Wind along an old road bed on the west side of the lake, then descend just a few feet to meet the Meadowlark Trail as it follows the diversion canal closely. Along the way, you'll get an up-close look at both native and non-native plants and animals, but won't see quite as much water. The Meadowlark Trail (2.6 miles) stays closer to the lake and the feeder stream, crossing the diversion canal at the south end using small rock steps. You can simply slosh through the water -- a refreshing respite on a particularly hot day. From here, link up with the Whitetail Trail, which continues up to the north end of the canal and crosses there, adding about a quarter mile to your total distance. From the north end, the Whitetail Trail heads to the south end of the diversion canal, then begins zigzagging along the property line, while the Meadowlark Trail sticks closer to the stream that feeds Bennington Lake. Alternately, the Kingfisher Trail is just 1.7 miles, and follows a moderate grade along the north and south sides of Mill Creek itself. Hike Description Written by Anna Roth , WTA Correspondent
column106: Beautiful meandering stroll around lake, primroses, lots of birds, especially bank swallows and great blue Herron, folks fishing at lake, views of hills and horse back riders.

column8:
Steptoe Butte State Park Heritage Site  —
              Jun. 19, 2024 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2024-06-23.131402113826)
column51:
Steptoe Butte State Park Heritage Site —
              Oct. 14, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-10-14.202134463314)
column55: Steptoe Butte State Park Heritage Site
column60: Decided to drive to the top of the Butte.  Road not for the faint of heart as you drove up and up.  Many potholes, almost not drivable at places.  Very disappointed in our state's lack of road maintenance in some of our state parks.  Views spectacular, but I would not drive it again until road repaired
column98: Hiking Steptoe Butte State Park Heritage Site Fans of geology, history and, of course, nature can enjoy this 168-acre day-use park. The quartzite butte, which once marked the original border of the North American Continent, contains some of the most ancient rock in the Pacific Northwest. Steptoe has historically been used as a wagon road and once housed a hotel site and even an observatory. The top of the butte has magnificent views from above the Palouse Hills, and you can learn more about the area’s unique geology from interpretive panels at the summit. Hike Description Written by Claudia Lopez , WTA Community
column106: Road repaved. Super smooth, like a skateboard park. Still closed, work 98% done, scheduled to reopen, 10/22/25. Got within 100’ of top.Gorgeous!

column8:
Jade Lake, Marmot Lake, Pea Soup Lake, Dip Top Gap —
              Jul. 13, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-07-14.141407923388)
column51:
Pea Soup Lake, Dip Top Gap, Jade Lake, Marmot Lake —
              Aug. 2, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-08-03.134938234430)
column60: 25.3 miles and 5,630 vertical feet on GPS watch.  Other than swimming in 2 lakes, my friend and I were hiking virtually entire time. We left trailhead at 6:05am.  Arrived to Marmot Lake ~945am and Jade Lake ~11am.  Marmot Lake was prettier than I thought it would be.  Trail from Marmot to Jade wasn't too bad.  Air temp. was warm, probably in the 80s by 11am, so I'm glad we started early.  We jumped in icy Jade Lake, probably 40 degrees (refreshing, but we didn't last long) and Marmot Lake on way out (probably in low 50s) where we stayed in the water for 20 minutes to cool off.  Marmot felt like a bath tub compared to Jade. From Jade Lake, Recommendation #1, after the campgrounds, follow trail above the shoreline and turn right just before the last tree grove and scramble fairly easily down a "hiker's trail" near the head of the lake.  Don't do what we did which was to go left of the upper tree grove, and traverse the scree slope above the snowfield.  It was nasty traversing the scree slope, and I bloodied myself a few times.  There isn't much exposure, but the rocks move underneath you each step.  On the way back, we smartly followed the lakeshore and hiked up the scramble trail. Recommendation #2, bring microspikes (this time of year) for the snowfield up Dip Top Gap.  Microspikes worked well.  Crampons or poles would have been nice, but I didn't want to carry the weight.  Ice axe would be overkill. "Summitted" Dip Top Gap for splendid view of Mt. Daniel and Pea Soup Lake.  We saw Glacier Peak and Mt. Baker too.  Recommendation #3, bring light goretex pants for the glissade down.  We had an awesome glissade from Dip Top to nearly Jade Lake.  Recommendation #4, bring bug juice.  I'm scratching at nearly 100 bug bites today.  Worst was in the morning after Deception Pass (near several ponds breeding grounds), Marmot Lake and Jade Lake.  Half the people were wearing mosquito nets.  We returned to the trailhead at 8pm. Jade Lake and Dip Top Gap are totally worth it.  Next time, I might bring a tent and stay at Marmot Lake.  Doing this in 1 day was a lot for me, and my body is paying for it today.
column98: Hiking Pea Soup Lake
column106: We did a day hike up to Dip Top Gap and then climbed up to Dip Top Peak. The trail is in great shape until Marmot Lake. Once you reach Marmot Lake the trail becomes narrow with many down trees. It's really hard to follow the right trail to Jade Lake but just be prepared for scree and a climbing over a few boulders. Going around Jade Lake is fairly straight forward until you reach a junction with one trail going up and another dropping steeply to the shoreline. Take the trail that descends to the rocky shoreline and then do you best to follow cairns to the bottom of the snowfield. The snowfield was in good condition but within a week or two it will become icy, and crampons will be very helpful. At Dip Top Gap head right up some rock slabs and eventually you will find a faint trail which goes part way up Dip Top Peak. It's mostly class 2/3 but at the very top there is a narrow 25ft section with huge drop-offs on both sides. Took us 13 hours or so roundtrip. The mosquitos were annoying but not bad with the exception of Jade Lake.

column60: Mosquito creek was flowing enough for me to park by portable toilets rather than trailhead parking lot. A few blowdowns but I understand as of today a crew did log out since my hike. The trail was in great shape otherwise below the snow. After passing through the switchbacks in open meadow, the trail was snow covered in the upper forested section a little before 3.0 miles. After that the only exposed trail was in the skree. I followed fresh goat tracks and checked the map a couple times to keep close to the trail. It was a hot day so the snow was soft and post holing was a concern, with even the goats popping through. Fortunately I could see their post holes and knew to tread lightly. Near the top there multiple small cornices along the cliff edge so I was sure to keep far away from the ridge line. No snow on the summit outcropping and a beautiful view. The goats were hanging around but none were aggressive. Coming down, poles were necessary in the snow but following my tracks, the softness made for an easy plunge step. On a colder day, I would have worn spikes on the way up and glissaded down.
column98: Hiking Scotchman Peak The views from the top of 7,009 foot Scotchman Peak are gorgeous enough to allow visitors to forget that they gained 3,730 feet in elevation over the course of 3.5 miles to get there. With more than 1,000 feet gained per mile, it is one tough training hike, but it is well-worth the effort it takes to get to the top. Long-proposed for protection as part of the Scotchman Peak Wilderness, this is a very wild area that's still easily accessible. The trail is undergoing improvements to its too-steep grade, so the round trip mileage will eventually be a bit longer. There's nothing to be done about the elevation gain, which is actually more in the winter when the TH is inaccessible and intrepid snowshoers and backcountry skiers must start a little lower down and closer to town. Check avy conditions before a winter visit. The beginning of the hike is in a recovering forest with few views, so watch for the local flora and fauna instead. Spring wildflowers eventually give way to summer huckleberries along the route. Approximately two-thirds of the way up, the trail leaves the trees and enters a rocky section. The views are impressive, with Lake Pend Oreille shimmering far below and other peaks all around. At the summit, site of an old fire lookout, keep an eye out for Mr. Scotchman (actually any number of local mountain goats). Please don't feed or approach the goats! The trail was closed for a time in the summer of 2015 due to habituated goats. Keep dogs on leash and keep all food stowed safely in your pack. Keep your pack on or nearby as well, as the goats will attempt to lick salt off the straps of unattended packs. Hike Description Written by Holly Weiler, WTA Correspondent
column106: Fairly smoky conditions which limited views, but I would love to come back and hike it again when the air quality is better. I didn't see any mountain goats this time, but there had been a lot of foot traffic so it makes sense that the goats would move on. Love climbing and exploring the rock formations at the peak.

column60: We did this hike a year ago following WTA's directions. Today we found a handwritten sign posted at the gate which said this is NOT the access to Tumwater Botanical Area "contrary to what is on WTA"; in fact, the access is just past MP96. Hmm. Since we knew from experience that the road does go past lots of Lewisia, we continued on. Instead of a partly overgrown, green and leafy road, we found the road has been bulldozed so that it could be driven if the gate were open. Definitely cut down on the charm of the hike. The peak for Lewisia has passed but we did find many up at the ridge top at 3200 ft, along with Lewisia Rediviva, maricopa lilies, lupine, etc. And bear scat, some fairly fresh, so we made lots of noise. Using the old logging roads, you can explore and make loops. After 7 miles RT/1600ft gain we were ready for dinner at Yodelin in Leavenworth. On the way home, we did note a pull out just east of MP96 where there was a porta potty and some sort of trailhead post. We didn't stop to read it.
column98: Hiking Tumwater Botanical Area The Tumwater Botanical Area is a special area designated by the Alpine Lakes Area Management Plan because a couple of species of rare plants grow in the area. There are no official trails in this area. Visitors are strongly encouraged to tread lightly here, since at least one species of these rare plants have not been documented anywhere else.
column106: With the spring wildflower season rapidly drawing to a close at low elevation, I was hoping to find a few more new species on my "must-see" list of wildflowers, this time on Tumwater Mountain.  In addition to the beautiful, but more widespread lupines, balsamroot, phlox and buckwheats, Tumwater has some rare ones. The UW Herbarium has in its collection a number of specimens of at least five different rare species from this mountain.  One of them is showy stickseed (Hackelia venusta), which somewhat resembles a very large white forget-me-not.  The story goes that one day, a group of graduate students went collecting plants for the introductory botany lab at the University of Washington and unknowingly wiped out the roadside population of this plant along SR 2 at the base of Tumwater Mountain.  While I cannot swear that there are no plants left along the highway, every time I have stopped to examine the white flowers along the roadside, they are always buckwheat, phlox, yarrow or spiraea.  Several years ago, I parked alongside the highway, climbed straight up to the top, came down the other side, walked through Leavenworth and back along the highway in search of this and several other rare species (including wild peonies and several orchids). I had a great day, but found none of the species I was looking for.  Part of the way up I found a trail, with switchbacks, but because I did a loop trip, I never found out where it began.  In spite of stopping at every pull-out along that highway at the base of Tumwater Mt. (there are at least 18), I have not found it since.  It did not go all the way to the top, but it went up a good bit of the climb.  This is by way of background.
