According to the WTA website, the Tumwater Botanical Area "trail" starts at FR 7903.  However at this time there is a hand-written sign at the gate that says the Tumwater Botanical Area is not here, but at mile post 96.  I believed this sign, because according to my Green Trails map, the actual botanical reserve boundaries do not intersect with FR 7903 or those roads that branch off from it.  Nevertheless, I thought it was still worth exploring.  While I was sitting at the gate keying out a small, inconspicuous flower I found there, a truck pulled up, opened the gate and drove on.  The gate is not locked and the driver apparently already knew that.  This road has been recently bulldozed, which has me a little worried.  Access to the wild lands in most of the canyons in the area is blocked by private property-no trespassing signs.  Why else would a closed road be improved unless they were planning some development or logging in the area?  The area is not protected.  FR 7903 has pretty good floral diversity.  There's an especially nice display of orange honeysuckle in bloom.  But I did not find exactly what I was looking for and turned around at about three miles.  On the way down, I found a friendly Western Yellowbelly Racer.  Next stop, mile post 96. The trail at mile post 96 is exactly at the turn-out at MP 96, not the one a little farther on with the Port-a-Potty that goes to Castle Rock.  The start is a little hard to find, to the left side of the pull-out.  I was hoping this was the beginning of the trail I had found a few years earlier.  Unfortunately, like the one at Castle Rock, this is a climber's trail that dead-ends at a cliff.  I tried to continue on up from there off-trail, but after going up a little ways, it was clear this was not feasible.  I decided to go back down to skirt the rock formation that was blocking the way. I met two young women who were also looking for the Tumwater Botanical Area trail and found the sign directing them to MP 96. I found a way up to the right of the climbing rock and continued beyond up another 1500' vertical elevation before turning around because I was running out of time.  This is a truly spectacular climb not only because there is a continuous view of the canyon itself, but also because of the many interesting rock formations along the way.  The roar of the Wenatchee River drowns out the busy highway below and one always feels as if one is in a wild place.  It is sad there is no trail all the way up out of Tumwater Canyon, because this is the most scenic route up to the highlands in the Leavenworth area, already way over-crowded.  The route I took is only for those comfortable with off-trail travel, but it actually feels safer than some trails.  I refer to those really steep trails with a hardpan topped by a thin layer of sand or gravel.  The ones where, on the downhill, your feet are constantly threatening to slip out from underneath and send you flying down on your butt.  The soil on the mountain is soft and loose, permitting you to dig in your heels and plunge step down the steep slope.  The slope is open with few downed trees.  There is one caveat.  The area within three hundred vertical feet of the road is well-guarded by cliffs, so it is important to come down the same way you go up in order to avoid getting cliffed-out.  I found a new species of broomrape on the slope, which parasitizes buckwheats, but not my target species.  There are lots of buckwheat and some lupines in bloom up there, but many species are finishing up for the season.  If you get up high enough, there is Tweedy's lewisia. I thought I'd try one more place on Tumwater Mountain before giving up for this year.  This time I tried FR 7701 on the back side of Tumwater Mountain.  Being a Sunday, there was a fair amount of road traffic up the mountain, mainly of people with bicycles, but, mercifully, no motorbikes.  This is definitely an easier way up the mountain, but shaded with few views until you get near the top.  The road branches several times, take two lefts to get to the summit.  Many flowers are at the end of their flowering season, but there is some Tweedy's lewisia and lots of lupine still in bloom.  I found many spotted coralroot orchids along the road and one striped coralroot. I also found one of my target species, two phantom orchids, on a spur off the main route.  Unfortunately, they were still immature and not blooming yet.  There is a rough trail along the ridge of Tumwater which I did not have time to explore.  The view at the top is fantastic. I still want to find those other plants, so I guess next year I've got another off-trail route to do on another part of the mountain.

column60: The report for this hike is very accurate, took us about 2.5 hours to complete including stops along the way. There is a bathroom at the lighthouse as too, and it is well maintained. Saw a few of the locals out on the road too today!
column98: Hiking Turn Point Lighthouse It doesn’t get better than Stuart Island if you want to combine a quaint little hiking trip with sea kayaking, camping and wildlife watching. Enjoy the dramatic setting of this historic lighthouse and gaze out across Boundary Pass towards the Canadian Gulf Islands. Watch for river otters, harbor seals, and if you time it right, orca whales cruising in the waters just offshore. The trail starts at Stuart Island State Park, above the dock ramp on Reid Harbor. Head left (north) on the Prevost Loop and wind your way down towards the head of Reid Harbor. The trail intersects the “road” here (no need to be wary of traffic!) and continues northwest towards the Stuart Island School. The original building is now a museum. Just past the schoolhouse, on the left, is the tiny Stuart Island cemetery, also worth a side visit. Continuing north along the road, you’ll arrive at a T-junction (turning right will bring you to the Prevost Harbor dock). Turn left, and after a little over a mile you’ll arrive at the Turn Point Lighthouse on land now designated as part of the San Juan Islands National Monument. Return back the way you came, or to make a loop, follow the road to Prevost Harbor and return to Reid Harbor by way of a short connecting trail. Hike Description Written by Kathleen Foley, WTA Correspondent
column106: We’ve been exceedingly lucky this week to sail with friends in the San Juans. Trails like this that have no road or ferry access suddenly become available. The highlight of this trail really was the 1893 lighthouse and its adjacent buildings. Many of these buildings had fallen into disrepair due to vandalism but thanks to friends-of-the-lighthouse type group they’ve been refurbished. Volunteer docents were on hand to do tours and answer questions. The trail, more realistically a gravel road has many points of interest to keep us entertained. Water views, Madrona trees, and unusual geology were among our distractions.

column60: We went out to lester as a part of a canoe trip in the stampede pass area. Driving the gravel roads is what you would expect, dusty and full of potholes but overall passable for most vehicles. The ghost town trek itself starts at a blocked bridge into the watershed, and is a straightforward path on a gravel road, with one washed out section the has a clear detour. The hike itself is quite and isolated, very nice of you're already up in the pass. None of the old buildings of the ghost town remain as they were taken down by staff out here due to people's negligence and danger about 5 years ago. Do not do this hike if ghost towns are what you want.
column98: Hiking Lester Ghost Town History: Lester was once a thriving town that provided services and coal to Northern Pacific steam locomotives before they made their journey over Stampede Pass. The town became a victim of both technological progress and the needs of a much larger municipality. By 1908 the town was home to around 250 residents. In addition to the residents’ homes the town had a hotel, roundhouse, post office, general store, and a school. One resident fought hard for Lester to be recognized by Washington's historic register. Gertrude Murphy was one of the 26 people left living in the town by 1980. She had been a schoolteacher in Lester, but as the town dwindled, she became a champion for the town as well as a board member for the school. The school was closed in 1985, when the state legislature determined that the town was too small to operate a school, and Murphy worked full time to save Lester. In 1993, her home burned down, and she moved a mile and a half out of town into a cabin that she referred to as "the suburb of Lester." Murphy died in 2002, the last resident of Lester. By the 1940’s the rail line serviced by Lester was switching from steam to diesel locomotives. The new engines had no need to stop in Lester for fuel or supplies, which meant the town had lost a major source of income. The town began to decline. In the 1960’s the City of Tacoma sought to shut down Lester to protect the drinking water quality of the Green River Watershed, and by 1969 the city had purchased the land on which the town sat. The final nail in Lester’s coffin came in 1984 when the BNSF Railroad stopped using the rail line that ran through the town altogether. The line was reopened again in 1996, but by then the town was no more. Hike Description Written by Exploring History in Your Hiking Boots , WTA Community
column106: All the town buildings are gone. Found some foundations, old appliances, sinks, bathtubs, lots of likely fuel oil barrels, etc. Game warden told us a few years ago the last buildings were demolished due to bad condition and a safety hazard. Area itself was pleasant. The road has deep potholes and not recommended for a sedan.

column60: Today I went to Oregon to visit one of the best State Park - Silver Falls State Park. I did the Trail of ten falls Loop. 8.4 miles, barely 1000 feet of elevation gain. Today the park was crowded, Although I reached there at 12:30 pm. After I did the Abiqua Falls hike. South Falls area has the most crowds, once you are out of South Falls, the trail gets better. Less people and beautiful trees and more waterfalls. There are 3 falls, where you can walk behind it. pretty cool. The entire park is so well maintained. The gift shop and cafe is really good too. The Cafe has lots of warm food and beverage options.
column98: Hiking Silver Falls State Park Located in Central Oregon, this delightful park plays hosts to The Trail of Ten Falls, an extremely popular trail that makes for a great day's diversion for those hoping to venture deeper into Oregon. The Trail of Ten Falls is a designated National Recreation Trail. As such, it's a beautifully sculpted route that weaves above, below, behind and around ten fantastic waterfalls over the course of an 8-mile loop hike with less than 1000 feet of cumulative elevation gain though with the rolling up-and-down terrain the elevation gain will be more. Five of the waterfalls are more than 100 feet tall and one can walk behind four of the falls. There are several connecting trails which allow you to make shorter loops, but the full loop is doable for most hikers, and it makes a delightful day hike. WTA Pro Tip: An Oregon State Parks Pass is required to visit Silver Falls State Park. You can pay for a day pass at the kiosk near the entrance to the park. Hike Description Written by Multiple authors contributed to this report, WTA Community
column106: beautiful 😍

column51:
Tonga Ridge Snowshoe, East Fork Foss River Snowshoe, West Fork Foss River and Lakes —
              Jan. 9, 2026 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2026-01-09.165834363886)
column60: Parked 3.5 miles from trailhead due to continuous soft snow on the forest road. I was parked about 3400 feet elevation and hiked about 1k feet to the Tonga Ridge trailhead. I carried snow shoes and it came in handy at the forest road fork towards the right up to the trailhead parking lot.
column98: Hiking Tonga Ridge Snowshoe The route up Tonga Ridge is not clearly marked for winter travel. Visitors to this area should have a route planned, a map, snow travel and avalanche travel skills. Toilet Information No toilet at trailhead More information about toilets
column106: With a considerable avalanche forecast, I decided to drive up Foss River Road and see how far I could get without getting stuck (been there, done that). Snow started in earnest after passing the trestle but I was able to make it to the junction with FR 6830 (Tonga Ridge) before turning around and parking about .2 miles before.  Ruts were mostly gravel with the berms around 6-7 inches.  4-wheel drive helped deal with the snow but I knew it would be a sloppy mess on my out so I erred on the side of caution. Plus, I never did like the sound of scraping the undercarriage. Since I have a Tonga Ridge Snowshoe on my bucket list, I hiked back up the road and turned up on FR 6830.  From here I probably could have made it a little further in the car but by the first switchback the ruts in the snow would have been more than my Element could have managed. The first mile the ruts were exposed gravel but by that first switchback the ruts were mostly snow and continued to get deeper the further I went.  There were so many waterfalls! It wasn't long until there were some branches/trees across the road with the first significant one being about 2 miles up.  The tracks continued so I am guessing only those with serious off-road clearance are making it past this point unless like me they are on foot.  There was a good size tree down at 3.3 miles that I can't imagine anyone in a vehicle going over but who knows because the tracks continued.  Maybe the tree came down after? I made it about 4.4 miles up Tonga Ridge Road before opting for lunch and soaking up the views at a spot where the trees were sparse enough to see the surrounding peaks. Malachite, Bald Eagle and Sobieski were the most prominent along my trek.  The tracks continued past here, maybe they go at least to the junction with Mount Sawyer Road? I had my snowshoes but didn't need them because of the compact snow of tire marks.  I did put them on for a while on the way down since I had them but eventually the ruts were too annoying so I took them back off.  If I wanted to do a lot more "breaking trail" there was plenty of snow on the sides of the road if so inclined. All-in-all I did about 9 miles car-to-car and could not have asked for a better day.  I only saw one other group, 4 people in a jeep who turned around and parked where the first set of trees were down.  And of course, I passed some monster trucks headed up as I was driving down. Looking towards the trailheads to East/West Fork, the road conditions looked to be about the same.  Higher clearance and 4-wheel drive a must. Link below with more pics.

column60: Fun climb of Mineral Butte with Kidz Won't Hike and Ngie. We thought we'd get better weather but it was cloudy all day and therefore not great views. Precipitation held off and no wind, so it was comfortable. Most people seem to climb this one when there is more snow, but today there was only 1" above 4k' and 4" at the summit around 5.3k'. So we hit a lot of vegetation and bushwhacking. Saw plenty of animal tracks in the snow, including fresh bear tracks, which looked to have been made between the time we ascended and descended! Parked just before the gate a short ways up Salmon Creek Rd which is off the Index-Galena Rd. No facilities. Started the hike behind the gate on the road around 7:15 am. We wanted to leave plenty of daylight for the descent. This old road goes up pretty high and progressively gets worse and more overgrown the higher you go. There are some very long switchbacks lower down which will compel you to go cross country to cut them. The first 1.5 miles we stuck to the road and made one switchback. Per previous GPX tracks, at this point we left the road and started uphill. Some sections are open forest that aren't too bad, besides lots of blowdowns. Other sections have a lot of alder and trees, in addition to many blowdowns, and require some steep and annoying bushwhacking. We went through many shorter and longer sections, maybe 8 of them, and also occasionally made use of the old road. Eventually the road runs out and we started the long hike up on various ridges, which mostly was open terrain and not too much bushwhacking. There seemed to be faint trails in places, possibly game trails, that were able to use. The final section is mostly boulder field. With more snow, it would be a pretty straight forward snowfield ascent. However, we only had 2-4" of snow, so have to travel carefully over the boulders. Luckily it wasn't enough to hide many posthole opportunities, but it was enough to take a good grip of the microspikes. The clouds moved in as we summitted, so we didn't have any views of surrounding larger peaks, just some of the closer ones. Still, it was a satisfying ascent. After a break, we headed back down, not looking forward to the bushwhacking. Things mostly went quickly though, with a few breaks for snacks, and we made it down just after 3:30, an hour to spare for sunset. Who misses the summer? Stats: 9.7 miles, 4,250' gain, 8:17 total time, 1:40 stopped time Gear: Poles, waterproof boots (TX4s), microspikes, gaiters, gore-tex layers and gloves, glasses for all the times I got whacked in the face by vegetation. Watersources: None. Didn't need. GPX: https://www.peakbagger.com/climber/ascent.aspx?aid=3047026
column98: Hiking Mineral Butte
column106: They're rocks, Hank. Earlier in the week I was deliberating on a snowshoe destination when a trip report popped up on NWHikers describing an ascent of Mineral Butte. The pictures looked amazing, and the hike's been on my radar for some time, so, decision made. Arrived around 9 with one other car in the parking area. Started around 0915 and followed the road pretty much the entire way, save for one shortcut which honestly I don't think was worth the trouble. Put on microspikes around 3200' and kept going. Near the end of the road before turning into the forest, I caught up with the owners of the other car, a couple of fun-loving dudes named Hans and Tristan. Turns out they were also inspired by the same NWHikers report! Good times. We headed out together and put on snowshoes at the clearing around 4000'. I had to take some extra time for a food-bio break while they pushed on ahead and upward. The final approach was fairly difficult; the afternoon sun had started softening the wide exposed snowfield slope, which turned my snowshoes into more of a liability than an asset. Regardless, I persevered and made it to the top, where the fellows were still enjoying themselves. Mineral Butte provides a unique vantage in all directions; you can see almost the entire span of the central Cascades, up-close views of Columbia Peak, Mt Pugh, Three Fingers and even far into the Olympics. Worth it! Hung out chatting with the guys for awhile, and then made myself a coffee and freeze dried meal while they headed out. Refilled my water bottle with some melted snow, took in a few more moments of the amazing views, and packed up. On the way back down I changed into the microspikes and did a sort of half-glissade half-sidestep down the snowfield, which had turned even sloppier, to the treeline. From there I followed various tracks back to the road/trail. Uneventful descent and was able to make it down to the last mile or so before finally turning on my headlamp. Got to the car around 5:30 and away I went. Overall I had a perfectly good time taking the road; the slide alder does get more prevalent further up but it's never more than a minor nuisance in a few spots. To me the extra mileage was worth the tradeoff of not schwacking up the forest that most people seem to do, but, as always, HYOH!

column98: Hiking Last Chance Promontory Begin from the Bessemer Road pullout and parking area (a blue Department of Natural Resources gate). Follow the road 1.1 miles to a signed junction with the CCC trail and a bridge over Big Blowout Creek on your left. Take a moment here to listen to Lower Big Blowout falls, heard through the trees just to the north. Crossing the bridge, travel west another 1.2 miles on the CCC trail and arrive at a second bridge, this time crossing over Wise Creek. Enjoy a nice view here of Russian Butte through an opening in the canopy eastward. For another 0.8 mile, climb softly with the CCC’s slight grade increase and reach an area known as the Plateau. Rest a minute and have some water on the old, well-placed log in front of a rock face. Take in sweeping valley views that are a preview of what's to come. Once ready, hike another 0.9 mile, passing over Lower Brawling Creek and arriving at a dirt path on your right. At 3.8 miles, this is the turnoff for the signed Last Chance Promontory trail. In about 150 feet of gain over 0.3 mile, follow the trail as it weaves through an area of second-growth forest. In years prior, this area had been severely damaged by storms. Enjoy nicely graded switchbacks until you reach a rockier path heading up and to the northeast. This is where the real climbing begins. Head up the steep, rocky trail across 3 long switchbacks. The unmaintained nature of this portion makes itself known with the regular appearance of blown down trees. At 685 feet of elevation gain over 1 mile, arrive at an impressive third bridge crossing over Upper Brawling Creek. Past this, follow even steeper switchbacks for 600 feet of elevation gain over 0.6 mile to a decommissioned junction with West Green Mountain trail. Veer right and hike on more even ground another tenth of a mile to Far Enough Promontory. You will see a slight opening in the trees, directly in front of a massive rock face. Acknowledge the view here and hike another tenth of a mile, slightly downhill to your destination: Last Chance Promontory. Arrive at the much larger opening and rest easy somewhere on the wide array of mossy talus. Enjoy expansive views of the Middle Fork Snoqualmie Valley, with its peaks towering above the river and road you travelled in on. Extending your hike Travel a short distance downhill on the trail to an unmarked and unmaintained scrambler route on your left. This leads to the summit of Green Mountain in 1 mile, over 1,020 feet of elevation gain. Toilet Information No toilet at trailhead More information about toilets Hike Description Written by Josh Machniak , WTA Correspondent
column106: This trip report is for a specific route to Absolute Last Promontory (also known as Last Chance Promontory) below the summit of Green Mountain. Start from the Bessemer Road trailhead (blue gate) and follow it up a mile or so to the bridge over Blowout Creek, on your left. Crossing the bridge, follow the CCC trail west as it leads to another bridge crossing over Wise Creek, and then up across the CCC Plateau- giving a hint of the expansive views to come. Continue on, pasisng Lower Brawling Creek and reaching a dirt path on your right at 3.8 miles in from the trailhead. This trail is now signed as Last Chance Promontory, which peaks my interest into the status of the project being managed here over the past 5 years or so. From here you will traverse up steep switchbacks over about 800ft in a mile or so to a newer bridge over Upper Brawling Creek. Past this, follow even steeper switchbacks for another 600ft over roughly a half mile to a decommissioned junction with West Green Mountain trail. Veer right and hike on more even ground to Far Enough Promontory. Acknowledge the view here and hike another tenth of a mile to your final destination: Absolute Last Promontory (also known as Last Chance Promontory). The views from this spot are on par with any you can find in the Middlefork valley. Russian Butte, Revolution Peak, Mount Defiance, Dirty Harry's Peak and Mailbox Peak dominate. To the south see the top of Tahoma peeking out and further down to Mount Washington and Change Peak. To the northeast, observe The Pulpit below the massive Preacher Mountain as they hug the Pratt River drainage. Beyond this, enjoy some slightly obstructed views of Garfield Mountain and it's cathedral-like beauty. Today was completely snow free start to finish, although there were some ice patches in shaded portions of all three trails- as well as FR-56 (Middlefork Valley Road). I nearly spun off the road near the "one lane" barricade, not seeing the ice. Please be mindful, it can come up on you quickly! I encountered 6 other hikers on this holiday, and 4 dogs. Most of which on the CCC. RT 11.6m/2100ft

column60: Easy to moderate. Moderate because the middle has a steep drop off that's not for everybody. Thank you to whoever maintains this trail! Hiked half a dozen times or so and the foliage is always nicely trimmed back. Takes about 45 minutes each way for us mortals. Cool mushrooms this time of year. Saw a noisy Killdeer probably defending a nest, and put on a show! Google reviews for this hike are funny. It's easy to find. (There's a Public Notice sign on the road now because they're going to add amenities to it). It's a little muddy. It's a normal Washington beach.
column98: Hiking Haley State Park This small, undeveloped state park-managed property is on the Key Peninsula. It is just 178-acres on the east side of Case Inlet. with 1,980 feet of saltwater shoreline. The northern edge of the property is bordered by a creek leading into a small lagoon. There is one small trail leading from the road to the beach. The salal-lined trail passes through forest with a high canopy, gradually opening up to the shoreline, which visitors can hike up and down before returning the way they came. It's easy to miss as you drive by, so keep your eye out for the unsigned trailhead on the northwest side of the road. Parking is tight here. With room for just one or two cars at the roadside pullout, be sure to have a backup location available if there's no room at the trailhead. Hike Description Written by Multiple authors contributed to this report, WTA Community
column106: Lovely walk through mossy woods leading into a gulch. Past the gulch leads you into a beautiful cove and beach with fantastic views of the Olympics on a clear day. Getting down into and out of the gulch is a little steep but there are ropes to help. Go during low tide to see lots of sea birds and sand dollar skeletons.

column8:
CCC Road: Upper Trailhead, Middle Fork Campground Nature Trail, Middle Fork Connector Trail —
              Feb. 5, 2026 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2026-02-06.090537074005)
column51:
Garfield Ledges, Middle Fork Connector Trail —
              Feb. 6, 2026 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2026-02-07.084818975441)
column60: Our group of senior hikers began our trip on the CCC Trail from the Middle Fork/Gateway Bridge parking lot. We hiked the trail past the campground where a young rock climber came by us who was going up the trail to a rock wall area to practice some big wall climbing. Going by the junction to the side trail that goes up to the site of the former FS Nordrum forest fire lookout tower and the trail up Quartz Ridge we continued on the CCC Trail. After leaving the old road section of the trail we were going through a nice moss-covered forest area. After going by the huge Western Red Cedar snag the trail heads downhill where it crosses several small creeks on bridges. At one of the bridges, we saw some repair work had been done because of a conifer tree that had blown over onto the bridge that is now cut out. This is also where the side trail takes off going north over the rock wall is located that climbers use. Further down the trail we came across a few fallen trees on the trail that we climbed over. We went as far as the big roaring creek with no name where we took a snack break and some photos. This creek runs all year, and you need to boulder hoop to get across it. On the way back on the trail, we met a woman and her two dogs, plus two other guys out on this nice sunny day. When we got back to the campground, we hiked the road up to the picnic shelter for lunch in the sun. After eating we took the Nature Trail out to the Taylor River, crossed over the Middle Fork Road and then hiked the Middle Fork Connector Trail back to the parking lot. Along this trail we stopped at the Taylor River viewpoint with a nice view of Garfield Mtn. Made for a nice day of hiking with a good group on a trail in the mossy forest. George
column98: Hiking Middle Fork Connector Trail Sharing a trailhead with the Middle Fork Snoqualmie River Trail and the Pratt River Trail, this short and flat connector trail wanders through the forest on the banks of the Snoqualmie River, connecting the parking lot for the Middle Fork Snoqualmie River trail to Garfield Ledges trailhead. Improved by WTA volunteers thanks to a puncheon about halfway through, this wide trail offers a short but sweet ramble. It's just the thing to tag onto the end of a long hike as a cool down, to introduce kids to hiking or to take a slow saunter for recovery from injury. Spot Stegosaurus Butte through the trees, enjoy the lush moss, sit by the Taylor River while viewing Garfield Mountain, and get a quick dose of nature on this short ramble. Hike Description Written by Multiple authors contributed to this report, WTA Community
column106: I haven't hiked much recently so picked this one for our last "spring day", as it has just enough elevation to make you feel you accomplished something!  We parked at the large middle fork parking lot and walked the connector over to the start of the ledge trail.  Always recommend this as the potholes on the far side of the Taylor river bridge at the ledge parking area are now car eating size.  Temperatures were all over the map, 50s in North Bend on the way in, mid 30s at the parking lot - 40s when we returned.  As we hiked up the ledge trail things warmed up nicely, and with the sun out the ledge is a nice place to catch a few rays.  The view was great and you can see all the way back down the valley to Rattlesnake Ledge.  The trail is dry and you don't need winter boots.  We stepped over a number of small trees on the way to and from the ledge trail, but apart from that everything is in great shape. We didn't linger at the ledge but stopped on the way down at the Taylor Rover picnic area (right  by the start of the ledge trail), to snack on coffee and Met Market cookies in the sun.  Be careful here as the river has seriously undercut the bank and some of the tables are no longer on solid ground.  After our treats we wandered back via the camp ground nature trail and CCC trail.  Find the turn for that on your right immediately after you recross the bridge. I love that section of the CCC trail, the moss lined path is sublime. Total mileage was 4.5.  Outhouses for both middle fork and ledges were decent, the ledge outhouse was newly serviced and stocked.  Was saddened to see road side garbage in some of the pull outs on the road in, but on the way out a forest service vehicle had pulled in to take care of that. CAUTION - there was a tree down blocking the eastward drive lane before you reach the locals housing.  The remainder of the road in was clear but there are two sections that are down to single lanes and have red barriers.  Hopefully we are not going to lose the road, that would be a sad day as the valley is such a gem of a place to both visit and hike.

column60: We walked on Rhodie road with the dogs, it was shady and cool on a hot day. No other walkers, just 2 bicyclists so felt like we had the path to ourselves. Only 2 rhododendrons bushes found with blooms but a little late in the season. Lots of birds chattering, well maintained.
column98: Hiking Rhododendron Park Rhododendron Park is a 32-acre, largely forested, mixed-use Island County park in central Whidbey Island. Facilities include a picnic area, children's play area, three groomed baseball fields, restroom facilities, 15 basic camp sites and about 3 miles of forested trails. The park also makes a convenient access point to the southern end of the Rhododendron Trail, a separate mixed-use trail that parallels Highway 20 north through Coupeville and beyond. One quick warning - the park is close to the Naval Air Station Whidbey secondary OLF field which when in use can be thunderously noisy so having a back up walk in mind if the jets are flying is a good idea. The trail system consists of a central paved north/south trail, "Rhodie Road", and a series of dirt trails that make a rough exterior loop which can sometimes be a bit hard to follow as signage is limited. Forest cover is typical second generation, largely evergreen trees. The main draw, as the park name suggests, is the brilliant show of blooming native rhododendrons in late spring. The Washington State flower is the Pacific Rhododendron and the park delivers with thousands of individual plants with hundreds of thousands of blooms in this relatively small area. Hike Description Written by Erik Morgenstern , WTA Correspondent
column106: Walked the Rhododendron Park trails Wednesday from the main southern lot off Patmore Rd.  Parking is free and plentiful.  There are also a few spots on the north end off the park next to the campground off Hwy 20.  Full restrooms were open and in good condition next to the sports fields plus there is one other sanican here plus another up by the campground.  The trails are in good condition with just a couple muddy/sloppy spots but nothing problematic.  Do consider taking a cell phone pic of the trail map heading out as trail signage is present along the center trail but not out along some of the smaller dirt singletrack and can be a little confusing.  The only other quick FYI is that this property is right next to the Navy OLF backup field where they will sometimes do touch and goes in their EA-18G Growler jets which while neat to watch are very, very loud and having a back up walk in mind if they are flying is a prudent idea.  The draw this time of year is the thousands of blooming wild rhododendron bushes.  It really is pretty amazing looking out into the fairly dense forest and it’s completely carpeted with blooming light pink rhodies.  They are slightly floral smelling as well unlike most of the human bred variants.  Lots of salal bushes blooming right now too with their delicate white to pale pink flowers.  Wildlife included a bunch of squirrels and chipmunks, some small forest birds, a pair of bald eagles way overhead and the highlight was pair of very vocal and loud raven calling with all sorts of noises, normal >grok, grok< and clicks and screams and weird >tick, bong< noises that sound vaguely like somebody playing pickleball or knocking wood together - really cool.  The northern end of the park also connects directly with the Rhododen Trail which is a paved, mixed use trail that runs all the way back into Coupeville proper if you’d like some extra distance.  The rhodies are probably a week or so from max bloom so now is a good time to go.

column8:
Fort Simcoe Historical State Park —
              Apr. 24, 2024 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2024-04-24.232716646207)
column51:
Fort Simcoe Historical State Park —
              Apr. 24, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-04-26.175541282465)
column60: We really enjoyed coming out to this historic site.  We were met with birdsong as soon as we exited the car.  There is quite of variety of birds- all beautiful.  That is worth the drive alone!  Fort Simcoe takes on a quiet and beautiful park like setting.  I loved touring the buildings and reading the descriptions.  I appreciate the effort taken to furnish the officer’s building with decor of the time.  I was astonished to learn many of the windows still have original glass from 1856!   I am thrilled it has not been vandalized.  It would be a wonderful place to picnic as there is wide open grass and plenty of shade offerings.  Make sure to walk to the left of the officer’s buildings and see one of the few remaining original buildings.  It is quite extraordinary to see with the background of the plains and hills behind the historic building  trying to imagine what it was like back 168 years.  My one complaint is I didn’t feel the descriptions of the Indian School were accurately portrayed.  To say Indians “were encouraged” to abandon their language, ways of life, spiritual beliefs falls incredibly short of actuality.  Our First Nations peoples were subjected to severe abuse, slavery, forced work and imprisonment, as well as a genocide of their traditions.  It seems the very least this important historical site, and those who run it, could do is acknowledge these horrendous truths.  I was very disappointed to see the minimization of this dark time for our indigenous peoples.  Please consider changing this.  It falls so incredibly short and that makes so many people sad.
column98: Hiking Fort Simcoe Historical State Park Fort Simcoe Historical State Park consists of 196 acres in the Yakima Indian Reservation. The day-use heritage site is primarily a historic preservation effort. Fort Simcoe is part of the National Register of Historic Places because it is one of the few pre-Civil war forts that remain in the west. Between 1860 and 1922, Fort Simcoe was used as a boarding school Native American children were forced to attend. The school building burned in 1955 and no longer stands on the property, but a lookout, officer and servants’ quarters, and a jail remain behind. Additionally, the park has 0.8 mile of hiking trails, as well as an Interpretive Center, museum, volleyball field and two horseshoe pits. A wide variety of birds, like the Lewis’s woodpecker, can be spotted at the Fort Simcoe Historical State Park. The Park is closed in the winter from October 1 through March 31. Hike Description Written by Claudia Lopez , WTA Community
column106: We had camped at Maryhill SP for 4 nights and were on our way to Yakima Sportsman SP to camp tonight. We took a side trip to Fort Simcoe to hopefully see the many Lewis's woodpeckers who frequent the area and we were not disappointed as there were many flying in and out of the oak trees in the picnic area near the large parking lot! Fort Simcoe is located on the Yakima Reservation and one of the few remaining Pre-Civil War forts in the West. It is closed October 1 through March 31st and open 8AM to dusk April 1 to September 30th. There are 5 remaining original buildings which have been restored and open to visit if you have a reservation. The restroom near the parking lot was closed, but there was a clean and well-stocked porta potty available. The restroom behind the original buildings and near the interpretive Center was open. We talked to a local couple who told us that last summer there had been a bear with 3 cubs in the park. I will post a link below with information from the Washington State Park website.

column60: We were looking for clean air for our sensitive grandmas, and the San Juans looked to be it. We pulled out our guidebook for this area (Day Hiking the San Juans, Craig Romano) and found one we could get a nice walk right from the ferry dock, saving ourselves the $$$ ferry. I'm going to make this a bit long, so you can benefit from what we learned.  We picked Indian Cove, a road walk to the Shaw County Park and a trail back thru the Graham Preserve, about 5.5 miles RT. This made a great outing, even tho the skies were overcast and the water grey. First, we had a small window of time to go there and back again, in the words of a famous Hobbit. The ferry left Anacortes at 730, so it was an early morning, bringing our breakfast on the ferry, concessions are closed. The ferry was late, due to the fog, so we didn't get going until after 8, and not starting our walk until 930. We wanted to catch the 1240, the next one would have stranded us there until 430. Off the ferry, walk along Blind Bay road, a quiet country road with views of the water and some fun road decorations the local residents have made. When you get to the Shaw Community Center, turn left onto Reef Net Bay Road (originally Squaw Bay Rd), and a sign for the County Park. Since the guidebook, the road has been renamed for obvious reasons. Keep on this road and you will come to Shaw County Park. The park has a few camp spots (reserve) and beach access. There is private beach here too, signed. Once we checked out the beach, we got back on the road and kept going around the corner until we found a sign on the right side with a hiker on it signed for the Preserve. We followed this thru the forest until it comes out at the Community Center on Blind Bay road just down from the corner we turned on. We were now headed back well within our strict turnaround time. We walked a little more slowly on the way back knowing were good on time. When we got back, the ferry was running over an hour late, so we checked out the store, got some coffee and a cookie, and ate our lunch at a picnic table by the ferry dock. If your ferry is ON TIME, you could do a bit more by going to the Ceder Rock Preserve, another mile down the road on the Hoffman Cove Road. You could also take the trail thru the preserve both ways and skip the road walk. Backpacking down to the park and staying overnight would be another choice, I bet the sunsets are fantastic! The most important thing to remember when doing these island walks is, check the ferry schedule, be flexible, and have a firm turnaround time to make it back. Of importance, there are restrooms at the ferry dock and restrooms at the park. The store has very limited supplies, take what you need, but splurge on a treat.
column98: Hiking Shaw Island WTA worked here in 2013!
column106: Places like Shaw Island are a bit of a time capsule just waiting to be explored. Our time today was limited but I’ll surely come back with a bike and get a fuller experience. We road walked from the dock area to Reef Net Bay and back. If you study your map closely a very sweet road, Rue Gilson that can be used to make a loop. These roads have little traffic, good views, and cute displays of local art. The dockside pub, if open is a gem and the store has great treats. A visit here would be great any time of year. As a bonus we visited nearby Blind Island. There is boat in only campground here (though we moored in the harbor). A user made trail runs around the island visiting intertidal zones, dry grassy hillsides, and steep drop-offs. The views of Shaw and Orcas are amazing. The entire trail is less than a quarter mile.

column60: These seldom visited falls are incredible. While I imagine they were not nearly at full strength when I had the opportunity to visit them, it still was a great experience to have, and a unique area to explore around and under via the trail. This visit was a part of a longer day hike further up the Goat Creek, but I spent much of that time early on viewing these falls. One part that I found interesting was the inverse fern growth out of the ceilings of the cavern beneath. I enjoyed a light spraying at multiple points on the trail approaching and while under in the cavernous area. This section did have a few points with loose and wet rock, and there are some steep drop offs, so be mindful of your steps while visiting. RT 1.8m/200ft
column98: Hiking Cathedral Falls This is a perfect hike if you want to get a feel for Washington's forests, though it's not necessarily indicative of what the rest of the Mount St. Helens National Volcanic Monument is like. The north side of St. Helens was the least affected by the 1980 blast, and the forest that the Goat Creek Trail winds through is home to huge, old trees that survived the eruption that obliterated the forests on the other side of the mountain. The trail leaves a small parking area large enough for five cars and traverses the hillside through quiet forest of red cedar and hemlock. Mossy rocks, and plenty of trailside distractions like chipmunks and slugs will keep kids entertained. Continue gently climbing to Cathedral Falls, the highlight of the hike. The trail provides an intimate, 360-degree view of the falls, leading hikers towards the base of an enormous waterfall, and then winding behind it. Hike under a cave and enjoy the spray from the falls, but be careful — the trail drops steeply away off to your left here and a wrong step can mean a far fall. Toilet Information No toilet at trailhead More information about toilets Hike Description Written by Anna Roth , WTA Correspondent
column106: Great day hike! Beautiful views. Lots to explore. Very easy hike, the trail was in excellent condition. Very easy to find. We made it up the road in our car, I highly recommend a truck or SUV. Dusting of snow in a few spots.

column60: This is a gorgeous hike with a wonderful trail. Parked for free at the ski area and used the restrooms. Walked 2 miles on the road to the trail head and there was little traffic on the walk. Trailhead is well marked and there are no services available at it. While this is also a mountain bike trail we didn’t see any nor any other hikers. Trail is in gorgeous shape and definitely a work out. Lunch by the gondola and then hopped the gondola down.
column98: Hiking Northway Trail This hike takes you gradually up to a ridge looking west to Mt Rainier’s Tahoma and the White River and on to the Crystal Mountain Summit. The hike begins 2 miles down Crystal Mountain Boulevard and down a short spur road. After crossing the bridge over Silver Creek, turn right on the first road you come to and park at the dead end – you will see the trail. This trail doesn’t see too much traffic until the summit, but beware of occasional mountain bikers and horseback riders. As you gain elevation the shaded young forest transitions from hemlock to fir. You will skirt impressive cliffs before the trail opens to meadows where you can see across Crystal Mountain Boulevard to Norse Peak and Castle Mountain. This section is great in the fall when the scrub oak turns to bright red! Once to the ridge you will turn left, north, and follow the ridgeline. Look down to see ski runs off to your left and more wonderful vistas to your right. The final slog takes you past Northway chair and Green Valley via a gravel road up to the summit house and gondola. Here is where you wonder how a flat “cat track” can be such a challenging hike. If you’re doing an out-and-back, this is the turnaround point. You can also ride the gondola down for a fee (even with your dog) or continue on to the Crystal Mountain trail, making a big loop. Hike Description Written by Janice Sears , WTA Community
column106: The brief road off of Crystal Mountain Highway is in decent shape for any car.  If you find yourself amid a horse camp, you're just a bit shy.  Head back out to the CMH, continue forward to the end of the guardrail and right there will be the gravel entrance on your right.  At the Northway trailhead there is ample parking; in the several instances I've used this trail it's usually one other vehicle, or just mine.  Bring plenty of water as there are no sources save for one at the very beginning.  Otherwise, it's 6 miles to the Summit House on a steady incline.  The trail is as gentle as you can get in this area; fewer roots and rocks than most others.  The hemlock, then later fir, canopy is soothing and cool.  At a point after mile 3.8 the trail begins to dance with the exposed ridge until finally leaving the canopy nearly altogether.  The ridge is glorious.  You'll see the White River valley and unsurpassed, unobstructed broad views of old Tahoma, Little Tahoma, the Tattosh, and Cascades beyond on your right.  To your left are vast views to the northeast and directly below you the first backcountry runs and bowls of Crystal Mountain ski resort.  The flanks of noble fir below you are so pristine and perfectly distributed as to suggest some cosmic landscaper is behind it all.  That's nature!  Golden meadows appear after mile 5; these make good spots to set up camp as we did.  On this trip we did not meet a single other user, not equestrian nor mountain biker, until reaching the Summit House the next morning where, of course, fresh tourists to visit with can be found.  The wind was gentle to moderate Thursday night.  Sometimes, being on a ridge, it has been substantial at night; good staking is important.  Also, heed the cautions regarding lightning: one long horn, lightning in the area, move to gondola and download immediately; three short horns, take immediate cover away from peaks or trees.  I've ascended this trail a dozen times and never had the experience; nevertheless, stay informed, practice trail etiquette and enjoy. BERRY REPORT:  In the fir canopy the deciduous dark purple/black huckleberries of good size are so plentiful, they brush against you for about 1.5 miles along the trail.  No need to leave the trail; they're right there, cool and ranging from somewhat tart to sweet.  After the first real clearing at the ridge you'll find a meadow of 8" tall sturdy shrubs with the teeny, tiny fuchsia/purple huckleberries, each one a shocking drop of pure sugar!  But, the real star of the show is back on an ancient avalanche chute that you switchback over about three times that has been taken over by thimbleberries by the millions.  My hiking buddy, an original Southern boy, was discovering this joy for the first time.  It was fun to watch him unable to get enough into his mouth.  The bliss of people discovering nature that they never previously comprehended!

column51:
Peewee Falls Overlook and Boundary Dam Overlook —
              Jun. 18, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-06-24.172510815329)
column55: Peewee Falls Overlook and Boundary Dam Overlook
column60: This was my first opportunity to check out one of the newest recreation sites on the Colville National Forest following a nearby backpacking trip into the Salmo Priest Wilderness. By this time next year there should be a brand new  9 mile hiking trail connecting here, too, but for the time being this very short version is worth checking out for the view! It will only get better as fall arrives and the nearby larches turn golden. Once the snow falls this one will close for the season, however, so watch for updates on the USFS website . I'm also not sure how early it will be open in the spring once the snow melts, but I'm sure a spring visit will be well worthwhile to see Peewee Falls at peak flow. This new site has ample parking, two CXT toilets, and three picnic tables. The hike to the overlook is 0.25 miles round trip on hardpacked gravel. The view of Peewee Falls across Boundary Lake is gorgeous, and Hooknose Mountain serves as the distant backdrop.
column98: Hiking Peewee Falls Overlook and Boundary Dam Overlook Unlike most of our state’s rivers, the Pend Oreille flows almost straight north between Newport, Washington, and the Canadian border. Several hydroelectric dams cross the steep canyon in northeastern Washington, including Boundary Dam near the border. In 2023, the U.S. Forest Service and Seattle City Light opened two new overlook areas designed to meet Forest Service accessibility guidelines: Riverside Canyon and Peewee Falls. Construction of the overlooks fulfilled one of the requirements under Seattle City Light’s license to operate Boundary Dam. Seattle City Light funds also paid for an upgrade to the nearby Boundary Dam overlook. The trail from the parking area descends through a few switchbacks, leading to a viewing platform with benches where you can relax and enjoy the view of Peewee Falls and Hooknose Mountain across the valley. After you leave the Peewee Falls overlook, turn left on Eastside Access Road and visit Vista House, where you’ll get a clear view of Boundary Dam. A short trail descends from Vista House to an overlook platform. A 9-mile hiking trail connecting the Peewee Falls and Riverside Canyon Overlooks, also funded by Seattle City Light, is nearly complete as of 2025. Toilet Information Toilet at trailhead Accessible toilet More information about toilets Wheelchair Accessibility The parking area at Peewee Falls Overlook has space for 15 cars, and includes van-accessible parking, accessible toilets, and picnic tables. The wide trail to the overlook is compacted gravel and was designed to comply with Forest Service trail accessibility guidelines. Parts of the trail may be steep for some wheelchairs, so you might want to bring a helper. The spacious viewing platform is wheelchair accessible. Hike Description Written by Mary Hartman , WTA Correspondent
column106: I have fallen in love with the upper right-hand corner of our state! I keep returning to the Metaline Falls / Sullivan Lake area. This stretch of the Pend Oreille River is a hydrologic anomaly, flowing north... the first time I pondered it, I felt so confused! Both Peewee Falls and Boundary Dam overlook are well worth a visit. The latter is especially interesting for civil engineers, as you get a good view of the downstream side of the dam. The wind was blowing pretty hard up the river canyon, though at the nearby Mill Pond Campground there was almost no wind.

column8:
Sweet Creek Falls Interpretive Trail, Sullivan Lakeshore, Riverside Canyon Overlook, Halliday —
              Apr. 6, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-04-08.164609329669)
column60: I was in the neighborhood over the weekend and decided to camp Saturday night in order to do some trail scouting on Sunday morning. I wanted to check out conditions on a couple trails, and started with Sullivan Lakeshore since that was closest to where I camped Saturday night. I started at the south end and mostly wanted to check out the early miles due to reports of some challenging trail conditions. Noisy Creek Campground isn't open for the season yet, so I parked near the gate and walked in. I was surprised by how low the water is currently, although I'm sure that will be changing soon as the snow starts to melt in the high country. I found the trail to be somewhat brushy and narrow in places, although all-in-all pretty good for early season. But I turned around just after the mile mark, so no reports on what conditions might be like beyond that point. When I stopped to re-tie my shoelaces near the end of the hike, I discovered I had several hitchhikers: ticks! It was funny because I had treated my hiking pants & shirt with permethrin ahead of the hike, but I forgot to spray my hiking shoes. The ticks were mostly trying to hide in my shoelaces. I think I found a total of six or seven, including a few later in the day, although I suspect I picked them all up on the Lakeshore Trail. It's kind of a known hotspot for them. After leaving Sullivan Lake I headed for Halliday, since I'm leading a trailwork crew up there next month. I discovered that there is still quite a bit of snow on this trail: patchy for the first mile, and then completely snow-covered beyond Halliday Fen (at which point I turned around). I'm sure it will melt out significantly in the next month and will be ready for the trailwork crew, and I found there are even a few warm-up trees down for us in the first mile of trail. At that point it was lunchtime, and I couldn't think of a better spot to enjoy my packed sandwich than the Riverside Canyon Overlook! It's just a short drive from the Halliday trailhead. There was a bit of snow over the roadway in shady areas: probably only a problem for very low clearance vehicles. The trail itself is snow free, and the viewpoint is fantastic. After that it was time to start making my way home, but I couldn't pass by Sweet Creek Falls without making the stop! The waterfall is roaring right now and will only get better with additional snowmelt. I discovered that the trail structure on the highest point of the trail system has toppled since the last time I visited. The lower trails are all in good shape, though.
column98: Hiking Riverside Canyon Overlook In 2023, the U.S. Forest Service and Seattle City Light opened two new overlook areas designed to meet Forest Service accessibility guidelines: Riverside Canyon and Peewee Falls. Construction of the overlooks fulfilled one of the requirements under Seattle City Light’s license to operate Boundary Dam on the Pend Oreille River. The trail from the parking area descends through a few switchbacks, leading to a viewing platform with benches where you can relax and enjoy the view of the magnificent Pend Oreille Canyon. You’ll notice the river flows due north at this location. It enters Canada a few miles to the north before turning west and joining the Columbia River. A 9-mile hiking trail connecting the Riverside Canyon and Peewee Falls overlooks, also funded by Seattle City Light, is nearly complete as of 2025. Toilet Information Toilet at trailhead Accessible toilet More information about toilets Wheelchair Accessibility The parking area at Riverside Canyon Overlook has space for 12 to 15 cars, including van-accessible parking and accessible toilets and picnic tables. The wide trail to the overlook is compacted gravel and was designed to comply with Forest Service trail accessibility guidelines. Parts of the trail may be steep for some wheelchairs, so you may want a helper.  The spacious viewing platform is wheelchair accessible. Hike Description Written by Mary Hartman , WTA Correspondent
column106: Before heading to the Metaline Falls / Lake Sullivan area, I stopped at the ranger station in Newport (the former ranger station at Lake Sullivan is permanently closed). The ranger told me a lot about the new overlooks and trails funded by Seattle City Light. She said a connecting trail between Riverside Canyon and Peewee Falls overlooks should be finished this season.

column51:
Price Sculpture Forest, Ebey's Landing —
              Jan. 10, 2026 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2026-01-11.150100833778)
column60: Quick second walk of the morning around the short Price Sculpture Forest after wandering around Ft Casey earlier.  Parking and access are free though limited to just a handful of spots and one disabled spot, (though there is a bike rack right next to the entrance if you can cycle there.)  There is a single though very well maintained sanican at the lot currently.  Neither bicycles nor dogs are allowed on the trails.  The trails remain a couple small (though not flat) loops with the art installations placed out in the woods along the way and were all in good condition.  Note, they are not ADA/wheel chair accessible.  The main draw is the sculpture and there is a pretty wide variety of types and styles to hopefully pique most people’s interest for at least a few of them.  There is also a virtually augmented program to download and use as well if you are into such things.  But even without the art this section of forest is quite nice, dense 2nd growth with lots of moss and a good number of native rhododendrons scattered about.  There is also a large bald eagle nest visible in the NE are of the property.  No eagles out today but there were a couple of talkative raven and quite a few little winter birds fluttering about chirping, etc.  A nice little walk in the forest, especially if you have an interest in sculpture.  Link to further information about the property - https://sculptureforest.org/
column98: Hiking Price Sculpture Forest Walk on a winding trail through a thick forest, peppered with sculpture art created by local artists. The trail itself forms two loops, and hikers are asked to follow directional signage to prevent congestion from hikers running into each other. Price Sculpture Forest indicates that while the first loop should be accessible for wheelchairs when the trail is not wet from rain (due to puddles and mud), the second loop is too steep. To do the self-guided tour, which offers a chance to listen to the artists themselves speak about their art as you walk up to their sculptures, look for instructions at the trailhead. The park is open every day from 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. or sunset, whichever is earlier. There is no admission fee to enter the forest, although donations to the Price Sculpture Forest are welcome. Toilet Information Toilet at trailhead More information about toilets
column106: Did a Whidbey walkabout starting out with breakfast in downtown Langley, visiting the goats at the chocolate flower farm and then wandering the Price Sculpture Forest. The quick trails at the forest are fun for the kids to explore and the art is beautiful. We also drove to Ebey’s landing beach and walked on the beach it was a little windy for the kids to stay too long or attempt the full Ebey’s landing trail but we will be back to do the whole trail again soon. We love winter on Whidbey. If anyone finds a key fob to a Toyota Highlander my daughter knocked it off the key ring and we don’t know where it was lost. Thanks!

column51:
Mirror and Cottonwood Lakes, Tinkham Peak, Twilight Lake —
              Nov. 16, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-11-17.013746275873)
column60: Only had time for a half day climb so decided to finally check Tinkham off the list. I did this via Mirror/Cottonwood lake and parked at the mirror lake trailhead. There was only one other car parked at the Th when I arrived at 7:30. There is parking, but it's all spread along the road. The parking is 0.2 miles from the actual trailhead, the final stretch of road has deteriorated to the point no cars are getting up that.  There are no facilities at this TH.  Road The road to get to the TH is in great shape, quite a bit on gravel but no potholes and no big rocks. I think just about any car should be able to do this easily. Maybe one or two rocky bits where you might want to take more care and that's it. I think the bigger challenge would be staying on the right road as it's a bit of a maze back there with FS roads.  Trail to Mirror Lake This is a really easy and beautiful trail. I see why it's popular with families. Nicely graded, nothing challenging and you get to the lakes very quickly. One person was camping at Cottonwood lake.  Boot-path to East summit The boot path up to Tinkham kicks this up quite a bit from the ease of the Mirror lake trail. Finding the entry to the boot-path might be tricky if you don't have nav simply because there are a lot of social trails around the lake.  The steep grade in the forest is honestly the worst part, about 50 feet straight up with some blow-downs to navigate around. Not too bad but my least favorite part.  After you break the trees on the final few hundred feet the views really open up. This is also the final steep section with more rocks this time. Overall as a boot-path this isn't bad, easy to follow and even though it's steep it's pretty short so it's over before you know it.  The summit itself has such a cool view for an easy climb like this. The lakes below make for a unique vantage. There is also a summit box located on the east summit. Lots of room on the summit ridge, but be careful with pets as the cliffs on the north side are sheer, there is the potential for a fatal fall if you were to stumble too close to the edge.   Boot-path to West Summit I came planning to make sure I got all of Tinkham, so I took the boot-path over to the west summit as well. This was also a very clear trail, and not as bad in terms of eg gained and lost as I had been expecting. Easy walk along the ridge, which was very scenic and you're on the other summit! I do think it's worth doing both, as there are some small lakes and tarns you cannot see from the east summit that you get from the west, also I imagine this summit gets fewer visitors.  The Return On my return I encountered a few people climbing up to Tinkham (5 total). Things were a little busier down by the lake, one group of day hikers and another set of backpackers. I only passed 2 other people on the PCT section on my way out until I got to the parking lot.  There were roughly 10 cars parked for the Mirror lake TH when I returned at noon. Easy to get out, everyone was parked out of the way so there were no problems.  Really fun climb, gorgeous views! Finally got the summit of the mountain I am always seeing from Silver peak.
column98: Hiking Tinkham Peak
column106: I followed @youcandoit's excellent and informative trip report from yesterday. I had a bit more time, so I went up and over Tinkham(s) clockwise starting from Mirror Lake. It started to rain on my way down, but by the time I got back to the junction just above Mirror Lake, the rain had stopped - so I created a figure 8 by passing Mirror Lake again and heading downhill to visit Twilight. The route up and over Tinkham was wet, but there were only a few brief stretches of snow - and they were not on the steep portions of the hike. I definitely recommend completing this route counterclockwise so you reach the last stream crossing pictured in @youcandoit's trip report at the end of your day. This was the only crossing all day where it felt virtually impossible to keep my feet dry - but it helped to know I was almost back at the car. I found a few tent stakes along the shores of Mirror Lake, and a small garden shovel high up on Tinkham. Let me know if these might be yours. I also spotted several doggie bags but did not pack those out this time because my trash bag was already full of metal objects.

column8:
Oneonta Trail to Triple Falls —
              Apr. 26, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-04-26.204639290049)
column51:
Oneonta Trail to Triple Falls —
              Jul. 15, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-07-15.230221791815)
column60: Beautiful day for a hike. The cloud cover was there in the morning but soon burned off by 1 pm or so. Several waterfalls on the way and an eagle's nest observed just past Triple Falls. Wildflowers just starting up really, and those were beautiful of course. Our goal was to make it to Franklin Ridge, but with time restraints we had to come back down. Wore my new Danner Mountain Light boots and loved them. Many people on the trail on a Saturday, but folks were very polite and helpful to each other. Some lose gravel and larger lose stones on the trail at some parts so be careful with footing. In short, take the time to think about where you step on parts of the trail with loose small rocks as you could easily twist an ankle. But don't let that stop you! The hike was amazing and well worth it.
column98: Hiking Oneonta Trail to Triple Falls This long, steep trail is one of the most challenging routes that leads to Larch Mountain, 7.7 miles away. Luckily, Triple Falls, just 1.7 miles into the trail, is one of the biggest draws of this hike, and a perfectly reasonable destination for most. And for those who want to go a little further on, there's a bridge at 3.06 miles with a shaded boulder field that would offer a 6.12 mile trip with about 1500 feet of elevation gain. To reach Triple Falls, from the trailhead, switchback up the Horsetail Falls trail for 0.2 miles to a T intersection. Turn right, and follow Horsetail Falls west. For a mile, you'll traverse just above the Columbia River Historic Highway, passing Ponytail Falls and Middle Oneonta Falls before connecting with the Oneonta Trail. At the intersection with the Oneonta trail, head uphill (left). Now you're on a moderately-steep and relatively exposed, rocky trail. Keep kids close and dogs leashed here; the trail has steep dropoffs through this section. Its about another mile to Triple Falls, which you will see well before you arrive to where the trail crosses the river. Before you arrive at the crossing for Triple Falls, there's a nice viewpoint of the waterfall, but be careful with your footing in this area. If you want to continue past Triple Falls, continue over the river and head upstream again. The trail here becomes a little brushier and stays closer to the river for a little more than a mile to a river crossing with a bridge and a nice shaded boulder field, great for snacks. Continue past the bridge and in just about 0.2 miles arrive at a camping area and intersection with the Horsetail Creek trail. Past this intersection, its 2.2 fairly steep miles to a junction with the Franklin Ridge trail . From here, you can continue along the Franklin Ridge trail to loop up with the Larch Mountain Trail, or you can continue on the Oneonta Trail for 2.3 miles to the summit of Larch Mountain. Toilet Information No toilet at trailhead More information about toilets
column106: The trail was very rocky. Sturdy hiking shoes/boots highly recommended. The beginning of the trail was nice in the canopy, but when you entered the gorge and left the forest, it was extremely hot and dry.

column60: Road up to Tomlike Mountain is closed. The information on the paper attached to the road closed sign says that the road will reopen on January 15th. We said F-it, moved a couple rocks and made our way up. Got about two and a half miles up and ran into a bunch of boulders covering the road. From what I've heard around Hood River, there was a really gnarly storm recently and a lot of the NF roads are shut down around Hood River. Deschutes is open and more hikes across the river in Washington are open. Know before ya go. Happy trails.
column98: Hiking Tomlike Mountain
column106: This was a fun adventure with varied terrain and nice views. None of the sections are too long so you won't get bored if a particular bit of terrain is not to your liking.  The wind made it a bit challenging in the exposed areas but at least it wasn't cold. The donning of the stocking cap was merely to keep my hair from whipping me in the face and/or losing my ball cap to the wind (since I'd already lost one to wind this year). We hiked a clockwise loop from Wahtum Lake to Chinidere Mountain, then on to Tomlike Mountain, returning via the Anthill trail.  There was some fall color up on the ridge to, and past, Tomlike Mountain, before that the foliage is mainly green.  The better fall color was as we were returning on the Anthill trail -vine maple near rock outcrops overlooking Wahtum Lake and some overgrown huckleberry bushes. The trail to Chinidere is in good shape.  The trail heading toward Tomlike included 9 downed trees in short succession, all easy to cross.  The trail to Tomlike includes varied terrain including forest, open ridges, scrub pine, a short boulder field before the ridge climb up to  Tomlike Mountain's summit. From the summit the ridge continues northwest. There were around 8 downed trees on the Anthill trail (smaller branch-sized so not really worth mentioning). Traffic: There were 2 tents at the Wahtum Lake TH campground one near the privy (which smelled of cinnamon potpourri by the way) and one across the parking area.  We did not see any tents at any of the walk-in sites we hiked past.  We saw 1 person on each section of our hike (1 person on the forested section after descending Chinidere, one person on our way down from Tomlike, and one person on the Anthill trail). Wildlife: 0 Weather: Sunny, warm, windy, wildfire smoke on the horizon in all directions

column60: Reached the huge parking lot for Beach 4 at 10am, only a dozen or so cars. Headed down to the beach, and continued north past a tide-pooly area for a bit over 3 miles to the south end of Ruby Beach. Thanks to a 0.0 ft tide, the entire route was a wide sandy beach. The crux of the trip was climbing down a rock at the end of the beach access trail below the parking lot. Saw few people on the beach on the way in, and almost no one until reaching the south end of Ruby Beach. On the way out, the beach area just below the parking lot had turned crowded.
column98: Hiking Beach 4 At a minimum, any stop at this trailhead isn't complete without visiting the viewpoint. From the signpost at the trailhead, take the right fork for a quick stroll along the 250-foot flat, graveled path. It leads to a viewpoint above Beach 4 with a stunning 180-degree view along the coast. This short path to the viewpoint also has some magnificent nursery trees. From the signpost at the trailhead, take the left fork for the main trail. There are several interpretive signs along the way where you can learn about local ecology. You'll quickly turn to the right and start the descent. The trail follows a small creek down the draw and is mostly wooden box steps with gravel. Enjoy the native coltsfoot and cow parsnip along the trail amidst more common rainforest flora. The trail ends at a short bridge with driftwood flourishes that crosses to an uneven rock outcropping. From the rock, it's about a 4-foot drop to the sand. At this time, there's a rope tied to the bridge to help you climb up and down. There's no other structured or safe method to reach the beach. Wind, water and erosion can quickly change beach landscapes, but this rocky entrance provides a more sustainable access point. Note that the only places to camp on the southern coast of the Olympic National Park are at the Kalaloch campground (3 miles from Beach 4) and the South Beach campground (6.5 miles from Beach 4). If you plan to adventure further along the beach, always make sure to check the tide times. On the return ascent up the stairs, if you need to stop to catch your breath, there's a rustic wooden bench before the final turn. Afterwards, don't skip a visit to the Tree of Life on the beach below the Kalaloch Campground, a couple of miles south of Beach 4 on US 101. Toilet Information Toilet at trailhead More information about toilets Wheelchair Accessibility There are five accessibility reserved parking spots at the trailhead. The viewpoint is 250 feet along a flat, graveled path. Hike Description Written by Aaron Czechowski , WTA Correspondent
column106: Trip report for Monday, July 7, 2025 to Ruby Beach, and Beach 1, 2, 3, & 4. Made a day doing five mini-hikes along the Kalaloch Beach area and Forks on a foggy Monday. Started north at Ruby Beach about 1:45pm in the afternoon. It was crazy crowded at Ruby Beach for a Monday (granted, however, it’s summer in July). Parking lot full and lines at the restrooms. The short trail to the beach is in good shape. The beach is still beautiful with all the shifting logs and rocks from the last winter storms, but got out of there quick with all the crowds and found peace and quiet at all the other nearby beaches and trails. Keep in mind, all of the trails to these beaches are short – like not even a quarter mile to get to the beach. Started north working south at Beach 4. It has a large parking lot and pit toilets available - take advantage of this because neither are at any of the other beaches listed below. Beach 4 has stairs leading to the beach and the bridge. A rope is attached to the bridge to help you down, but really it’s not necessary if you’re conditioned, and it’s a short distance down the rocks to the sand. The beach is lovely here - walked north to the point for tide, pulling, and rock hopping. Then drove a short distance to Beach 3, this trail switchbacks to a quick descent to the beach. There are a couple of faded but informative signs describing the area. Once down at the beach, there are some very cool rock formations that I was able to walk on and around during the low tide. Continuing on down to Beach 2, look for the trail sign right before the guard rail. A quick few steps to the beach and loads of rocks (like Ruby Beach) greet you - and amazing logs and huge tree stumps along the beach as well. Finally, Beach 1 also has easy access and immediately starts in a short burl tree forest loop. Amazingly strange and beautiful trees in my opinion. A trail then takes you down the stairs and across the bridge to the beach. You have to do some climbing over our logs, (so be careful because they can get loose) to reach the beach. Very stunning area with wind trees along the ridge here. Side note - Beaches 1 - 3 really don’t have parking. They are just turnouts for no more than four or five cars right on Highway 101 so be careful. I lucked out late in the afternoon on a Monday & I was able to get access every time I stopped, but I can’t imagine on the weekends. If you can get parking, it’s worth a quick trek to get to these beaches. They are all beautiful.

column60: There is a beautiful flower show still going on, along with magnificent vistas. Paul and I canvassed the eastern loop, flower list below, thanks Paul! There are still some thick areas of camas, triteleia, and sea blush, new thick areas of bare-stem desert-parsley and thick spots of broadleaf lupine and balsamroot. FLOWERING PLANTS IN BLOOM (49 species) white (13 species) large-flower triteleia (Triteleia grandiflora) — only the white version big-leaf lupine (Lupinus polyphyllus) panicled death-camas (Toxicoscordion paniculatum) shepherd’s cress (Teesdalia nudicaulis) common yarrow (Achillea millefolium) small-flowered prairie-star (Lithophragma parviflora) whole-leaf saxifrage (Micranthes integrifolia) cryptantha, species uncertain (Cryptantha sp.) miner’s-lettuce (Claytonia perfoliata) common bedstraw / goose-grass / cleavers (Galium aparine) coastal manroot (Marah oregana) bitter cherry (Prunus emarginata) arrow-leaf buckwheat (Eriogonum compositum)  yellow (14 species) Klickitat desert-parsley / biscuit-root (Lomatium klickitatense) nine-leaf desert-parsley / biscuit-root (Lomatium triternatumi) bare-stem desert-parsley / biscuit-root (Lomatium nudicaule) pungent / butterfly-bearing desert-parsley / biscuit-root (Lomatium papilioniferum) fern-leaf desert-parsley / biscuit-root (Lomatium multifidium or dissectum) Scouler’s hawkweed (Hieracium scouleri) sticky monkeyflower (Erythranthe moscata) seep monkeyflower (Erythranthe guttata) Carey’s balsamroot (Balsamorhiza careyana) antelope brush / bitter brush (Purshia tridentata) false agoseris / false dandelion (Nothocalais troximoides) western buttercup (Ranunculus occidentalis) salsify (Tragopogon dubius) spring gold (Crocidium multicaule) bluish: blue to violet to blue-purple (9 species) common camas (Camassia quamash) — one with white flowers bachelor’s button / garden cornflower (Centaurea cyanus) two-color lupine (Lupinus bicolor) longspur lupine (Lupinus arbustus) big-leaf or broad-leaf lupine (Lupinus polyphyllus or latifolius) larkspur, probably common / upland (Delphinium, probably nuttallianum) small-flowered blue-eyed Mary (Collinsia parviflora) Pacific hound’s-tongue (Adelinia grandis) ball-head waterleaf (Hydrophyllum capitatum)  reddish: pink to red to red-purple (10 species) tomcat clover (Trifolium willdenovii) big-head clover (Trifolium macrocephalum) red-stem stork’s bill (Erodium cicutarium) bicolored linanthus (Leptosiphon bicolor) bittter-root (Lewisia rediviva) shortspur sea-blush (Plectritis congesta) common sheep sorrel (Rumex acetosella) shooting-star, desert or poet’s (Primula conjugens or poetica) garden vetch (Vicia sativa) dove-foot geranium (Geranium molle)  orange (2 species) fiddleneck, Menzies’s or tarweed (Amsinckia menziesii or lycopoides) California poppy (Eschscholzia californica)  green (1 species) Garry / Oregon white oak (Quercus garryana)  BIRDS Western Meadowlark Turkey Vulture Red-Tailed Hawk Common Raven Western Kingbird Yellow-Rumped Warbler American Robin Northern Flicker Red-Breasted Nuthatch Violet-Green Swallow Killdeer Western Scrub-Jay Golden-Crowned Sparrow  BUTTERFLIES Silvery Blue (Glaucopsyche lygdamus) Anise Swallowtail (Papilio zelicaon) Julia’s / Pacific Orangetip (Anthocharis julia) — both ♂ & ♀ Gray Hairstreak (Strymon melinus)
