column98: Hiking Catherine Creek Loop This route at Catherine Creek takes hikers past a natural arch and into the higher country around the meadows at Catherine Creek. From the main parking area, head up towards the Natural Arch. Take a trail that goes up and over past the arch, and then continues up the hillside through the open meadows with stellar views of Mount Hood. Towards the top of the meadow, the trail heads into a grove of oak trees and heads east. Traverse this way for roughly a mile before arriving at a trail that turns you back down towards the river. This route heads back down towards the water, again with gorgeous views of the Columbia River Gorge, Mount Hood, and up close, wildflowers! Hike Description Written by Multiple authors contributed to this report, WTA Community
column106: Since the Forest Service recently opened Catherine Creek to recreation again after the Burdoin Fire in July 2025, we hiked the Catherine Creek Arch Loop to check out the fire impacts. As soon as I got out the car, I could smell the smoky scent of burned ground and trees despite four months having passed since the fire. Some areas of ground still were black and bare where the fire had burnt most intensely. Much of the burned area has greened up with introduced non-native grasses. We noticed burned Oregon white-oaks resprouting from their roots. Some shrub species, like ocean spray, also were sprouting new growth from their roots. The trailhead kiosk survived the fire. We passed it as we set off on our hike. We hiked the loop clockwise, hiking first on the Atwood Road to the spur where the BPA powerline maintenance road crosses Catherine Creek. An oak tree has fallen across the "trail gnome"-built footbridge, but we didn't need it since Catherine Creek was dry and we could walk across at the vehicle ford. We approached the Catherine Creek Arch, where a new buck-and-rail fence replaced the fence that burned and a new interpretive sign explains the arch is sacred to the Yakama Nation and is closed to the public. The old corral and remnants of ranch structures burned in the fire and nothing is left. We birded and botanized as we hiked, so our pace was slow. We saw about a half dozen acorn woodpeckers and a large convention of Stellar's jays convening in a tree next to Catherine Creek. Many juncos, kinglets, chickadees and brown creepers flitted among the oak trees. A prairie falcon flew low overhead while we were eating lunch. We looked for signs of returning wildflowers; we saw grass widow stems only about an inch out of the ground, small lupine starts, and bitterroot, micranthes species, and western buttercup leaves. Along the eastern part of the loop trail, several pine trees killed by the fire have fallen across the trail. We were able to go around them. The WTA-built log bridge across Catherine Creek survived the fire, with only a scorch mark on the underside of the log to show that the Burdoin Fire had passed through here. We completed the loop and returned to our cars. NOTE: a portapotty is available at the trailhead.

column8:
Mount Spokane State Park - Snowshoe Summit Route —
              Jan. 12, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-01-12.194213137109)
column51:
Mount Spokane State Park - Snowshoe Summit Route —
              Feb. 9, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-02-09.165818921864)
column55: Mount Spokane State Park - Snowshoe Summit Route
column60: Excellent snowshoe conditions to the top of Mount Spokane today. Lots of snow. Not ice crusted over. Most snowpack I've seen dumped on trees at lower elevations than all my previous years of trips made. Also, possibly the widest I've seen the trail be. Lots of group snowshoers. Was a rather jam packed day on this Sunday, but past the campground not many opted to go to the top. Great views even if lots of cloud cover. Baby blue skies poked through here and there. First time that I've been able to take off my mittens at the summit in winter. Loved that there was near zero windchill. Several downed trees, but none that are all that difficult to snowshoe around. Only weird change noted is that the skiers/snowboarders with ski passes are stepping off their designated ski path and going off route and going down the slopes where snowshoers and hikers are pushing for the summit. Is this a new allowed thing now?
column98: Hiking Mount Spokane State Park - Snowshoe Summit Route Snowshoers who wish to hike the direct route to the summit of Mount Spokane can use this winter-only route. This is a short yet difficult hike since it's a steep straight-up climb to the top! The route runs directly from Bald Knob campground (closed in winter) to the radio towers. Hikers need to remember to stay to the left of the ski area boundary on the hike to the top. Once on the summit, snowshoers are welcome to hike to the access point near the top of chair one, crossing at the gate, in order to visit the 1934 Vista House. The ski area operates a winter-only weekend concession stand inside, so get a cup of hot cocoa & relax by the fireplace before retracing one's steps or opting for more exploring on the park's extensive trail system.
column106: Absolutely perfect weather on the mountain today. We took the trail all the way up, hung out at the Vista House, then descended off-trail down to Deadman Creek, followed that to Trail 100, and headed back to the parking lot that way. It was so beautiful. By far the best part was the maze-like forest right near the lifts--no one there and utterly serene.

column60: This concerns the Allison Springs trail, which isn't even mentioned in the hike description but is generally the most interesting of the McLane School trails. To get there, park at the school and walk across Delphi Road to the Allison Springs water facilities (see the WTA Hike Finder map for this location). The trail goes left, along the south side of the water facility fence, and follows an old road beyond down to Allison Springs. This probably used to be a very impressive artesian spring before Olympia grabbed it as the main water supply for west Olympia, but it is still a large spring pool, perhaps 150 feet across, with a flow of several hundred gallons per minute that exits to the Mud Bay estuary via a very short stream. When I visited, it was occupied by hundreds of very active spawning chum salmon. The chum run here is generally timed about 2 weeks later than the popular McLane Creek run, so it was peaking in the first week of December. From here, except at high tide, you can also explore social trails through the tidal marsh that lines Mud Bay south of Mud Bay Road, or the more adventurous can explore the old forest that lies just south of the entrance trail.
column98: Hiking McLane School Forest Trail This multi-use trail, also known as the McLane School Trail, starts at the McLane Elementary School in Olympia. It connects to the Ralph Munro Trail which was formerly known as the McLane Nature Trail. The paved trail goes around the elementary school and includes signs identifying native plant species. Hike Description Written by Claudia Lopez , WTA Community
column106: Took two kiddos on bikes. Was pleasant. Small grade changes perfect for earlier learners. Similar to previous hike report, freeway is very loud and down steep cliff separated by small chain link fence. Less than peaceful and a little nerve wracking for small kids. But overall very nice for what it is. Will do again.

column60: This is a follow up to my last report. wonderful trail minus traffic noise. I could not figure out how to add photos in the last report, so now I am adding them.
column98: Hiking Ralph Munro Trail Formerly known as the McLane Nature Trail, the Ralph Munro Trail was re-named in June of 2018 to honor the man who established the McLane Forest Committee. The group was responsible for designing, building and maintaining the trail. The trail starts near the McLane Elementary School and goes along Evergreen Pkwy NW towards the Evergreen State College. The multi-use trail is popular with bikers. The trailhead is across the street from the McLane School Trail which is also called the McLane School Forest trail. Hike Description Written by Claudia Lopez , WTA Community
column106: paved and mostly flat. most of it was near roadways, so it was a bit loud at times

column60: The Middle Fork area was extremely busy today. Mailbox Peak Parking lot was topped off when I drove by around 2pm. I drove all the way to the Garfield Ledges trailhead, and the potholes across the bridge have gotten worse. You can take them as slow as you want but you'll still be jostled around in your vehicle. I double backed to Mine Creek trail and did a little trail running. After an intense leg day the day prior, I took it slow and easy but it still felt good to get out and get some trail time. The holidays have been busy with work and family stuff, so getting out today was a blessing. This would be hike #50 in my quest to achieve the 52 hike challenge.
column98: Hiking Mine Creek
column106: Last fall I had heard that there were some new accessible trails, picnic areas, and river views that were developed along the Middle Fork Snoqualmie Road. My husband had the afternoon free and we really wanted to get out of the house, but we’re also really tired, so we wanted something easy. I thought the Middle Fork would be the perfect place to get some fresh air and check out somewhere new. The Mine Creek Day Use Area was our first stop. A new parking area has been developed just around the bend from where we often see folks kayaking and accessing the river. There’s a new pit toilet, too. Wide, flat gravel trails take you out to the river through mossy forest. There are some picnic tables near the river, with easy access down to the water. We recorded just over a mile of trail on the loop we took. Then we drove down and checked out the new Russian Butte View access point. There’s a short trail to the river, with wooden logs to sit on and reflect while you admire the view. Russian Butte was hiding in the clouds, but it was still a nice spot. We ended up at the big Middle Fork trailhead, where we checked out the new paths and picnic tables. There are some huge trees back there! Any of these spots would make a fine destination for families of all ages to enjoy the forest and river. I’m so happy to see more development making access for all close to town.

column60: We were at the post office in downtown Bellingham and stumbled across this lower half of the trail.  Great walk on a cloudy day along the creek to view the raging falls and wander over to Maritime Heritage Park.
column98: Hiking Whatcom Creek Trail - West The westernmost end of the western half of the Whatcom Creek Trail is Maritime Heritage Park, which has a small trail system all on its own. One of its highlights is the Whatcom Creek Fish Ladder — in the fall, when salmon are running, you'll likely find other folks around to watch the bounding fish. The park also features the Maritime Heritage Center, amphitheater, picnic tables, benches and interpretive displays. If you head out of the park that way — past the fish ladder, up the stairs to the bridge — you'll start along the Whatcom Creek Trail. From here, the trail follows Whatcom Creek, crossing a few roads along the way. Be careful as you cross the street as these are marked but non-lighted mid-block crosswalks. Note that the section of the Whatcom Creek Trail between Ellis St and I-5 is the sidewalk along the road — east on Kansas St, then east on Meador Ave to I-5. Toilet Information Toilet at trailhead Accessible toilet Toilet has running water More information about toilets Wheelchair Accessibility The large paved trail within Maritime Heritage Park is wide enough for wheelchairs and mostly flat. Most of the gravel trails in the park and the length of the trail outside of the park are likely too narrow and rough for wheelchairs.

column8:
Chief Joseph Wildlife Area - Joseph Canyon —
              Oct. 20, 2020 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2020-10-21-9974373394)
column51:
Chief Joseph Wildlife Area - Joseph Canyon —
              Dec. 4, 2021 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2021-12-06-9307436745)
column55: Chief Joseph Wildlife Area - Joseph Canyon
column60: Revisiting this area I hiked up directly from Joseph Creek about 1/4 mile before the unmarked turnoff for the parking area in Joseph Creek Canyon. Hunters and fisher people were out en force up and down the Grande Ronde and Joseph Creek. I chose one of several ridges that rise 2000 vertical feet up from the canyon floor with the intention of walking the divide that separates Joseph Creek and The Grande Ronde River. Once on top of the ridge near point 2990 I noticed an elk herd relaxing in the saddle between me and point 3016. I decided not to continue as they were safe and sound from hunters below buzzing around on their quads. I instead watched them from the distance while having lunch before the steep descent. No trails in this area other than old roads in Green Gulch and a short section of single track in Joseph Creek Canyon which disappears within a mile or so in blackberry brambles. The ridges however are accessible for off-trail adventures and offer miles of walking with broad views over the canyons of Joseph Creek and The Grande Ronde. There is some steep terrain in order to get up there though.
column98: Hiking Chief Joseph Wildlife Area - Joseph Canyon The Chief Joseph Wildlife Area sits in the very southeast corner of Washington State. This trail follows Joseph Creek for a couple miles before ending in overgrowth. This area is primarily managed for wildlife habitat, so keep an eye out for wildlife. And, for another nearby hike checkout the Green Gulch trail . Hike Description Written by Multiple authors contributed to this report, WTA Community
column106: I have long had this area on my list of places I'd like to explore, and was finally able to make it happen! This was just a short weekend trip with some nearby car camping, and my friend and I started with Joseph Canyon on Saturday following the drive down from Spokane. It was overcast and off & on drizzly all day, but didn't start raining hard until well after dark. For the hike, we followed the main trail to the first likely looking ridge to ascend, then started making our way up to the top for the view. It's steep and there's no trail, but it wasn't at all technical. The view from the top is excellent. We descended down a nearby gulch, checking out neat rock formations along the way. Once at the bottom we still had a little daylight left, so we continued the rest of the way up Joseph Creek via the trail. As others have noted, the trail comes to a dead-end not all that far up the creek. It wouldn't be much of a hike if one was just sticking to the trail, but the off-trail scrambling in this area is great.

column60: This is not in Washington but it's not very far from the border. Moscow Mtn is the highpoint of The Palouse Range, a 10-mile ridge that runs east to west from near the Washington/Idaho border to north of the town of Troy, Id. It is visible from any hill in Pullman and most of the Palouse region as it stands nearly 2500' above the surrounding terrain. Much of the area is private timber land but access is open for recreation during the daytime as long as active work is not taking place. Parking for this hike is at the former site of the Tamarack Ski Area which is long gone. The access road is also called Tamarack and is plowed to about 3800' where snow enthusiasts can enjoy miles of roads for skiing and snowshoeing. East Moscow Mtn is 1.5 miles from Moscow Mtn and the site of an old lookout which is long gone as well but the views south are exceptional of the Palouse and as far away as The Wallowas, Blues and Seven Devils Range. It's relatively short hike of 4.4 miles RT and 900' of gain but one can also visit the ancient cedar grove another mile up the road or the actual highpoint of Moscow Mtn at just under 5000' a bit further than that for a longer outing. Edit: I returned on Feb 7 to find the road closed beyond the parking area to access due to active logging in the area. I was told it would be inaccessible for for about 3 weeks. Workers did suggest other roads that take off to the east and west just beyond the gate about 100 yards up Tamarack Rd from the parking area.
column98: Hiking East Moscow Mountain, Idaho This is not in Washington but it's only a stone's throw from the border. Moscow Mtn is the highpoint of The Palouse Range, an 10-mile ridge that runs from near the Washington/Idaho border to north of the town of Troy, Id. Much of the area is private timber land but access is open for recreation during the daytime. Parking for this hike is at the old site of the Tamarack Ski Area which is long gone. The access road is also called Tamarack and is plowed to about 3800' where snow enthusiasts can enjoy miles of roads for skiing and snowshoeing. East Moscow Mtn is the site of an old lookout which is long gone as well but the views south are exceptional of the Palouse and the entire region including the Wallowas, The Blue Mtns and Seven Devils Range. It's relatively short hike of 4.4 miles and 900' of gain but one can also visit the ancient cedar grove another mile up the road or the actual highpoint of Moscow Mtn a bit further than that for a longer outing.
column106: Hiked East Moscow Mtn, the second highest point in the Palouse Range, in stellar spring weather today. Some new areas have been logged lower down near the gate on Tamarack Rd over the winter but the upper end is still nicely forested. The road to the lookout site is the first left upon reaching the ridge top. The entire hike is just over 4 miles with just under 1000' of gain and the views are better than the more popular Kamiak Butte. Today was somewhat hazy and far off views to the Wallowas, Seven Devils and Blue Mtns were obscured by clouds. Some snow patches remain where the road swings to the north side of the ridge but they won't be around much longer as it's finally warming up around here.

column60: Lower Stevens Lake is likely the most popular hiking destination on the I-90 corridor through North Idaho.  I joined a Mountaineers outing to pick up trash from the campsites (please, pack-it-in, pack-it-out! but to whomever left the fire ring trash, the toothbrush (really?), empty wine bottle, empty water bottle, and half of a broken trowel (well, at least you brought a trowel...), and assorted smaller trash--you're welcome that I hauled it out for you.)  The fall colors are fantastic, and a little overnight snow really made the hike spectacular for our group of 11 hikers. We made this trip a lot more difficult than the basics by hiking the main trail to Lower Stevens (a fairly easy although steep hike), then connecting to Upper Stevens Lake.  The trail to Upper Stevens is less defined & was therefore difficult to find in the snow.  Then we hiked up a climbers route to gain the ridge (difficult) and summited Stevens Peak (very difficult).  From there, we made our way out along a ridge overlooking Lone Lake.  There's a climbers route down, but again, it was difficult to locate in the snow so this was a bit of a bushwack.  From the outlet at Lone Lake there's an easy trail back to the shared parking lot for both trailheads.
column98: Hiking Lone Lake North Idaho's Lone Lake is a beautiful alpine lake located close to I-90 for easy access. It shares a trailhead access point with the more popular Stevens Lake , and is only a short distance from an access point for the Idaho Centennial Trail. The route to Lone Lake starts on an old roadbed converted to trail, where the impacts of both timber and mining industry are still highly visible on the surrounding landscape. The trail is short and ascends quickly, and soon enters a recovering forest. This trail is ideal for summer dayhikes and fall color hikes. Snow tends to linger here, although the trail is usually accessible by early to mid-June. The hillsides around Lone Lake are covered in huckleberry bushes, perfect for late summer treats and spectacular fall colors. The trail climbs over 1600 feet in just 2 miles and deposits hikers at the outlet stream of Lone Lake with a dramatic backdrop of Stevens Peak towering overhead. Adventurous hikers can find the climbers' trail leading up the more moderate western slope above Lone Lake and gradually ascending to the ridge where it is possible to hike to Stevens Peak's summit, or even extend the hike down to neighboring Stevens Lakes. Hike Description Written by Holly Weiler, WTA Correspondent
column106: Today I decided to do the full loop for the Stevens Lake trail head. This was something I'd been encouraged to do but couldn't find a ton of info online about. Here's how it worked: I started up to Lower Stevens, which was gorgeous and warm. There was one tent set up, not sure if it was occupied when I hiked past it. Proceeded to hike the trail over to Upper Stevens. Note that this trail is in pretty rough shape and overgrown in many places; I definitely hiked off-trail for several annoying minutes of it. Markers could be helpful if not just better maintenance. Upper Stevens didn't have any people at it, and it was a much harder lake to get access to. I did see a single, adult mule deer and she was utterly gorgeous. We observed each other for a good minute before I marched on. The little side trails that break off at the lake and go up the valley wall--these are what I took, since there wasn't anything in any of trail apps showing a designated route up to the peak. I basically said "this isn't vert, so I can hike up it." I followed what turned out to be game trails above the treeline, and continued up and up and up and made it to the ridge. The far rock formation on the right of the ridge was my first "sit" or major break of the day, but there were so many of those fly/gnat things that I couldn't get a proper rest in, just for some water. I was a bit worried about how steep it was going up and how awful it would be if I did have to go back down. No spoilers. After gauging the ridge-line and thinking about how much problem-solving the light scrambling would yield, I suddenly saw it gleaming in the light: an old climber's trail! This trail followed the ridge 100% of the way to the summit, and it made me wonder if there was indeed a proper route up to the top of the ridge from Upper Stevens after all! After getting to the summit of Stevens, which was much faster than I intended (though I was very exhausted), I looked at the immensity of the valley on the Lone Lake side. I was a bit terrified as a solo hiker. I was told I would probably have to bushwhack to Lone Lake, and looking down from above was much different than gauging vert from below. But I did notice the ridge trail opened up a bit on the other side of Stevens and there was faint resemblances of game trail that I could just barely make out. I knew that if I had to turn around and head back the way I came, there was plenty of time for that, but I took the risk and challenged myself to push forward. The trail turned into an OHV trail of all things, and I followed that easily and quickly to what looked like the best descent point that didn't just drop off into oblivion. Taking one step at a time, I was able to navigate all the way down to the valley floor. Bonus was the sheer number of huckleberry bushes I walked through, which kept me hydrated and filled with positive energy. Getting to the valley was much easier than I thought, but then I had to make my way to Lone Lake! I knew where it was from the source lake but couldn't actually see it, so I had to go through some pretty unnervingly dense bushes. I screamed "Hey Bear" a gazillion times since this was perfect bear habitat, but didn't see any evidence of bears the entire trip. I slowly made my way down the source water to the source lake via game trail and amazingly found someone had cut open a trail that I could walk out, passing the source lake towards Lone Lake. I lost the trail a couple times but managed to find the trail at Lone Lake easily enough. My first sighting of real people was there, a couple enjoying the warm water and swimming. A brief hello and I didn't want to intrude so I decided to not jump in the water (I'll be back for that, I hope, on another trip!). I found myself easily walking the main trail out from Lone Lake, which took about an hour. The lot started with a few cars including mine, and ended with closer to ten! There were even folks just starting their treks when I arrived, much to my surprise (it got hot out!). Overall this was a fantastic adventure in the true sense of the word. I challenged myself, I found myself nervous and mildly afraid, and I figured out ways to overcome and persist, and I succeeded at the end of the day. One thing that was very helpful with my confidence is the fact that the beginning of the trail up to Stevens / Lone Lake has great cell service, and Stevens Peak and the full ridge also has full 5G, so I was able to share my location with my partner for most of the "sketchy part." Times:

column60: Note: the obstacles I report were only found on the Kyes Peak "trail"; the Blanca Lake trail is in great shape up to Virgin Lake, at which point I left it. I had been planning to attempt Kyes Peak for a while, and found a good day to get it done. Rode my motorcycle to the trailhead for extra adventure. The Blanca Lake trailhead took a bit of work to find via Beckler Road just past Skykomish. There were a dozen or so cars in the parking lot just after 7 AM. Climbing the Blanca Lake Trail from the trailhead to Virgin Lake is easy to follow, just a long walk uphill. Once off-trail, climbing from Virgin Lake to the ridgeline is fairly steep and slick in places. There is a decent climber's trail for the majority of the walk, and orange and pink surveyor's tape occasionally marks the route, but it's kind of sporadic. Staying on the east side of the ridgeline is recommended once above the obvious grassy meadow at ~4870 ft. A burned out area, with many large downed trees, was a little challenging to navigate. Climbing Blanca Lake East was an accident, because I was in my zone following the ridge. The standard climbing route descends left, from the ridge south of this small peak. After finding myself on top of it, I was cliffed out by the ridge, so I inched my way across some very slick mud-and-veg slopes, with mossy rocks for handholds and hundred-foot runouts below. This felt very slow, but I managed to follow the ridge north, to a saddle holding the main climbing trail, in about half an hour. Climbing from this saddle to the Monte Cristo Benchmark was fun. After leaving the forest, I chose my own adventure across talus and scree, aiming for the gap just north of the last gendarme. There are some cairns here and there, but following the path of least resistance worked fine. While I never once had to walk across snow, there was plenty of running snowmelt, which I used to fill a bottle on my descent. Climbing from the benchmark to Kyes summit is a fourth class scramble on slightly crumbly rock. However, the slab is not as steep as it looks from afar. It was too cloudy for great views from the summit, but on a clear day you'd have a phenomenal view of Glacier Peak and surrounding terrain. I down-climbed very slowly, as a slip on a loose pebble would probably result in a long ride. On the return, I entered the forest too low, resulting in extra uphill travel. Then I opted for the "main" trail, which bushwhacks through huckleberry and scrubby trees on the slope below Blanca Lake East. I found this route to be almost as yucky as the muddy veggie belays above, so I'm glad I tagged an extra peak on the ascent. The rest of the descent was uneventful, although keeping upright on slick terrain was much harder after all the vert on the way in. I returned to Highway 2 via the paved Index-Galena road, which was a much more pleasant ride than the washboards and potholes I rode in on. For gear, I did not bring an ice axe. I wore gaiters and shell pants (for wet veg), and carried microspikes, which I never used. Above Blanca Lake, thousands of juicy huckleberries were exploding off the vine! I wouldn't come all the way up here just for huckleberries, but snacking on them was delightful. Wading through them... not so much :)
column98: Hiking Kyes Peak A scramble to a summit off of Highway 2. Route-finding experience and climbing equipment required. Class 3 climbing.
column106: Distance (RT): 13.3mi/21.4km Gain: 5479ft/1670m Total Time (moving): 8hr27min Type: Solo Gear (used): Semi-rigid mountaineering boots, poles, helmet, gtx rain pants/coat Gear (unused but still recommended): microspikes Gear (should have brought): N/A Water: No sources past Virgin lake until tarn (6200ft) in boulder field below false summit. Additional (minor) snow sources further on. Bugs: None observed on route nor summit. Overnight trip. Road to trailhead (and washout section) in good condition. Only 4 cars in the lot. Reached Virgin lake by late evening and setup camp in a small wooded section just off the turnoff for the climber's trail as it starts upward. Only 2 campers spotted throughout and had complete solitude at Blanca lake for sunset. Note: the false summit (pyramid-shaped peak) is what is visible from Blanca, as the true summit block is obscured from view. Left camp by 9am. Conditions cloudy but everything was wet. Gtx rain pants/coat were vital throughout the morning. Trail starts faint (minor bushwhacking) and requires attention to follow. A handful of pink ribbons mark the way. Will eventually break out of the woods into a slightly more refined boot path, maintaining right (east) of the ridge throughout. Then reaching the first (of two) good meadow sections for camping at ~0.3mi in (4860ft). From here the trail is easily followed and will lead to a small rock gully (class 2/3 scramble). Then continuing on while still maintaining right (east) of the ridge . At 5400ft the 2nd open meadow (campsite) appears, offering views of Blanca lake and Columbia peak - albeit at this time things were still socked-in and damp, and I started to have concerns about whether the summit block would be dry enough to climb. The trail eventually reaches a burnt-out section, crossing from east to west over top of the ridge, and then down to a small rock field below (west) of Point 5600. Beyond here the traverse through numerous sections of meadow, tree belays/bushwhacking, and steep side-hilling begins - where the trail becomes difficult to follow and you will veer off. Though once out of each tree section, it was relatively benign to find and regain the path. I slipped and fell multiple times throughout but was too lazy to stop and put on microspikes. They would certainly be worth bringing, even if the ground is dry. Once passing through the final tree and rock section, a short down-scramble will lead into the large boulder field within view of the false summit. Just over the first minor rock crest at 6200ft is the tarn to filter water. Continue left (clockwise) around it and continue making your way upwards, taking the path of least resistance. Aim for the notch between what looks like an elephants foot on the left and the small sub peak north (photo 1). Going right around the foot and onward will lead you to a scramble path back up to gain the ridge of the false summit. From here it's a relatively flat section to traverse (photo 4) to the true summit block (now in sight) - with excellent views of Columbia peak to the west. Fortunately the weather cleared and the rock was dry by time of reaching the summit block. The final section is a class 3/4 scramble with loose, chossy rock covered in scree. The foot steps are small and the rock is brittle, but the ascent was mostly uneventful given enough care and attention (see photo 2 for route). However the down-climb required significantly more caution and careful maneuvering due to the exposure and potential for slippage. Summit offers brilliant views of Columbia Peak and Monte Cristo - and also sightings of Gothic/Del Campo, Vesper/Big Four, and Sloan/Pugh/Whitechuck. Overall a very-rewarding climb. Good route-finding practice, and the bushwhacking was not as difficult nor frustrating as presumed based on previous trip reports. For the most of the route, a visible boot path exists. Microspikes would be useful for the side-hilling and tree sections. I would not want to be caught navigating back through in the dark via headlamp - so plan your time management accordingly. The summit block does require extreme care. The footholds are small and covered in loose scree, while not offering much in terms of hand holds - but did not have any slip or fall moments.

column60: Did a quick overnighter from Indian Camp trailhead (off of FS Road 64). Spent the night at Shoofly Spring and went up Round Butte in the morning. The destinations are in Oregon, but the trailhead starts just over the border in Washington, so we are logging this one at WTA.org Solitude report: I saw two people at the trailhead, and didn't see anybody else during the hike. Snow report: A couple small patches of snow remain alongside the road, but roads and trails are snow free. Water report: Don't count on any water up on the ridges. The last snow has melted and the springs are dry. You'll have to descend pretty far down into the gullies to find running water. Trail status: Physically it's an easy trail with very little up and down. There were only 4 or 5 downed trees to cross. A couple small stretches had wildflowers overgrowing the trail, so long pants were nice, but not mandatory. But this was a walk, not a bushwack. The trail was mostly easy to follow, but it was faint in places, and it is easy to miss the junction between the Shoofly and Round Butte trails. But the navigation isn't too hard - you are just following ridges. There is no marked path to the top of Round Butte, just scattered game trails. Wildflower report: Flowers were great. Buckwheats, penstemons, ceanothus, alliums, columbines, and much more. Lots of color and variety. Bug report: Minor bugs, but nothing to complain about. Lots of pollinators enjoying the flowers. The ceanothus were swarming with bumblebees. Quite a few butterflies too. Getting there: You can approach from Walla Walla by taking Mill Creek Road to Tiger Creek, and then turning right to climb up FS Road 65. Mill Creek Road is paved, and FS Road 65 is well graded gravel. When you reach FS Road 64 (Kendall Skyline Road), turn left and head about 4 more miles to the trailhead. FS Road 64 immediately narrows to a single lane and gets pretty rutted. From Dayton you can take North Touchet road toward Bluewood Ski Resort, then continue past Bluewood on FS Road 64 for about 9 miles. FS Road starts as well graded gravel and gradually narrows to a rocky single-lane. Both approaches are pretty comparable in length and ruggedness. High clearance and AWD is helpful, and I'd very be cautious on rainy, wet days. Considering that there were still patches of snow in early July, FS Road 64 could be treacherous early or late in the season. Personally, I preferred the vistas on the Dayton route. The Indian Camp trailhead is a small roundabout just a short drive off of FS Road 64. There's a small stream providing water, but no bathrooms. The trailhead signboard has been knocked down. The trailhead is on my older FS maps, but not the current online maps, so I guess it's no longer being maintained. But the trail is still there for now.
column98: Hiking Round Butte This is an out and back on Round Butte Trail that can extend as far as you like.It's delightfully moderate, staying flattish almost until its endpoint at the Wenaha River. The Shoofly trail junction is 2.1 miles in, while the titular  Round Butte is about 3 miles in, though there is no developed trail to the top of Round Butte. An intersection with the Trapper Ridge trail is 5.5 miles in and past the Trapper Ridge junction, the trail descends down toward the Wenaha River. Until then, the trail follows the ridgeline and has fairly little elevation change. Toilet Information No toilet at trailhead More information about toilets Hike Description Written by Multiple authors contributed to this report, WTA Community
column106: I made a hike out to the summit of Round Butte on this stunner of a trail in the Oregon portion of The Wenaha-Tucannon Wilderness.  Miles of ridge walking with excellent views as well as nicely forested sections lined with huckleberries are just some of the prime features here. I only walked to Round Butte, about 3.5 miles each way, but wished I could have continued when I saw the terrain ahead. Though the trailhead requires some challenging roads to get to, the trail itself is actually in quite good shape. There are a few large blowdowns in the beginning but the rest of the trail, as far as I walked it, is clear and the tread is easy to follow. A short distance from the start of the hike there is a sign on a tree marking the crossing into Oregon and the trail eventually drops down to Wenaha Forks and joins The Wenaha River Trail. I walked the trail to the saddle on south side of Round Butte and ascended mostly open, grassy slopes to the 5904' summit. The ridgeline ahead was beckoning but I had gotten a late start and would have walked out in the dark. Next time I'll bring overnight gear (and water) to camp along the scenic ridge line. A primitive camp area is available at the trailhead with Indian Spring as a water source. The signboard, as noted in the last report, is no longer standing and presently is in use to dam up the spring creating a pool. The last report also nicely describes the driving conditions and options to get here. I came via Dayton from the north and a sign stated that Kendall Skyline Rd was currently closed at the Oregon border. A small fire had been reported in that area.

column51:
Kautz Creek to Indian Henry's Hunting Ground, Pyramid Peak —
              Nov. 11, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-11-11.184329759879)
column60: Did the long approach to Pyramid Peak from Longmire. Long day planned so I left early hiking in dark. Trail through Kautz creek was a bit difficult to follow with headlamp but it was there, if you aren't sure if you are on the trail any more then you probably aren't, just retrace and pick it up. Beautiful sunny skies at Indian Henry's, trail is a bit swampy for a couple of hundred yards after the Mirror Lake and Wonderland Junction. Surprised a bear at the large open meadow just before starting the climb to Pyramid. The bear loped off a short distance and continue feasting on berries. The trail after here is steep and rugged but easy to follow, it will carry you all the way but the last couple hundred vertical feet to the summit. Here the boot path disappears in rock but the route is obvious. By the time I arrived at the summit the peak had become completely enveloped in clouds but I still had nice views to the south. Just under 18 miles round trip with 4,800' of gain
column98: Hiking Pyramid Peak
column106: The bluebird day called for hiking in high places, and the Kautz Creek trail did not dissappoint! Incredible solitude allowed for full appreciation of the various mushrooms, birdcalls, and glimpses of mountain goats on adjacent slopes. Big  views of Adams, Hood, and St. Helens, and of course, Rainier. Snow began about 3.3 miles in at 4800 feet, but remained patchy until the descent into the hunting grounds. The morning snow was still crunchy outside the boot path, so I opted for no spikes on the way in, but it was slushy and slick on the way out so I was glad to have carried them. I made it up to the patrol cabin for lunch and decided to push on a bit toward Pyramid Peak. The Pyramid Peak spur was in worse shape - the trail was mostly underwater with a thin crust of ice. But if you're ok with wet feet, there was a boot path visible, at least until the next snow dump. I went as far as the saddle between Copper and Pyramid before turning back due to time.

column8:
Mill Pond Historic Site Trails —
              Jun. 26, 2024 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2024-07-13.143034642067)
column51:
Mill Pond Historic Site Trails —
              Apr. 6, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-04-07.193101352363)
column60: This was my second time to this historical site, and it has become one of my favorite stops when in NE Washington. Read the history of the flume and the log cabin -- fascinating! And seeing the young trees and meadow wildflowers reclaiming the valley after dam removal is heartening. It's nice to see accessible trails here. I think parts of these trails are going to need regular maintenance if they are to remain accessible.
column98: Hiking Mill Pond Historic Site Trails The first thing you need to know is that there is no longer a Mill Pond, despite what your topo map may show you. The dam that once impounded Sullivan Creek was removed in 2017 and habitat restoration followed. The site now offers accessible hiking trails in the tranquil northeastern corner of Washington State. Mill Pond Flume Trail is a 0.6 mile interpretive loop that showcases several historic structures, while the 0.9-mile Floodplain Loop takes you through reborn meadows and young groves of willow and aspen. Mill Pond Flume Trail The trailhead for the Mill Pond Flume Trail begins at the west end of the lower parking area. The trail begins by crossing a sturdy footbridge over the canyon at the former dam site, then goes southwest, along what used to be the shoreline. When you reach a fork, take the right trail, which declines gently into the forest. You’ll pass historical markers that include a log cabin and the remnants of a flume that formerly carried water all the way down the mountain to Metaline Falls. Take a moment to sit on one of the wooden benches along the side of the trail and enjoy the deep peace. In the shade of cedar and pine, you’ll hear nothing but the rushing creek and birdsong. The trail eventually intersects the Sullivan Creek Trail; turn left and go back over the bridge to the trailhead. Sullivan Creek Floodplain Trail The Sullivan Creek Floodplain Trail begins at the east end of the lower parking lot. The sign says “Sullivan Creek Trail 565,” but within a few strides you’ll reach a fork. As the sign indicates, bear right for the Floodplain Trail, which gradually descends. At about a third of a mile you’ll reach a junction, where you can go either way; it makes a loop around the flat floodplain. You’ll see groves of young trees, some new saplings, and meadows of wildflowers. Near the west end of the loop you’ll come to a short spur trail that supposedly gives you a view of the former dam site. However, the view is obscured by young trees that are clearly thriving – and after all, that’s the whole idea of restoring this valley. Continue around the rest of the loop and return to the trailhead. Toilet Information Toilet at trailhead Accessible toilet More information about toilets Hike Description Written by Mary Hartman , WTA Correspondent
column106: Lower flood plain was great! A couple of downed trees over the trail, but passable. The trail over to the Mill Pond campground was blocked and impassable  due to down tree.

column60: Today we drove the Sherman Pass Scenic Byway which crosses the the Kettle River Range and follows routes which have been used by wildlife and people for many years. We did this for the first time last year after reading a WTA report from the area! The expansiveness of the larch is awesome and can be seen in every direction. We first stopped at the White Mountain Fire Overlook which had a clean and well-stocked outhouse. We walked a short trail there which had informative signs. Next we did the scenic ADA accessible trail at Sherman Pass Overlook where there were 2 clean and well-stocked outhouses. The fall colors of the Larch, red berry bushes and other foliage were beautiful. 3 picnic tables each with a fire pit and a small Closed CG were there.
column98: Hiking Sherman Overlook The Sherman Pass Scenic Byway is a 35-mile stretch of State Route 20 connecting the towns of Republic and Kettle Falls. The high point of this road is Sherman Pass, which at 5,575 feet, is the highest mountain pass in Washington that is maintained year-round. The drive is beautiful, but to really take in the stunning views, make a stop at Sherman Overlook. The site features a picnic area with a short, accessible scenic trail, as well as a campground. The start of the paved scenic trail is clearly marked near an information board in the day use area. It leads eastward, looking down on a hairpin bend of Highway 20 and out toward the surrounding peaks. A series of information boards provides facts about forest fires and firefighters. An interior trail (also paved, but a bit rough) leads to a shelter. The main trail makes a loop that brings you back to the day use area. Toilet Information Toilet at trailhead Accessible toilet More information about toilets Wheelchair Accessibility The trail is flat and even, with little or no side-slope. Hike Description Written by Mary Hartman , WTA Correspondent
column106: We were a week early for peak larch color which was disappointing, but we did find some color. Yellow was the prime color with very few reds! Because of the recent snow, the short road to the overlook parking area was gated so we parked across the road in a fairly large pull off area across from the overlook. There was some slush and ice as we neared Sherman Pass, but the road was easily traveled. I will add a link below for our visit in 2024!

column98: Hiking Taylor Ridge This feeder trail for the Kettle Crest is known by mountain biking enthusiasts but makes for an excellent hiking route as well. The access for the upper section of the trail is 6.5 miles up NF-6113 (Bulldog Cabin Rd) at the 5050-foot level after turning south off of Boulder Creek Road. This trailhead is marked only with a signless post and parking for a few cars is available just across the road at a wide spot. This point marks the division between the upper and lower sections of The Taylor Ridge Trail which begins at Deer Creek Summit and continues to its lower eastern terminus, Tom Creek on Boulder Creek Road. There are some nicely forested sections of the trail before arriving to burned areas higher up. the highpoint of Taylor Ridge, 6190 feet which is an old lookout site just above the trail at the 2.6 mile point and has sweeping territorial views over the area. The single track joins an old road from here and continues northward to connect to The Kettle Crest and Deer Creek Summit. Toilet Information No toilet at trailhead More information about toilets Hike Description Written by Multiple authors contributed to this report, WTA Community
column106: This feeder trail for the Kettle Crest is known by mountain biking enthusiasts but makes for an excellent hiking route as well. I accessed the trailhead 6.6 miles up NF-6113 (Bulldog Cabin Rd) at the 5050' level after turning south off of Boulder Ck Rd. The trailhead is marked only with a signless post and parking for a few cars is available just across the road at a wide spot (48.7926276,-118.3392827). This point marks the division between the upper and lower sections of The Taylor Ridge Trail which begins at Deer Creek Summit and continues to its lower eastern terminus, Tom Creek on South Boulder Ck Rd. It was evident that a work crew had just come through very recently and cleared brush and trees from the trail so it is presently in great shape. There are some nicely forested sections of the trail before arriving to burned areas higher up. I walked to the summit of Taylor Ridge, 6190' which is an old lookout site just above the trail with sweeping territorial views over the area. The single track joins an old road from here and continues northward to connect to The Kettle Crest and Deer Creek Summit. The info on the FS link says that the access road is 6110 but my hike started on 6113 where the hiker symbol is located on their map. 5.3 miles RT and 1269' of gain.

column60: "In 1890 considerable mineral discoveries were made on Jumbo, prospector Knute Nesta and others named the mountain because poor mining claims made it a white elephant.  The Queen Anne Mine and a trail were on the N slope. From Squire Creek Road 4.8 mi. from Darrington (est. 1600'), find an old miner's trail...  Ascend timber parallel the creek (flagged) about 800 feet to an old shack...  can gain a total of about 2000 ft. on trail..." Cascade Alpine Guide   1977 My perseverance paid off!  Five visits in 2 weeks, today I found and fixed up a bunch of this historic path - one of the oldest I've had the pleasure of working on. About 300 feet before stream bed with culvert, find big pile of rocks I made and trail start on L.  I followed the animal/climber's path to where I had found trail last trip.  I knew for anyone to use it I would need to find the bottom half.  Didn't want to fix it if it were a dead-end, so waited to work on, flagged as found. USGS map Lost the trail, was ready to head home when I looked under the thick trees - there it is!  Funny how many trails I've found after giving up - was able to hook it up all the way to the bottom.  I turned around and clipped and raked, threw off sticks and branches, up to where I got on it today.   Had the saw but didn't use it.   There is a good spot to access the stream on the L for water, at boulder with only cairn on route.  Massive Old Growth trees. Now that I fixed the lower part I can easily do the rest, which is already in better shape since it's the part the climber's use.  Part I fixed today looked like it hadn't been used since 1977, no evidence of any work having ever been done.  Cleaned up trail cut my descent time in half. No other hikers, even on Squire Creek Trail.  Stirred up a hornet's nest but they gave me a second to back away, unlike usual.  I would say come see! but it doesn't really go anywhere yet.  At 2300', miner's trail heads L above slide, current Jumbo climbing route goes R and crosses stream.  Here's a detailed description from 2016 at Willhiteweb Someone dumped a bunch of trash near the end of the road since my last visit - I filled up the trunk with what would fit.  Pick up is tomorrow, time to see what I got! Cheap gas at I-5 and 530. A quick scan of the nearly 100 Reports from today so far reveals no one but me and Kenwx (has works right in the name) doing any trail work - c'mon people!  Just because it's Summer doesn't mean you're on vacation.  A wider variety of destinations visited with the dwindling snow, but still few I haven't heard of, and none new. Want some new places to go?  Look at the old Metsker's Atlases on Historicmapworks.com .  Pick a "lost" trail, fix it up, write a Report, and create one!  Almost always some evidence of even the most missing, just a handful of trails I've sought and not been able to find.  3 Reports for here before my 2 from this year.
column98: Hiking Jumbo Mountain Summit scramble off Squire Creek Trail on Mountain Loop Highway. Gear and expertise required.
column106: Final day of cleanup on this for now.  Trail to where I found it is in good shape after 6 days of work clipping , sawing and raking.  At the very end I saw where it went above what I located, but I had climbed in a couple other spots so had no more in me.  It'll be waiting when I return.

column8:
Catherine Creek Loop, Catherine Creek - Natural Arch, Catherine Creek - Tracy Hill Loop —
              Apr. 10, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-04-11.052451310716)
column51:
Catherine Creek - Tracy Hill Loop —
              Dec. 3, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-12-07.135315714795)
column60: EDIT: The full loop that I did was actually the Tracy Hill loop. Apparently when I walked up above the arch, that was the western portion of the Catherine Creek loop. So I did not go on the eastern portion of the Catherine Creek loop. This route took me directly onto the Tracy Hill loop and explains why my hike stats didn’t quite match either of the WTA descriptions! Also, because I just kept going straight, it was quite easy to not go onto the eastern most portion of the Tracy Hill area which goes onto tribal land. ORIGINAL REPORT: My first Columbia River Gorge hike in Washington. Amazing to see so many wildflowers now in April that I don’t usually expect until June. Top three new flowers for me were different types of camas, grass widows (had to go all the way to the top of the loop to see a few still blooming), and shooting stars all over (from half mile or sooner into the hike and to the top)! I did the loop counterclockwise which meant going out over the footbridge on the east side and coming back near the end on the damaged plank bridge, which is opposite of the WTA description. I recorded about 5 miles and 1400ft of total elevation gain. Going this way also means you hike up above the natural arch first and hike back down below it, and that’s when you can see it. So if your main goal is the arch, you’d want to head towards the plank bridge on the west side first. There’s also a smaller loop that can be done, which I think is about 1/3 the size and still includes tons of flowers and the arch. I don’t know how, but somehow in one of the million flowers I was taking a photo of there was a crab spider feasting on a bee (see photo). Well, apparently there were loads of ticks trying to do the same to my dog. I think next time I’ll be coming without him. No issues with poison oak or rattlesnakes though. Parking was easy today. There was a doggy poo bag dispenser at the trailhead and a trash can across the street next to two portable toilets.
column98: Hiking Catherine Creek - Tracy Hill Loop The Tracy Hill Loop at Catherine Creek is a popular route, but the eastern-most portion of it crosses a parcel of tribal land not open to the public. Visitors are encouraged to use the WTA-built Catherine Creek loop, which starts and ends from the main parking area for Catherine Creek. WTA worked here in 2013!
column106: We hiked the Tracy Hill Loop (or at least our version of it) to check out the effects of last summer's Burdoin Fire. It was a cloudy day with fog hanging below the Columbia River Gorge rim. We started by hiking below the Catherine Creek Arch on the service road. The vehicle ford still was dry so we didn't have to use the "trail gnome bridge," which is looking pretty decrepit with rotten and broken stringers. We hiked up the east side of Catherine Creek, ascending through the meadows to the rim above Major Creek on what I call East Tracy Hill. We saw several species of native plants sprouting in the burn scars from the fire. Amazingly, Rush Skeletonweed, an invasive species, survived the fire and the upper meadow is filled with its dried plants. After lunch, we traversed over to Tracy Hill proper to check on a large Ponderosa pine overlooking the Catherine Creek canyon that our friend, Bev, long ago dubbed the "Friendship Tree" because we have enjoyed many hike lunches over the years in its shade or wind and rain/snow shelter. The "Friendship Tree's" offspring were mostly killed in the fire and the tree itself had scaling bark that suggested it might not survive. The fire burned intensely in the deep duff of pine needles and appeared to have scorched the tree roots. We will have to watch it into the future to know its fate. We descended Tracy Hill and took an old ranch road down through the oak woodlands. This route had been overgrown with poison oak in recent years but the fire set it back for at least a short time so the route is accessible again. We closed our loop and returned to the trailhead without seeing anyone all day. PRO TIP: The port-a-potty at the Catherine Creek trailhead has been removed. We used the Chamberlain Lake Rest Area on SR 14 as a restroom stop before and after our hike.

column60: Cross country hike starting from a pullout just south of the turnoff down to the boat ramp. Short easy walk across low, inactive sand dunes to the deeper sand along the top of the bluffs. Beautiful day, intermittent sun, windy as usual in the dunes but calm everywhere else. Lots of flies which seemed odd for this time of year. Saw lots of deer around the dunes and even a porcupine on the drive back out to Highway 24. Dirt roads are in great shape. Didn't see another person the whole day. This area is truly a gem in all but the hottest months of the year.
column98: Hiking White Bluffs - Central Slope The White Bluffs are a line of spectacular sedimentary cliffs rising 300 feet above the Hanford Reach, the last free-flowing stretch of the Columbia River. The bluffs are composed of the pale Ringold Formation, ancient lake and slack-water sediments deposited by the ancestral Columbia River between 8.5 and 3.4 million years ago atop the underlying basalts. You’ll also find sand dunes here, as well as badlands and both ancient and more recent landslides. Behind the bluffs is gently rolling shrub-steppe, host to a lush array of shrubs, grasses, and wildflowers, including some sand-loving species not found in the more common rocky and loamy soils of the shrub-steppe. The entire area is home to a wide variety of wildlife, from lizards and mice to coyotes and deer. You may not spot any critters, but you’ll find plenty of sign, especially coyote scat and tracks of all sizes in the sand. And you’ll almost certainly see (and hear) large numbers of geese and other waterbirds. For this hike, drive to the White Bluffs Overlook and head north on a clear game/boot trail. As you walk you’ll have magnificent views up and down the Columbia River, west to the Hanford Nuclear Site, Rattlesnake Mountain and the more distant Cascades, and north to the Saddle Mountains. After about a mile you’ll come to an area of open sand, flat at first, then rising into a nice dune. Continue north over this dune down to a grassy area and on to the next area of open sand. There is no obvious trail, but the route is open and almost entirely on sand, so it’s impossible to lose your way. You’ll almost immediately climb another large dune, then follow a series of lower dunes to a final big dune, a little over three miles from the trailhead. Once past the first area of sand, the bluffs themselves are not especially impressive as they have slumped away in the Wiehl Ranch Landslide complex, a recent landslide (1980s & continuing) caused by loosening of the Ringold sediments by irrigation water seeping from man-made Wahluke Lake and the unlined Wahluke Branch Wasteway. This is an area of hummocky terrain typical of landslides that cries out for exploring. There are numerous easy ways down from the sand and plenty of game trails among the small hills and valleys, sandstone pillars, stands of common reed, and hidden ponds. The dunes above are being formed by the prevailing winds blowing loosened sediments up from the landslide below. Once at the final dune, there are a number of ways to complete your hike. The easiest option is to retrace your steps for an out-&-back hike, but with some planning there are at least two attractive car shuttle hikes. One is to leave a car just south of the Wahluke Branch Wasteway on the road to the trailhead. Your vehicle should be visible from the top of the last dune, so just make your way cross country from the dune back to the road (about one mile). A second option is to leave a vehicle at the trailhead for the White Bluffs North. From the last dune, make your way along the bluffs until you find an easy way down to river level and then walk north to your vehicle. And throughout your hike remember that the cliffs can be unstable, so use caution when near the edge. Hike Description Written by David Hagen, WTA Correspondent
column106: We stopped by the Bluffs on our way to pick up our son from Walla Walla University. We missed the turnoff from the main highway because there was no sign at the iron gate, marking the gravel road. A couple flowers were still blooming despite the dry conditions. The weather was nice with clear blue skies, and a slight breeze to cool us as we walked. Highly recommend taking a lot of water or fluids, especially as the temperatures continue to rise as summer progresses. Due to the lack of vegetation for shade, it would be advisable to hike early in the morning when it is cooler (especially if you are taking kids along). The scenery was beautiful. We will do it again.

column8:
Huckleberry Creek, Burroughs Mountain, Sunrise Rim Trail —
              Sep. 10, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-09-11.055831275844)
column51:
Sunrise Rim Trail, Shadow Lake - Sunrise Camp Loop, Burroughs Mountain, Glacier Basin Loop —
              Oct. 8, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-10-09.095429769195)
column60: Want to make a note to anyone traveling on Huckleberry, there is a small fire present on the slopes above the trail.  I did a lollipop loop into the park starting at Huckleberry and then doing a loop around the Burroughs.  On the way in, there was no smell of smoke but on the return, I watched as a helicopter traveled up and down the valley and then noticed smoke in the valley. Return trip was inconsequential as the fire is pretty far above the trail but good for people to be aware. As for the trails, all are in great shape.  Huckleberry is such a pleasant forest walk and this route showcases the diversity of the park, from old growth forest to subalpine meadows to the alpine of the Burroughs. Of note, if you are early like me, prepare to get showered below the knees from morning dew.  Lots of water sources until you get just past Forest Lake.  Some log bridges that are narrow and care should be taken if they are wet.  Not quite the bonanza of berries like I experienced last week but they are still out.  Didn't encounter a single person on this trail on the way in or out. Sunrise area was surprisingly pretty quiet which was nice.  Burroughs always impresses with the in your face views of Tahoma. Road is rough but just go slow and you will be good.
column98: Hiking Sunrise Rim Trail The Sunrise Rim Trail is a short connector trail that links Sunrise with the Wonderland Trail, providing expansive views of Mount Rainier. The trail itself is a slight descent to the junction with the Wonderland Trail. It's a great standalone hike if you're hoping for a stroll near Sunrise to get a little closer to the mountain. This trail also ends up being a part of many hiker-made loops around the Sunrise area, as it offers an alternative to or from the west side of Sunrise to the popular Sourdough Ridge trail . If you'd like something just a tad little longer, Shadow Lake is only a short hike beyond the junction.
column106: Epic is an understatement. This hike (10.25 miles/3000 ft.) on a day such as this was one jaw-dropping view after another. The temps stayed in the 40's all day. Great views in the morning, then the clouds. The blue sky was roiled by swiftly moving clouds; just added to the views. Sunrise Road is closed and our contacts with humans was almost zero until on the Glacier Basin Trail on our return to the WRCG. We think CCW is the way to go. After the initial part of the Wonderland, great views abound until back on the GBT. Georg and I started up the Wonderland from the WRCG a little before 8 and arrived back a little before 4. After intersecting with the Sunrise Rim Trail and on our way to the Sunrise Camp we spotted a fox in the meadows just before the camp. Georg had just remarked that he had seen a fox at Sunrise on our hike to Dege same time last year. At the camp we met the only hikers we would see for hours. A couple from North Carolina doing the Northern Loop. They were impressed to say the least. Looking up at the First Burroughs from the camp it looks like quite a hike-only because it is. As I arrived at the top, I was greeted by the trail to Second Burroughs. Georg told me to stop whining and in no time it would be all down hill. I just focused on the Second Burroughs sans people. It was all worth it. We spent close to an hour just soaking in the views and taking advantage of the rock chair. If only it reclined. You can see the lookout, Skyscraper, Tamanos, Mt. Ruth, Dege, a great close up frontal of the Mountain and all its topography. Looking down on all the trails from Frozen Lake, not a person in sight. We did this exact hike 3 years ago and along with Dege and the lookout, we save these for the week from when the Sunrise Rd. closes and the WRCG stays open for a week or so. Great alone type hikes to really some of the best views of the Mountain and its surrounding terrain. They are even better with no people. Our hike from the Second Burroughs to the GBT is rocky, semi-steep with loose sand. At my age I tread very carefully. My rock-hopping days are over. Almost all the way down you are treated to a great view of the Mountain and great fall colors. The views never get old! Looks like we hiked one of the last nice days. Snow and rain forecast for the next week or so. Maybe Grand Park from 73 if there is a break and no snow. Happy hiking!

column60: Wind River Arboretum is a place full of vistas. Except, you must be prepared to look up! This is a place to take your time and not conquer as another trail accomplished. I only realized this after meandering for a few. That is when you start to look up and really see the striking differences between these trees. Arrived around mid-afternoon on a sunny Easter weekend. It was a bit shocking to see not anyone out on this trail except for the two gentlemen (One was a Stephen King fan) who were just exploring the area and found signs leading down the road. The trail directions and information are spot on. The thought of 'Whimsical' ran though my mind after staying on the main trail heading left for a few. A true arborist probably dreams of this place as their own emerald jewel. Most of this area was a saturated lush green color that can make anyone smile. A lot of the ground foliage is still in hibernation with few new leaves. There are a decent amount of fallen trees on the backside of the trail near the dry creek. They shouldn't poise too much difficulty to pass over.
column98: Hiking Wind River Arboretum U.S. Forest Service research dates back almost to the time the national forests were created. In 1910, research began at Wind River to learn more about reforestation following the Yacolt Fire in 1902. Established in 1912, the Wind River Arboretum is the oldest in the Pacific Northwest and ranks among the earliest forestry experiments still in existence in the region. This interpretive trail passes dead and surviving trees of 250 species from all over the world planted here to see which ones would grow best for timber production. Small placards identify each species; 14 larger interpretive signs tell how the exotic trees fared. It’s no surprise native trees grow best in this climate. If you start your hike on the trail to the left at the arboretum entrance, you will be able to read the interpretive signs in sequence. As you walk through the groves, contemplate the long-term learning that has happened here over the last century. When you leave, look up in awe at the Giant Sequoia trees in front of the historic houses on Chapman Avenue; they have grown very well at Wind River. The low elevation makes this family-friendly hike accessible most of the year, but spring brings wildflowers under the trees. WTA Pro Tip: Some of the former Forest Service houses have been renovated and are available to rent for overnight accommodations. If you’re visiting for the day restrooms are seasonally available at the Hemlock Picnic Area at the junction of Hemlock Road and FR 43. Toilet Information No toilet at trailhead More information about toilets WTA worked here in 2025, 2024, 2023, 2022 and 2021! Hike Description Written by Susan Saul, WTA Correspondent
column106: Just a short distance off the very winding Wind River Road, this place was utterly deserted on a warm Friday afternoon. With all the old buildings nearby, I almost felt like I was trespassing, but the arboretum is clearly marked and maintained.

column60: Decided to check out this trail before the rains set in. Loved hearing all the bird song. Our dog enjoyed his visit!
column98: Hiking Little Lake Forest The Little Lake Forest was acquired by King County Parks in 2018.  A small forested lake sits in the middle of this 155-acre park, and a gravel access road leads to the northern shore of the lake. King County Parks restoration program has been planting native plants to restore vegetation around the lake. And WTA volunteers broke ground on an ADA accessible trail in the spring of 2021. This trail along with a parking area and other improvements will someday make this a more accessible area for recreation. Currently there is no parking available. Note: This park connects to the Tomanamus Forest, which is owned by the Muckleshoot Tribe and managed by Hancock Recreation. You need a special permit from Hancock Recreation to access the Tomanamus Forest. Toilet Information No toilet at trailhead More information about toilets WTA worked here in 2024, 2022 and 2021! Hike Description Written by Charlie Wakenshaw, WTA Staff
column106: Have lived in the area a long time but have never explored this area before. We decided to visit this trail with two kiddos and two dogs. Although there is no parking lot, there is room for a few cars to park along the side of the road. We followed the main trail down to the lake. Once there, we completed the loop around the lake and took the main trail back to the car. My watch died while on the trail but we roughly clocked 1.5-2 miles. At the lake we saw several ducks, a beaver house, and lots of beaver signs (gnawed trees/branches) but no beaver. As a previous trail report said, we saw a handful of other people on the trail, most of which had an unleashed dog.

column8:
Antoine Peak Conservation Area - Summit Loop, Antoine Peak Conservation Area - Emerald Necklace —
              Nov. 6, 2024 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2024-11-06.171511864272)
column51:
Antoine Peak Conservation Area - Emerald Necklace —
              Jun. 8, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-06-08.135913421413)
column55: Antoine Peak Conservation Area - Emerald Necklace
column60: I woke up too early & couldn't get back to sleep, so decided to go to nearby Antoine Peak for a sunrise hike. I just happened to pull into the parking lot right behind a good friend who had the same idea, so we had an excellent morning hike & chat to the summit. At that point my friend needed to turn back but I still had a little extra time, so I completed my favorite easy 5-miler by dropping down Upper Canfield Gulch and then hiking around the north section of the Emerald Necklace. There were some fresh looking moose tracks, but I didn't spot any this trip. We did spook a grouse on the hike up, which isn't really a common sighting up here so that was fun! And the sunrise was gorgeous; definitely the perfect decision to get outside and move my entire self instead of staying home to let my mind race in the early morning hours.
column98: Hiking Antoine Peak Conservation Area - Emerald Necklace The Emerald Necklace trail encircles the upper portions of Antoine Peak. Trail users who come to experience the Emerald Necklace often utilize the Brevier Road access into the West Trailhead of Antoine Peak. Those wishing for more of a challenge, or at least more elevation gain, should access the trail from the Trentwood Trailhead on the south side of Antoine Peak near Wellesley Rd, since the west trailhead is 620 feet higher in elevation than the Trentwood Trailhead. You'll get more of a workout starting from Trentwood. While traversing the Emerald Necklace loop, the views around the north side of Antoine Peak towards Mount Spokane are some of the best to enjoy. It is important for route finding to know that the Emerald Necklace is completely composed of old logging roads and does not incorporate any singletrack trail. The trail junctions are well marked with wooden posts and reflective trail name signs to assist with route finding. The Emerald necklace does gain and lose elevation while going completely around Antoine Peak. For those interested in Geocaching the south portion of the Emerald Necklace loop has numerous caches. The Emerald necklace is popular with trail runners and offers multiple complementary loops and on/off connections to accommodate athletes seeking various mileage totals for the day. History Antoine Peak is named after Antoine Plante, an early frontiersman who operated the only ferry across the Spokane River in the area. Toilet Information Toilet at trailhead More information about toilets WTA worked here in 2024, 2023, 2022, 2021 and 2020! Hike Description Written by Todd Dunfield , WTA Community
column106: Trail was in great condition. We were a group of 3 experienced backpackers and found the signage format to be misleading/confusing. Would recommend bringing a downloaded or printed map. Great birdwatching trail! Saw moose scat. Thimbleberry, lupine, columbine all in bloom. We started 730am and had intermittent shade throughout the hike. Bring extra water, esp if you have dog(s). Privy at trailhead.

column60: accidental double post
column98: Hiking Chehalis River Discovery Trail Explore the Chehalis River between working farmland and recently restored riparian habitat. Your hosts: a bevy of birds, from barn swallows to bald eagles. From the parking area, walk the gated access road past working farms and an old barn—notice the nesting swallows—to a T-junction at 0.3 mile. Pick up an interpretive guidebook and follow the signposts, first right, then back. Trees and shrubs along the river bank were planted in a partnership between the City of Centralia and the Chehalis River Basin Land Trust to protect salmon habitat. As they grow, cottonwood, red-osier dogwood, and willow will restore eroded river banks and create spawning grounds for threatened char. In the meantime, they provide superb bird-watching, including bald eagles, a pair of which resides here year-round. Note, too, the mature black cottonwood forest across the river. The largest such grove remaining along the Chehalis, this ribbon of riparian woodland is protected in perpetuity under a conservation easement. At 1.2 miles, reach the end of the north branch of the route. Note the expansive agricultural fields; they soak up water from the treatment plant and act as a filter before it reaches the river. Follow the path back past the T-junction to the south branch at two miles. Continue on the south branch to its terminus at 2.6 miles, where a thick grove of Douglas-fir and western red cedar towers over a 90-degree bend in the river. Relax on the shaded shoreline before returning the way you came. WTA Pro Tip: Built in 1908, the Olympic Club Pub caters to tourists and timbermen amid warm wood and turn-of-the-century details. If you have time to stay, check into one of the Olympic Club Hotel’s 27 intimate European-style rooms. Toilet Information No toilet at trailhead More information about toilets Hike Description Written by Aaron Thiesen, WTA Correspondent
column106: Previous poster reported the trail flooded out but it was dry and accessible today. Trailhead parking is well marked and located in the front lot of the city sewage treatment plant, the locals by the trail only get upset if you bypass that. TH has bathrooms but they are locked in winter. The trail is more of a walk than a hike and I mostly see folks here with kids and dogs all year round. Takes a couple of hours to do the whole thing if you choose to but easily shorter than that as after about a half mile it comes to a north-south T junction where the trail goes both directions, both ways are in and back. If you go south its mostly a walk along the back edge of farm fields but at the very end is beach access to a local swimming hole on the river. North section of the trail follows the river for a better out in nature experience. This trail is a bit of a hidden gem but that’s part of its charm. Doesn’t hurt that it’s pretty close to the highway and not that far outside of the city

column60: Very nice hike for my partner's birthday. Only went out a couple of miles, but the road is in nice condition the whole way. Lots of people and dogs out and about which was great to see. Another time I would love to come back and do some of the trails that went off the road and up into the mountains, but we were with some inexperienced folks this time so kept things chill. Only comment I guess - the trailhead that is marked on WTA is not right; the coordinates stop you at least 6 miles from the trailhead. The description on WTA is correct, but for those of you like me who just click the trailhead link and don't bother reading much... well hopefully you read this :). Drive to the very end of Icicle River Road! Just keep on going until you hit the barrier.
column98: Hiking Icicle River Road Snowshoe This trail is the final section of Icicle River Road that is left unplowed in the winter months. It is fun for snowshoers of all ages and skill levels. The trail slowly ascends its way up the Icicle Creek Valley, offering impressive views of Grindstone Mountain and the meandering, peaceful Icicle Creek. From the parking area, strap on your snowshoes and continue on Icicle Road for as long or as short as you like. This isn't a loop trail nor does it really "lead" to anywhere in particular. The trail simply meanders alongside the creek, gently rising and falling with occasional mountain views. This trail is used by snowshoers, skiers, snowmobilers, even dogsledders. It is not plowed but the snowmobilers do a great job of breaking trail for their fellow skiers. The native name for Icicle Creek was Nasikelt. As pronounced, this name sounds very similar to Icicle. Legend has it that early pioneers mistook the proper native name and interpreted it as Icicle. The name Icicle was established by USGS maps in the early 1900s. The valley is aptly named as you can see the huge icicles hanging from steep cliffs that line the road.
column106: Had planned on Icicle Gorge but didn't realize the road is closed at Bridge Creek. No worries, we parked there and first explored the campground and the bridge before snowshoeing the flat road to the big rock, where we settled down for a beer and watched the water. Absolutely gorgeous. Road leading to eight mile is quite slushy and could be problematic if you have a wide vehicle or anything less than high clearance.

column8:
Deer Park Missile Site Trails —
              Jan. 21, 2024 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report.2024-01-21.2296240135)
column51:
Deer Park Missile Site Trails —
              Feb. 19, 2024 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report.2024-02-20.9139070761)
column60: Beautiful secluded trail network great for winter hiking. Should have worn snowshoes but made it (with frozen feet) in boots alone. Saw three elk (or moose, was too far away from them to discern) in the middle of it. Only one other person and his two dogs were on the trail. Will have to go back when there's a little more snow to do some snowshoeing.
