The road to the trailhead is in excellent shape and suitable for all vehicles. HEATHER LAKE The trail up to Heather Lake is also in great shape, with only a couple of recent windfalls across the trail. Most of the streams that cross the trail along the way still had flowing water, so our dog was able to stay hydrated and relatively cool in the heat. Although the trail description mentions that this is a popular trail with families, we thought that the long hike through forest, without any views, combined with the long, steep climb in the second half of the hike, might not be the best option for getting children excited about hiking and backpacking. This is not an easy or particularly exciting hike. We enjoyed a long lunch break on the rocks at the northeast end of Heather Lake, where the official trail ends. The view down the lake is relaxing (see photo) and some lovely camping spots are clustered here. GLASSES LAKE After our lunch break, we set off to find Glasses Lake. Crossing the log jam at the outlet to Heather Lake was easy, and we had no trouble finding the beginning of the use trail along the southeast shore. We followed this faint, overgrown trail all the way to its end at the southeast end of Heather Lake. The trail was at times difficult to discern under the pervasive blanket of huckleberries, and was often blocked and obscured by windfalls across and along the trail. It roughly follows a contour above the lake, providing pee-a-boo lake views but only two possible access points down to the lakeshore. We did find footprints of a previous hiker in one spot, so apparently other hikers are using this trail, but it is clearly not used often. At the end of the lake, the trail ends at a lovely campsite across the outlet of the stream coming down from Grizzly Peak. Here there is access to the lake and a potential fishing spot. On the way to the end of the trail, we had missed the turn-off to Glasses Lake. After some searching, we found it on the way back. It is exactly as described in the trail description: immediately after an old “No Campfires” sign which is quite conspicuous from the trail. There is also an old blaze on a tree to the left of the trail (uphill) just before you come to the sign. Unfortunately, this is more visible from the southern side than it is as you come along the trail from the north. The trail to Glasses Lake heads uphill (southeast), perpendicular to the trail along Heather Lake. It is very difficult to discern at the junction, being almost completely disguised by rampant huckleberry bushes. Throughout its length it is even fainter, more overgrown, and more blocked by deadfalls than the trail along Heather Lake. Without maintenance, it seems unlikely to remain discernable for many more seasons. It is a steep, uphill grind, with several short sections that qualify as scrambles requiring hands as well as feet. Even our game and agile dog required help scaling a couple of these steep sections. We found only one flag and one blaze along the way. The trail is in forest almost all the way. About a quarter mile from Glasses Lake, it tops a small plateau and ambles a short distance through a subalpine clearing, with a lovely stream meandering through. Unfortunately, this idyllic interlude is short-lived. After a couple of hundred yards the trail re-enters the forest and heads abruptly uphill again, through a mass of fallen trunks and branches and up through a steep rock crevasse, before finally topping the ridge and affording a welcome view of Glasses Lake. A few more strides brought us to the lakeshore and the end of the trail (see photo). The lake is lovely, but there is very little access to the weedy shoreline. We managed to find a small, semi-dry spot, just large enough for the two of us to sit and enjoy a welcome break and snack. As far as we could tell, there are no camping spots anywhere between Heather and Glasses Lake, and no place to camp at the latter. OVERALL Throughout most of the day, we had little problem with mosquitoes or flies as long as we kept moving. Biting flies were peskier than mosquitoes, especially around the lakes. An onshore breeze helped keep them at bay during our lunch break at Heather Lake. However, our break at Glasses Lake was cut short by swarms of flies that seemed undeterred by our insect repellent. This is not a wildflower hike. We spotted a few blooms along the way, but mainly the understory is a carpet of huckleberries. Unfortunately, none of these had flowers or berries, even unripe ones. Perhaps it is a bad huckleberry year. Overall, we felt that this had been a good choice for a blistering hot, sunny August day. We loved the total solitude and the adventure of making it up to Glasses Lake. However, compared to many other hikes in the Cascades, I would say the reward for effort of this trail is low, especially if you include the extension to Glasses Lake.

column8:
Kalaloch Creek Nature Trail, Kalaloch - Browns Point —
              Jul. 17, 2024 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2024-07-17.195114623794)
column60: I visited the coast for a couple of days to dodge the heat as well as do some sightseeing and hiking. Yesterday I combined a walk up Kalaloch Beach from the lodge to the Tree of Life, then up and through the campsite to the Kalaloch Creek Nature Trail loop on the other side of Highway 101 and then back again. Total elevation gain was minimal, maybe 100 feet, with a combined distance of about three miles. The trip up the beach was in sunny weather, but with the ocean mist constantly rolling in. I timed it for when the tide was receding and donned sand shoes for this section, and after checking out the Tree of Life (located on the beach) and reaching the campsite I washed off my feet and put on proper hiking boots. The trailhead to the nature trail wasn't too hard to find, but crossing the highway made me feel like I was Frogger. The trail itself was just a short one-mile loop through a stand of old trees, and most of the big ones were missing their tops. There was one fallen Redwood snag that blocked the trail and had to be clumsily climbed over. Overall it's a pretty trail but I definitely wouldn't bother driving all the way out here just for it. Combine it with other hikes/walks in the area. Then today I checked out the beach area once again before driving back, and at low tide I spotted three otters playing in the surf. A pretty good way to cap off what was a very satisfying couple of days exploring the area.
column98: Hiking Kalaloch Creek Nature Trail If the tide is high, or you just want to see a different side of the Olympic Peninsula while you're visiting the coast, cross Highway 101 from the Kalaloch campground and take a peek into the deep Olympic forest. The wide and wet Kalaloch Nature Trail provides a quiet forested walk on a well-maintained trail, thanks in part to WTA volunteer crews, who visit this area each year to improve sections of this trail, trying to keep the eternal rains of the Peninsula from damaging it too much. From the parking area for the Kalaloch Campground, walk south to campground A. A sign points left (east) indicating the Kalaloch Nature Trail. Straight ahead, a service road continues through a gate. This trail leads to the Kalaloch store and is a convenient connector if you're camping in the park, but for now, take the trail branching left. Walk to the edge of Highway 101 and cross, being sure that there's no oncoming traffic. Remember, this is a US Highway, so cars will be moving very fast. Once safely across, immediately plunge into deep forest. The nature trail here is wide, but the forest all around is all-encompassing. Trees grow huge and gnarled, draped with thick moss. Skunk cabbage blooms early, lighting up the forest floor with its bright yellow leaf and pungent odor. The trail itself can be boggy -- despite WTA efforts, sections remain where puddles do form after periods of heavy rain. Push through these, across a log bridge, and down a set of steps. You'll continue walking among the giants of the forests, on a generally southerly trajectory, before arriving at a viewpoint of Kalaloch Creek. Foliage obscures the best views, but marvel at this large freshwater tributary feeding into the Pacific Ocean before turning back on the trail and heading north, away from the creek and through the forest, back to the trailhead. The gravel in this section was spread by WTA crews, encouraging drainage of water from the trail and a more secure footing for hikers. WTA worked here in 2015, 2014 and 2012! Hike Description Written by Anna Roth , WTA Correspondent
column106: Was high tide and needed to kill time until the beach hikes were accessible. This hike was a pleasant surprise. Vibrant green all around. Creeks and streams gurgling along the way. No one else the entire hike. Great hike for the whole family.

column8:
Salmo-Priest Loop, Shedroof Divide, Hall - Grassy Divide, Noisy Creek —
              Sep. 26, 2021 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2021-09-27-1319474491)
column51:
Grassy Top, Hall - Grassy Divide —
              Jul. 10, 2022 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report.2022-07-10.2165037946)
column60: I came up with this hike idea when other weekend plans were cancelled, and fortunately I have one friend who is just as nutty as me who was willing to give this route a shot. This is admittedly a crazy idea as a day hike, but it could easily be transformed into a multi-day backpack trip. We met at the Noisy Creeek TH late in the afternoon on Saturday & dropped off my car. Then we carpooled in my friend's car to the Salmo Loop TH, ate dinner, and slept for a few hours. We knew this route would take more hours then there was daylight available, so we were up & on-trail by 4am on Sunday morning. The route starts by dropping into the Salmo Basin, all of which we experienced by headlamp. Even so, the many mushrooms along the side of the trail were spectacular! I've hiked this trail on numerous previous occasions, but if anyone plans to re-create this route & has not seen the Basin in daylight, don't start so early as the forest is also beautiful. We were within a couple miles of the Shedroof Divide by the time the sun came up, and stopped at the last water source for our first real break of the hike so we could top off water bottles for the long dry section ahead. The fall colors are fantastic in the upper reaches of the Basin trail, and especially along the Shedroof Divide. The larch haven't really started to turn yet, so this one will continue to offer great fall colors until snow prevents access. We didn't need the water break at the camp below Cabinet Pass, but did stop again at the source just before the Salmo Divide junction. There were small water sources available at seeps along the trail near Thunder Mountain, and we stopped for another fill-up just past the junction with Thunder Creek & Jackson Creek. The hike up the steep switchbacks at Helmer was interrupted by several "tourist stops" to take in the colors on the burned landscape, all crimson & gold. The fatigue of all the miles started to hit us around Pass Creek Pass, where we stopped for a snack break & had a hard time standing up and walking again! But again, this section was beautiful and all of the fall colors offered a good distraction from sore muscles. Sunset on the Hall-Grassy Divide was spectacular! We didn't really start to suffer from this crazy hike until the sun went down. The lower portion of the trail has experienced several burns in recent years, so my usual landmarks to help me judge distance were impossible to pick out. It really wasn't until the last 7 miles that I struggled, but not enough for me to consider stopping early. We exited the Noisy Creek trail just a little after 9pm. Total distance was 43.16 miles with about 7500' elevation gain. The route is within the Salmo Priest Wilderness from the TH to Pass Creek Pass. A large portion of this route is also a segment of the Pacific Northwest Trail. It's a very easy route to shuttle, and could even be made a little longer by ending at the north end of Sullivan Lake.
column98: Hiking Hall - Grassy Divide This long ridge route gives hikers big views in all directions and also serves as a connector to enable big loop opportunities with other nearby trails. Since this trail is not accessible by vehicle as a stand-alone hike, hikers must choose which feeder trail best suits their access needs. There are three different trailheads that grant access to the Hall — Grassy Divide trail, which serves as a connector trail between Noisy Creek and Hall Mountain to the west and Grassy Top trail to the east. For the easiest road access to the Hall — Grassy Divide, start at the Noisy Creek trailhead at the south end of Sullivan Lake, located on the edge of the popular Noisy Creek campground. A small trailhead just off the pavement provides hiker parking for the Noisy Creek trail. This trail ascends 5.3 miles one-way to its intersection with both Hall — Grassy Divide and Hall Mountain Summit trail. Turn east at the junction to continue on the Hall — Grassy Divide. For less overall elevation gain compared to the Noisy Creek trail access, hikers may choose to start their hike at the Johns Creek trailhead for Hall Mountain Trail 540. Please note that Johns Creek is only open to motorized vehicles between July 10-August 14 each summer and is best suited to high-clearance vehicles. The Hall Mountain trail from Johns Creek comes to a junction with both the Hall — Grassy Divide and Noisy Creek Trail after a mere 0.7 miles. Hikers who come from either starting trailhead will want to consider tacking on the additional 1.8 miles one-way to ascend to the summit of Hall Mountain. The third trailhead access for the Hall — Grassy Divide is located at Pass Creek Pass, the start of the trail to Grassy Top . This longer approach via rough Forest Service Road is best for high-clearance vehicles. Start on the Grassy Top trail, which intersects the Hall — Grassy Divide after 2.7 miles (consider continuing 1.1 miles one-way to the summit of Grassy Top before proceeding). The Hall — Grassy Divide itself is about 5 miles one-way, opening up many possibilities for overnight and multi-day trips on the Sullivan Lake Ranger District. The trail crosses through forested areas and also includes wildflower-filled alpine meadows. A portion of the trail has been impacted by two major wildfires in recent years, leading to sections with big views but little shade, and downfall trees may be an obstacle to contend with both early season and following windstorms. The only drawback is that there is no access to water along this trail, so be sure to carry enough to hike through, or plan campsites along the Noisy Creek and Grassy Top feeder trails. Toilet Information No toilet at trailhead More information about toilets Hike Description Written by Holly Weiler, WTA Correspondent
column106: I hiked to the Northwest summit of Grassy Top which is right above the Hall-Grassy junction at the 2.7 mile point. The summit requires some bushwhacking the final 300’ gained in about .25 of a mile after leaving the trail but in mostly open forest with huckleberry understory which later give way to meadows. The best approach is to walk for a few hundred yards toward Hall Mtn until reaching a small meadow on the southwest side of the NW Grassy Top summit and walk through forest for a short distance to more open meadows. I had not studied satellite images sufficiently and took a more direct route from the southeast. Though shorter, this route required more bushwhacking and I only noticed the better approach after the fact. The trail has been logged out from Pass Creek Pass and is in good condition other than a few minor brushy areas. The PNTA trail crew has been hard at work on this section and it shows.

column60: I hiked from the trailhead on the Snake River at 780' to the top of the canyon to check out the upper reaches of the trail. The hike begins on an old jeep road which becomes a single track after about a mile. Eventually, it is more of a game trail but still relatively easy to follow. After 2.5 miles one arrives to a fence line at the top of the canyon with posting indicating the end of public land where Palouse farmland begins. 5 miles RT with 1,800' of gain. Nice, mostly snow-free hike for the winter months.
column98: Hiking Nisqually John Canyon This is a US Army Corps of Engineers Wildlife Management Unit located on the Snake River northwest of Clarkston and south of Pullman. It's a canyon hike that goes up about 2.5 miles before topping out to Palouse wheat fields. The adventurous hiker can explore several side canyons for multiple trips in this area.
column106: A friend and I hiked this trail for the first time on a rainy Sunday. While there was no snow at this elevation, the trail was muddy in many places, which made it difficult to navigate. The trail starts on an old jeep road that lasts less than a quarter of a mile. At this point, there is a swampy mud pit (about 10-20 yards of this). Someone brought planks to make crossing it easier, but we still had difficulty staying out of the mud. Walking around it is difficult because the surrounding blackberry bushes offer nothing to hold. The trail is relatively easy to follow beyond this but is overgrown in many places. At higher elevations, we saw a few cows, basalt formations, and several groves of trees growing along the stream below. We turned around after about 1.75 miles because the trail got extremely precarious with mud and steep slopes. The trail became unclear after the stream crossing where we turned around. We were the only people on the trail, but there was evidence of hunting/other recreation. We saw fresh boot prints and horse prints (as well as horse and cow poop). This trail seems like it would be better in the late spring/early summer after the mud has dried a bit. As it was, it wasn't a bad winter hike, and snow was not an issue.

column8:
Silver Creek, Crystal Mountain Loop (Silver King) —
              Aug. 9, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-08-10.123656584084)
column51:
Silver Creek, Pacific Crest Trail (PCT) Section I - White Pass to Snoqualmie Pass, Crystal Lakes —
              Aug. 29, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-08-30.101244647116)
column60: On Saturday we hiked from the parking lot at Crystal Mt (ski resort) via the Silver Creek trail to the summit of Crystal Mountain. We met our group at 7:30am and caught the trail on the East side of the parking lot. The group was doing an Everesting challenge, seeking to hike up and down a number of times over a long weekend to reach the height of Mt. Everest, in elevation gain.  We only came for Saturday as we had other engagements, AND having already reached over 29k in elevation from prior hikes, felt no pressure to hike up more than once. We have never hiked here so it was a great opportunity to check it out. This hike provides forest, meadows, lakes, wildflowers, wildlife and big mountain views from the top (Mt St Helens, Mt Adams, Goat Rocks, and of course Mt Rainier). Starting temp was in the mid-forties but we warmed quickly as we climbed up hill through the shaded forest.  We crossed a few small streams passed a lake and a couple of small tarns. There are still some wildflowers but mostly past prime.  As we gained elevation and were out of the tree cover things opened up and we were treated to huckleberries, more flowers and 5 playful marmots higher up on the trail. We saw elk tracks and bear scat but no elk or bear were seen.  We did not see any other hikers until we reached the summit where they were off loading from the gondola and hiking downhill. We arrived at the summit in just under 2 hours. ~5 miles, ~2500 eg. The staff was setting up for a wedding next to the gondola platform, and we were informed there was an event that evening "Summit Fest". Tickets were apparently sold out, so there was no option for us to attend. Of our group of 7, two showed up shortly after us, 1 took an extended hike (run) up some adjacent ridges to find their way back to the trail and show up 5 or 10 minutes later.  Those 3 took the gondola down to join another group who was starting up at 10:30am.  We stayed at the summit to wait for our 2 remaining hikers who took a more leisurely approach to the trek appearing at the summit 3 hours later. The 3-hour wait at the summit went by quickly. The air was a little chilly at first but the sun was warming things up quickly. There were great views to soak in and decent people watching.  There were quite a few dogs, all well behaved and on leash. 2 Other friends rode the gondola up and joined us to cheer on the final two hikers when they arrived. Once the rest of our crew arrived we took the gondola back to the parking lot, and set out to find something to eat.  Great day, great conditions and great company.
column98: Hiking Silver Creek
column106: This is the rear door entrance to Crystal Lakes without hiking to Sheep Lake with the large number of fellow travelers. We start out at the Crystal Mt. parking lot and take the new Crystal Mt. Trail to the Silver Creek Trail. In about 2.5 miles you hit the PCT. Go right and in about 1.5 miles you go right at the intersection just below Sourdough Gap to MRNP. You enter above Crystal Lake. Find a good viewing spot and watch the tiny hikers below scurry around the lake. You have a great view of Crystal Peak and can usually see someone up there. We also have a great view of one of our favorite hikes Brown Peak to Slide Mt. and of course all the surrounding landscape. The one defining part of this hike is the never ending view of trees. Dense forest the go on endlessly with a lake only accessed by animals. Number of people met. It is nearing the end of the season for though hikers. We met 16 on this short stretch. Guessing they all camped in about the same spot. The one comment we heard and have heard before, this is our favorite part of the whole hike, but then, we knew that to be the case. One person from the lake joined us on top and we met one person on the Silver Creek Trail. Pretty much except for the through hikers we met in about a one mile stretch of the PCT, we were alone on a Friday before a holiday.

column98: Hiking Shoeffler Butte-Heyburn State Park This trail in Idaho’s Heyburn State Park starts off on a remnant of a historic wagon road, then winds through ponderosa pine forests to top out on Shoeffler Butte. The trail starts off on the historic Mullan Road and climbs a little under a mile to the official start of the Shoeffler Butte Trail. As you climb, you’ll get occasional views of the south end of Lake Coeur d’Alene. The Trail of the Coeur d’Alenes, a 70-mile multi-use path popular with cyclists, runs close to the start of this trail, creating the opportunity for a bike-and-hike, or a continuation of your hike. Hike Description Written by Multiple authors contributed to this report, WTA Community
column106: Heyburn SP in North Idaho is the oldest state park in the PNW dating back to 1908. The trail up Shoeffler Butte is part of The Mullan Road which was built by the military between 1859 and 1862 under the command of Capt John Mullan and was an early wagon route over the Rocky Mtns to the Pacific Northwest. This section of road south of Lake Coeur d’Alene, completed in 1859, quickly proved impractical because of flooding and bogs in the St. Joe Valley. This portion of road was abandoned in 1862 after a new section over Fourth of July Pass was built, roughly paralleling today’s Interstate 90. Importance of Mullan Road diminished after rail lines were constructed in 1880s. The road was abandoned after completion of an automobile highway in 1916. Nowadays it's a hiking trail leading to the summit of Shoeffler Butte, 3320' which leaves from the lakeside picnic shelters below Chatcolet Campground. The campground is closed but I parked outside the gate and walked to the trailhead signed "Mullan Road" between sites 113 and 115. The trail starts off steeply and climbs 1086' in 1.25 miles to the summit. Views are somewhat limited by forest but there are some nice peak-a-boo views of the southern end of Lake Coeur d'Alene along the way. Access: From U.S. Highway 95 at Plummer, Idaho, drive 6-1/2 miles east on State Highway 5 and turn north at well-signed road toward Chatcolet (between mileposts 6 and 7). Follow paved road north nearly 2 miles - passing Hawleys Landing campground, Plummer Point picnic area and Heyburn State Park headquarters - to Y. Bear right to reach lower trailhead at picnic area. Bear left to reach trailhead at Chatcolet campground.

column51:
Roosevelt Grove of Ancient Cedars, Roosevelt Trail #266 to Little Grass Mountain —
              Oct. 19, 2021 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2021-10-21-4322979134)
column55: Roosevelt Trail to Little Grass Mountain
column98: Hiking Roosevelt Trail to Little Grass Mountain This trailhead is across the road from the parking area for The Roosevelt Grove of Ancient Cedars at Stagger Inn Day Use Area north of Nordman, Idaho. The hike begins in Washington but crosses into Idaho at about the 3-mile mark. The trail is well-maintained for approximately 3.5 miles then becomes a bit of an obstacle course with fallen trees and brush to negotiate. You'll have to pay attention at times and backtrack when necessary. Though some maps show a trail branching off to the left going directly up the ridge to the summit, no such trail exists. It also shows trail 266 abruptly ending on the south slope, but it in fact continues all the way to the saddle between Little Grass and Boulder Mountain. There are some very nice groves of old-growth cedar along the way and evidence of ancient fires with giant burned-out snags. Several water sources exist throughout the hike. The trail passes a junction to the south and continues north up to another spur east of the summit which goes to the top. If you arrive to an old road bed, you have gone too far. This is the eastern terminus of 266 and an old sign nailed to a tree marks the trail. Turn back and find the spur to the top which is well flagged. The summit spur is easy enough to follow but becomes vague near the top. From here it is feasible to walk open meadows to the old lookout site at 5696 feet. Hike Description Written by Multiple authors contributed to this report, WTA Community
column106: The trailhead for Trail #266 (Roosevelt Trail) is across the road from the parking area for The Roosevelt Grove of Ancient Cedars at Stagger Inn Day Use Area north of Nordman, Idaho. The hike begins in Washington but crosses into Idaho at about the 3-mile mark. The trail is well-maintained for approximately 3.5 miles then becomes a bit of an obstacle course with fallen trees and brush to negotiate. Bring along a saw or loppers to help this trail! The tread in the upper section is still easy to follow but you'll have to pay attention at times and backtrack when necessary. Though some maps show a trail branching off to the left going directly up the ridge to the summit, no such trail exists. It also shows trail 266 abruptly ending on the south slope, but it in fact continues all the way to the saddle between Little Grass and Boulder Mtn. There are some very nice groves of old growth cedar along the way and evidence of ancient fires with giant burned out snags. Several water sources exist throughout the hike. The trail passes a junction to the south and continues north up to another spur east of the summit which goes to the top. If you arrive to an old road bed, you have gone too far. This is the eastern terminus of 266 and an old sign nailed to a tree marks the trail. This road is permanently gated many miles below so is not an option for a shortcut. Turn back and find the spur to the top which is well flagged. The summit spur is easy enough to follow but becomes vague near the top. From here it is feasible to walk open meadows to the old lookout site at 5696.' The entire hike is 11.4 miles round trip with 2400' of gain. A link with GPS tracks is included.

column8:
Beebe Springs Wildlife Area - Cultus Jim and Chelan Bob Loop —
              Feb. 21, 2024 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report.2024-02-21.0424240295)
column51:
Beebe Springs Wildlife Area - Cultus Jim and Chelan Bob Loop —
              Jul. 22, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-08-07.044557551793)
column55: Beebe Springs Wildlife Area - Cultus Jim and Chelan Bob Loop
column60: As we’ve all been experiencing, snow is not there and temperatures are higher than normal. We thought we would look for greenery or early spring flowers in the Columbia River Basin. The hike was in great shape and the views wonderful. There were however no flowers out yet. Many plants had green basal leaves going but not much else. We saw evidence of big horn sheep, poop and tracks, but no sheep themselves.
column98: Hiking Beebe Springs Wildlife Area - Cultus Jim and Chelan Bob Loop Walk through a rocky, desert landscape with expansive views of the Columbia River. These trails are short and well built with rock steps for stable footing. This loop trail system may be started at either the Chelan Hatchery or at the loop’s top just off Highway 150 on the way into Chelan. Parking at the fish hatchery allows for the muscles to get warmed up before tackling the numerous stairs and switchbacks crafted into the hillside. Begin the counterclockwise loop by first walking north through the Chelan Fish Hatchery operated by the Washington Fish and Wildlife Department. Once past the hatchery a wide, level gravel trail is reached. After a short distance you’ll reach a fork in the gravel trail. The Cultus Jim trail is signed and will turn off to the right. At this point the trail becomes a single-track path winding through mature sagebrush steppe. The trail now begins to ascend in earnest up a narrow break in the cliff bands. Expertly laid native rocks make for an easy tread. In season the cliff walls echo with the descending scales of a canyon wren. Spring flowers carpet the hillside. At the top of this climb a brief gravel road walk takes you to the upper parking area. Bearing towards the left at this parking area you will find the Chelan Bob trail, first ascending a bit more, then ultimately descending back to your car. Steep cliffs with magnificent views of the Columbia River, McNeil Canyon and the Waterville Plateau stretch out below. In winter Beebe Springs freezes into a large cascade across these rocks. Pay attention to the main trail as several social paths may lead you astray. Rock steps once again make the trail much less gravelly and easier for the descent. At a junction with the Toad Creek Loop, stay right to return to the hatchery grounds to find your car. (The Toad Creek Loop is a nice shorter, flatter hike option in this same trail network.) Take a moment to consider the hatchery where hundreds of thousands of smolts and frys are reared every year before going into the Columbia River and alpine lakes. The state of Washington has done extensive work in the area, including across highway 97 alongside the river, restoring native plants and wildlife habitat. Though it is hard to get away from the noise and visuals of industry and the highway, there is still a strong influx of migrating birds, a bighorn family, and much other wildlife. Owing to the diverse ecosystems found here (shrub Steppe, riparian, and grasslands) the birding is excellent. Tribute is due to the namesakes of these trails. Chelan Bob and Cultus Jim were members of the Chelan Tribe. In the late nineteenth century these men refused moving to the Colville Reservation and instead took allotments of land offered by the Federal Government through the Dawes Act. These men and their families lived in the lower Chelan Lake area all their lives. Hike Description Written by Austin Smith , WTA Correspondent
column106: Beautiful and fun hike! We had a good time with two little kids, who enjoyed climbing the stairs and seeing the big views as we ascended. Definitely watch your step as the trail gets a bit narrow and steep, but it’s a quick one with a good payoff. Bonus — hatchery staff let us feed some fry as we headed to the trailhead from the parking lot!

column60: One of my favorite hikes.
column98: Hiking Raging River Natural Area This King County park is located on the eastern shore of the Raging River, just north of Preston. Arrive at the small parking area after crossing a historic bridge over the Raging River and head out on the trail. This area is managed primarily as important riparian habitat, but there are a couple short trails, one heading into the upland portion of the property and the other following along the river. Depending on the water level, this lower trail may hit a submerged dead end shortly. Similarly, the upland trail may be overgrown or muddy depending on when maintenance has occurred. The Raging River is a salmon spawning stream. This park is located a couple miles south from where the Raging flows into the Snoqualmie, and then eventually to the Puget Sound. For some other nearby trails, the Preston-Snoqualmie Trail passes within a couple hundred feet of this trailhead.  And just up the road toward Preston sits the Preston Mill Property which is now a park managed by King County. Hike Description Written by Charlie Wakenshaw, WTA Staff
column106: Today's outing was part of an advanced navigation course with the Foothill Branch of the Mountaineers. The area we practiced in is DNR territory and needs a permit to access, so I'm not sure how useful this trip report will be to most people. We had a little of everything: wind, snow, rain, sun, and lots of blackberry vines tripping people. We arrived in two waves of students and instructors so everyone could have private instruction time and more realistic practice scenarios. Our field trip lasted from 8:30 (first wave) to 3:45 (last wave leaving). The approach road (4-5 miles) is pretty rutted (we carpooled) and entry off Highway 18 is pretty nasty coming from Seattle - I hate blocking traffic and a left hand turn with northbound 18 traffic took at least 10-12 cars. Not an intersection I'll visit again. Once we got started, we had an engaging number of scenarios that gave us practice with map and compass, taking bearings, routefinding through dense forest, inchworming and leapfrogging (perhaps my favorite practice), and then shifting to Gaia use, finally ending with navigation by compass only. Two members in my party of 7 fell and a third almost fell; the co-leader opted out of the bushwhacking half of the day. Kind of a gnarly trip, all things considered, from weather to tech to terrain. But our group was amazing, our instructor stalwart and supportive, and to end the day we had a few sunbreaks. The takeaways were 1) be smart choosing gear, 2) never rely on Gaia if your phone is not the newest version, and 3) old-school map and compass remain the way to go, at least for me. The class didn't convert me! Despite the problems, though, the people made the day, especially my navigation partner who also drove the rutted road. There were no facilities anywhere (thanks, trees!) and nobody else up there except our field trip group. On the day only five bird species; I'd expected more but maybe the recent snowfall dimmed their song.

column8:
Dishman Hills Conservation Area - Flying L Trail —
              May. 17, 2022 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2022-05-18-0999006890)
column51:
Dishman Hills Conservation Area - Flying L Trail —
              May. 10, 2023 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report.2023-05-12.7427817491)
column55: Dishman Hills Conservation Area - Flying L Trail
column60: Arrived at 9 AM at the Phillips Creek Trailhead parking lot, took the Inside Passage turn and finished up at about 10:45 AM. It's a beautiful, mellow hike with sweeping views, meadows, ponderosa pines, old orchard trees and cottonwoods. Arrowleaf Balsamroot, western serviceberry and other wildflowers are blooming. I was fortunate to hike with one of the key volunteers involved in building this trail, local expert Chris Baldini. The trail is in great shape, and we saw a handful of other hikers, all smiles. Grateful for the Conservation Futures Program. A wonderful addition to Dishman Hills and a great legacy for the Phillips family - thank you!
column98: Hiking Dishman Hills Conservation Area - Flying L Trail The 2018 Spokane County Parks acquisition of the 179-acre former “Flying L Ranch” dairy farm and subsequent development of connecting trails have greatly expanded the options within the greater Glenrose Unit (also known as “The Cliffs”) of the Dishman Hills Conservation Area. Starting in the Ponderosa neighborhood in the south Spokane Valley, trail options include the 2.2-mile Flying L trail, which climbs from the parking area and traverses a Ponderosa pine forest before breaking out into an open hillside, flanked along its lower reaches by an old apple orchard and a small year-round stream. Located on the right and just past the stream, the Inside Passage trail junction expands the trail options. Visitors can choose to remain on the Flying L trail, which eventually connects to the main Glenrose Trail, or turn north on the Inside Passage trail leading toward The Cliffs trail (named after the area itself). Since The Cliffs trail also connects to the main Glenrose Trail, it is additionally possible to hike a loop instead of an out-and-back. The The Cliffs trail leading north from the Inside Passage and Glenrose intersection was formerly a lollipop loop with an impressive view overlooking the Spokane Valley, but — due to the recent Dishman Hills Conservancy acquisition of the Keystone Property, purchased in early 2025 — there is now a critical public corridor and trail connection with the Dishman Hills Natural Area. It is important to note that the trail corridor is narrow, with private property located on either side. Please respect adjacent private property owners by staying on trail. Additionally, the natural area is a hiker-only trail system (dogs are permitted on leash, but neither bikes nor horses are permitted within the natural area). The area is perhaps best for its spring wildflower displays, although it is accessible year-round and has something beautiful to offer in all seasons. Additional trails are also on the horizon, as Spokane County Parks recently acquired a private parcel located between the Flying L Ranch and the Cliffs. A new connecting trail is expected by late 2025. WTA worked here in 2020! Hike Description Written by Holly Weiler, WTA Correspondent
column106: I love this trail system and everything is so green right now. Fruit trees are budding and the wildflowers are blooming. My group and I set out on the Flying L trail and took it to the Glenrose unit. Hiked the old road/trail to the Inside Passage trail and followed it down to Flying L to make a 4 1/2 mile loop back to trailhead.

column8:
Green Mountain - Davis Trail, Green Mountain - Tin Mine Trail —
              Dec. 21, 2024 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2024-12-21.183709736330)
column51:
Green Mountain - Tin Mine Trail, Green Mountain - Davis Trail —
              Jan. 17, 2026 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2026-01-25.110821416561)
column60: Did a counter-clockwise loop at Green Mountain. There were surprisingly a lot of cars in the Gold Creek lot on this rainy day. We parked on the trailer side. The facility was open and stocked, but the door doesn't close all the way. We donned full raingear then headed up the Tin Mine Trail and immediately found mud and water on the trail. That would be the theme today. Up to the connector, there was water running down the trail and erosion down the center. Once we broke out into the open, the rain and wind pelted us, and made us glad we geared up. Climbing was more arduous with pants on and I started getting warm, but the wind kept my overheating in check. Ran across the only person we'd see this day, just before heading back into the trees and downhill. I don't know who was more surprised! The first half the descent to the mine was wet. Water ran down the trail up to 1.5 inches deep, pretty much full-width. At some point the trail relative to the hillside changed and water ran under the trail through culverts. We found the mine entrance and knew we wouldn't be exploring too far in as we didn't feel like digging out headlamps and the footing was sketchy as floating branches littered the way as a means to stay out of the water. Not real functional today. We went in about 15 feet then called it good. By this time the rain had diminished and there was no wind to speak of in this area. Looped around a few little lakes then headed back via Davis Trail, which was a wide flat thoroughfare on the other side of the wetlands area. More wind in this side and evidence of previous blowdowns, but we had no obstacles at all to deal with today. Took the connector back to our side  of the lot - this was the wettest section of trail today. Lots of mud too. I did manage to keep my feet dry despite all the water.
column98: Hiking Green Mountain - Davis Trail This trail is in Green Mountain State Forest, a dynamic working forest that is certainly a land of many uses. The trails are open to hikers, mountain bikers and horseback riders. Logging operations happen occasionally and can cause trail closures or reroutes. A couple different trails leave from this trailhead. You want the one immediately to the left as you drive into the parking area. Start out on this trail (the Gold Creek Trail) for a little under half a mile before coming to the first junction. Stay straight for another tenth of a mile to the second junction. Going left will take you on a journey to the top of Green Mountain . Stay straight to get on the Davis Trail. Once on the Davis Trail you will roughly parallel Gold Creek on a mostly flat route for 1.5 additional miles until the trail ends at a logging road. You can either turn around and head back on the same trail or devise a different route, combining logging roads and other trails in the forest. Just be sure to have a good map since all the intersecting roads and trails here can get confusing. Hike Description Written by Multiple authors contributed to this report, WTA Community
column106: Trail clear and well maintained. Took tin mine up past the mine and continued back on Davis trail. Only one down tree but it was easy to crawl under. Great hike with a 4-year old.

column8:
Vancouver Discovery Historic Loop, Columbia River Renaissance Trail —
              Aug. 13, 2023 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report.2023-08-13.6202206068)
column60: We began at Fort Vancouver, headed West to Vancouver's Farmer's Market then to the waterfront.  It was early enough that it was still cool and uncrowded.  We turned back, East along the waterfront and continued along the Columbia River to the Eastern terminus at Wintler Park. Not yet crowded, but with the forecast for the upper 90s it will certainly be packed shortly. We returned the way we came, along the river until the land bridge where we headed North across the bridge over Highway 14 to Fort Vancouver.  We checked out the garden at the Fort which is always impressive (especially compared to ours).  From the Fort, we headed East toward Pearson Airport then up though Officers Row. and looped back down to the Fort. Both of these trails can be accessed from different point for a shorter circuit or various out and back walks.  The paths are paved and in good condition.
column98: Hiking Columbia River Renaissance Trail The trail parallels the Columbia River, linking together several parks, public spaces and historic sites, and passing shops and restaurants at the Vancouver Waterfront and Columbia Shores. It offers sweeping views of the Columbia River and Mount Hood in the distance and a sandy public beach at the east end. You can spend all day walking this combination of sidewalks and paved trails round trip, or t here are numerous access points that allow shorter hikes. The trail is anchored on the east end by Wintler Community Park, a 12.5-acre park with a sandy beach, picnic tables and restrooms open April-October. A $5 parking fee is collected between Memorial Day and Labor Day. Start your hike at the beach or find the trail at the west end of the parking area. From Wintler Park, walk along the edge of a riparian cottonwood forest and in .3 mile, reach the large Tidewater Cove development that includes offices, condominiums and a marina. A short side trip on the marina breakwater leads to views of Mount Hood rising above the Glenn Jackson (I-205) Bridge. In winter, this is a prime birding spot. Beyond Tidewater Cove, the trail goes inland to bypass a wetland. At 1.2 miles, pass the Water Resource s Education Center across the street, which has restrooms, drinking fountains and educational exhibits that are good for kids. Check their website for opening hours and events. The trail then enters 58-acre Marine Park, with picnic tables, playground, flush restrooms open April-October, and drinking fountains. There is no parking fee. Reach 1.5 miles at the park entrance sign. Another side trip is to walk .5 mile down Marine Park Way to the boat launch ($5 parking fee year round) and the Kaiser Viewing Tower. Interpretive exhibits highlight the role of the Kaiser Shipyards during WW II. Return to Marine Park. From Marine Park, the trail continues 1.2 miles on a sidewalk along SE Columbia Way past the industrial Columbia Business Park, former home of the Kaiser Shipyards. Turn south for .2 mile along SE Columbia Shores B lvd. and resume the waterfront trail. Turn left to a dmire the Wendy Rose s tatue which commemorates the women who worked at the Kaiser Shipyards during WW II. Then turn around to continue west past several restaurants. Pass the Princess Ilchee s tatue next to a residential area . In .4 mile (3.5 miles from start), the trail becomes a long boulevard lined with cottonwoods. This is one of the most heavily used segments of trail so stay alert for cyclists, skaters, skateboarders, and other conveyances. In .75 mile, enter 5-acre Fort Vancouver Waterfront Park with benches, picnic tables and viewing platforms. This is a good spot to view the I-5 Bridge. Free parking. Pass a couple of restaurants slated for redevelopment and walk under the I-5 Bridge to t he Captain George Vancouver Monument Plaza which features Jay Rood's 1992 sculpture “Boat of Discovery” and interpretive panels about the European “discovery” of the northwest coast of North America. A t the next intersection, turn left on Columbia Way to visit the new Vancouver Waterfront Park, part of a 35-acre mixed use urban development on a former mill site. T he park includes the iconic cable-stayed Grant Street Pier, which juts 90 feet out over the river, benches, a picnic area, flush toilet restrooms, drinking fountain, a water feature, and a play area with salmon sculptures, sandy upland beach and netclimber. The west end of the trail terminates at Columbia Way. On-street, metered parking and private pay parking lots are available. Alternative Route : From the Captain George Vancouver Monument Plaza, continue walking north along Columbia Street for .25 mile to Esther Short Park established in 1853, the oldest public park in Washington. Check out the Salmon Run Bell Tower with a glockenspiel depicting a Chinook tale and salmon leaping up the side. The park has benches, a water feature, playground with swings, and flush toilet restrooms. Parking spaces around the park are metered with various time limits. This was the original western terminus of the trail prior to development of the Vancouver Waterfront. WTA Pro Tip: The east end of the trail is much less crowded than the west end, especially on summer weekends. Wheelchair Accessibility The entire length of this trail is paved sidewalks with curb cuts. Hike Description Written by Susan Saul, WTA Correspondent
column106: En route to my brother's place in Oregon, Edelman (that's Coach Edelman, as he's my half marathon coach, though he's pretty chill!) and I stayed in downtown Vancouver, WA for a night.  From the clock tower park near the waterfront and our hotel, I jogged about six miles out and back along the Columbia River Renaissance Trail. The first part parallels the river and takes you past the entrance to the grounds of historic Fort Vancouver.  This is where Edelman headed off to see where his grandfather had been stationed in 1926. I continued jogging along the riverfront, reaching some condos and buildings within about 2 miles. This is where one should head straight if you want to stay on the 'trail' as opposed to following the river. (Note: up to this point and also back along waterfront park downtown are the nicest portions of the trail-- at least considering the part I covered today. Supposedly it gets really nice further east.) The riverfront part of the trail ends just east of the condos, so I doubled back there , ran through a large parking lot, and hooked back up to the 'trail.' I'm using quote marks because it's a paved pedestrian lane. I ran a short distance further east, but it was all light industry and totally isolated, and didn't feel like the safest place for a small woman to run alone. So I pulled a u-ey and ran west again, all the way to the beautiful waterfront park complex which is west of the I-5 Bridge. This is a spiffy area that extends about another .75 miles and has several nice viewpoints jutting out over the river. I figure I ran about six miles total, most of which was very pleasant. Recommendation: rather than run along the industrial park,  next time I'll cut over to the Fort Vancouver National Park area, where a number of people were running and where the grounds are quite nice as well as historically interesting--rich Native American history along the Columbia, as well as the Fort . . .all of which is documented in plaques and a little museum on the grounds. Happy hiking and holidays, folks! Sorry no pics!

column8:
Apple Capital Recreation Loop Trail —
              Aug. 31, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-08-31.190220768224)
column51:
Apple Capital Recreation Loop Trail, Wenatchee Confluence State Park - Horan Natural Area —
              Oct. 11, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-10-11.223448767546)
column60: We biked this trail but all the info applies to hikers. Our round trip from Lincoln Rock State Park including the spur to Kirby Billingsley Hydro Park was 30 miles. Map: Loop_Trail_map Construction/Detour: The southern bridge across the Columbia River is closed for construction (through Nov 2026 per the sign). There are great detour signs on both sides of the river and we didn't get lost at all. BUT, the detour takes you through town on roads/sidewalks. We parked and began at Lincoln Rock State Park (Discover Pass required). It was a 5.5-mile bike ride on the Rocky Reach Trail to get to the Apple Capital Recreation Loop Trail. Both these trails are paved with rolling hills. There were signs along the Rocky Reach Trail about a recent mountain lion sighting in the area and the speed limit on this trail is 15 mph. Once on the Apple Capital Recreation Loop Trail, the speed limit is 10 mph. Both trails are very popular with people walking and biking, but the west side is much busier than the east side. In the congested areas around Wenatchee Riverfront Park, the bikes are separated from walkers, which is really nice. We biked out to Kirby Billingsley Hydro Park (a 3.2-mile spur off the south end of the trail). This park is quiet with a nice beach area and some benches for enjoying the view. There are numerous trailheads, bathrooms, drinking fountains, pieces of public art, views, places for kids to play, river access points, the list goes on. Really impressed with this trail and highly recommend it. #HiketheState
column98: Hiking Apple Capital Recreation Loop Trail This is a 10-mile, paved loop on both sides of the Columbia River near Wenatchee. The trail was completed in 1990 by the Chelan County PUD, connecting residents in the area with nature right in their backyards. The trail features an urban waterfront, as well as diverse natural habitats for wildlife in the area. The multi-use trail is well used by both recreators and commuters. Thousands of people use the trail each year, and it's accessible year round; even in winters with heavy snow, cross-country skiers and snowshoers love this route. Cross the Wenatchee River twice and the Columbia River once. Take particular note of the area where the Wenatchee River empties into the Columbia. There is riverfront beach access as it passes through several parks. Many users enjoy this trail, so be sure to acknowledge and practice proper trail etiquette. Toilet Information Toilet at trailhead Toilet has running water More information about toilets
column106: I enjoy chasing fall colors in Wenatchee, particularly elm-lined alley in Confluence State Park that is typically gleaming golden lush this time of year, creating wonderful photo opportunities. Last year WTA even featured my pic on their list of the spookiest fall hikes. This year however the said alley is a bit of disappointment; leaves seem to just dry out and fall due to hot and dry summer, and my beloved magical appearance is lost. There are still colors to be found along the Horan trail, and it was a warm and dry day anyway - nice change from rainy Seattle. There is still a lot of smoke around Wenatchee, with new plums coming and going, and it feels like buildings absorbed the smell and will keep it for a while. Note that the Apple Capital Loop is undergoing heavy renovation in places. From Walla Walla Point to Confluence SP, the bike trail is closed, while pedestrians are diverted via Horan Natural Area. On the southern side of the Loop, bridge across the Columbia is closed/limited during construction.

column60: Trailhead GPS or Map Link : https://www.peakbagger.com/climber/ascent.aspx?aid=2880917 Permit Required? : No Trail Type : Out & Back Duration : 13 hours Summit: No Weather : Scattered light showers, some snow flurries once we got up to the high point. Mid 30's to low 40's depending on elevation and proximity to the lake. Trail Conditions : Trail to Colchuck lake was obviously very well maintained, except for the pit toilets. Could have something to do with the recent closures, but they looked like they haven't been swapped out in a while. Would not recommend even opening them unless you have a very strong stomach. More snow on trail than anticipated, but show was firm enough to hold crampons well. Did not soften due to weather. Water Availability : Colchuck lake, some snow melt once you start the ascent. Bugs/Wildlife : very few bugs, probably due to the weather. Birds only wildlife spotted. Route Finding : There is some variety of GPX tracks once you start ascending from the lake to get to the saddle - we found a climbers trail on the climber's right-most side of the gully that worked well and kept us off the snow as much as possible. It did involve some boulder hopping, though. Gear Highlights : Used crampons and ice axes once we got to the snowfield, rope was not necessary for the portion of the trail we encountered. Probably would not recommend a rope if you are confident in your footwork.
column98: Hiking Colchuck Peak
column106: Climbed Colchuck>Pandoras Box>Dragontail Needed items: ice axe (mountaineering 60cm+ preferred) crampons helmet poles  the approach was easy, the Boulder field before Colchuck glacier still had intermittent ice. If you get there before 10AM you will be in the shade until you pass the glacier, which was nice. Glacier snow conditions: soft but beginning to harden up top. Once that turns to ice it’ll be a different animal. Very steep in the last section. Lower was sloppy. Everything else was straight forward, the snow on the backside of Dragontail was sloppy and kind of sketchy. Again, longer ice axe and previous glacier and snow travel will be preferred. Trip: 14 hours total. 8500 elevation gain. Take extra food

column60: Significant snowmelt has happened since last Saturday's (17th) snowshoe. I didn't get to go to the top and just did the "lower loop" up Moonshine and down California, but the loop for 99% of it was free of snow. Only scattered small patches were covered in crusted ice that got a bit slippery. Not sure at what point snowshoes can be or are worth being strapped on... as I didn't get to go high enough today. I'd probably still carry mine if I intended to hike to the top. Maybe? At the very minimum I would pack my cleats if I were going to higher elevation. Some parts today were iced over. Many parts melted out and muddy. A fantastic extra early morning hike with clouds blanketing the city below, but my hike was filled with baby blue skies and early morning sun. AllTrails map posted below for the route I took. #LoveLocalTrails
column98: Hiking Mica Peak Mica Peak is a popular destination for hikers, bikers, and equestrians because of the great workout it affords. The area hosts several varieties of flora, thanks to its elevation change from the parking area to the summit. The elevation gain from the parking area gives visitors a nice workout, doable in a day or less, and just minutes from Spokane. It's a destination for horseback riding, hiking, mountain biking, cross-country skiing and snowshoeing. Many trails exist here, but main access is via the parking lot on Belmont Road. Access the conservation area by hiking, biking, or riding along the road from the parking lot. The road is bordered by private property, so stay on the road. After a mile, the Mica Peak Conservation Area, and choose your own adventure. It's also possible to hike from here all the way to nearby Liberty Lake; a rugged 12+ mile one-way hike . When here, look for sub-alpine low brush to fragrant Ponderosa pine forest. Aspen and birch groves also thrive here, making the hill glow gold in the autumn. Visitors can also enjoy views of Spokane Valley and the rolling Palouse. The peak itself is off-limits — the summit is owned by the FAA — but the western slope of the peak still offers 2,000 feet of elevation gain from parking area to high point. Consult your map to plan your route. Note: Mica Peak was acquired in 2013 through Spokane County's Conservation Futures Program. Among other projects here, WTA volunteers helped complete the California Creek trail, the connecting segment that made the traverse to Liberty Lake possible. WTA worked here in 2025, 2024, 2023, 2022 and 2021! Hike Description Written by Multiple authors contributed to this report, WTA Community
column106: I hiked up California Creek, Moonshine Flats, Saltese Ridge, then came back down the road. The trail was snow free up to the lower section of Moonshine Flats, where it got a lot deeper, but it was still really manageable. I went a bit further and ran into a ton of deep snow.

column55: Pacific Crest Trail (PCT) - Bridge of the Gods to Road 23
column98: Hiking Pacific Crest Trail (PCT) - Bridge of the Gods to Road 23 This section hike is a great way to get a taste of the Pacific Crest Trail over the course of a week or long weekend. Starting from the Columbia River Gorge, you'll begin your trek with a long initial climb through lush, green forest (aptly named the Green Tunnel) before turning back east, weaving in and out of the Gifford-Pinchot National Forest and Yacolt Burn State Park. The initial 30 miles are fairly low in elevation and mostly forested, though you'll likely get some peek-a-boo views of the nearby mountains. Around the 32 mile point, hikers will reach the Panther Creek Campground, which is the last resting place before the longest climb of the section — about 9 miles uphill and 3200 feet of elevation gain. From this point on, you'll stay high and pass through a myriad of quaint lakes and flower-filled meadows as you meander through the Indian Heaven Wilderness, eventually coming up on your ending point at Road 23. The trail is dotted with plenty of campsites, making it easy to find a stopping point when your legs get tired.

column8:
Mount Roosevelt, Gem Lake, Snow Lake —
              Jul. 15, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-07-15.172628558446)
column51:
Mount Roosevelt, Snow Lake, Gem Lake, Wright Mountain —
              Sep. 21, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-09-21.155610631654)
column60: Hi, we're the Mountain Goats (Terrence), and today my dad and I summited Mount Roosevelt. I've always wondered why Roosevelt is so seldom visited, as it's off the extremely popular Snow Lake trail. We wanted to get an early start to beat the crowds, and because I have work tonight. We left the trailhead, making quick time to Snow Lake before heading to Gem Lake. Mount Roosevelt looms over the far end of Snow Lake, creating a stunning reflection. The trail winds around Snow Lake before ascending towards Gem Lake. You're greeted with stunning views of the Alpine Lake Peaks (Thompson, Price, Big Snow, etc.). Five miles in, we reached Gem Lake, and we immediately turned off the main trail and onto the Mount Roosevelt climbers' trail, which heads Southwest. The trail quickly gains 100 feet before flattening out as you walk along the top of a ridge towards Roosevelt. After a quarter mile of this, the trail begins to steepen as you head through trees and brush. The trail here is still relatively easy to navigate, and we didn't have any problems. This changed around 5,400 feet. The trail becomes quite steep and hard to follow as you pass through hemlock and rocky terrain. Don't slip here; once above this section, the trail gets easier as you climb above a rock outcrop before traversing towards the true summit of Mount Roosevelt. If you're on route, you should be right under the summit block at 5,600 feet, and the trail should be heading Southwest. Follow the trail as it steeply ascends through a mini scree field before you get on more solid rock mixed with trees. Overall, this section was fairly easy, some class 2+ stuff with maybe a class 3 move (maybe?). We simply followed the trail, and before we knew it, we were on the summit. Kaleetan and Chair sit right there dominating the skyline. Glacier, Baker, and Ranier, along with all the Alpine Lake and Mountain Loop Peaks, are visible, making the climb well worth it. The descent proved to be quite a bit more difficult than the ascent; we ended up losing the trail more heading down. Still nothing too difficult besides some steep terrain and plenty of tree-repelling. Overall, with ideal conditions (dry everything), this climb is fairly basic. Some steep class 2+ stuff with a few don't fall areas, but nothing that I would consider real Class 3 or 4. We ran into 120 people from Snow Lake to the trailhead, so I would highly recommend doing this climb on a weekday, as I wouldn't want to imagine the traffic on a weekend. Final Stats: 11.5 Miles - 3,350 Elev Gain - 8 Hours Car to Car
column98: Hiking Mount Roosevelt A climb off I-90 near Melakwa Lake. Gear and climbing experience required.

column8:
Rock Creek - Red Pass Loop —
              May. 31, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-05-31.171506614166)
column51:
Snow Lake, Rock Creek - Red Pass Loop, Rock Creek, Red Mountain (Commonwealth Basin) —
              Jun. 28, 2025 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2025-06-28.191730478453)
column60: Ascent to Snow Lake as snow on switch backs. Snow down to lake. Rock Creek initial switch backs - just descended snow. The clear up the Middle Fork. The Cascade Crest Trail is in great shape, someone has done a bunch of trail work and tree clearing (Thank You!). Snow starts at 4500 feet. The steep Red Pass is still steep wore crampons. Then rain blew in and it got cold - Commonwealth Basin is annoying with snow. https://strava.app.link/rOeCrV5APTb
column98: Hiking Rock Creek - Red Pass Loop This is a long-distance day hike that includes unmaintained trails. To hike this route, you should be both an experienced route finder willing to hike trails less traveled and prepared for a lonely hike. You may need crampons and an ice axe well into July. Why go? To condition yourself for long miles with significant elevation changes, to experience the difficulty of the Cascade Crest Trail before there was a Kendall Katwalk, or just to see new views. Begin by hiking to Snow Lake. Continue past the camps on the east side of the lake, and at 3.3 miles and 4,100 feet, encounter a junction with signs to Gem Lake (left) and Middle Fork Road (right). Go right, on what is more accurately the Rock Creek Trail. The trail quickly narrows and becomes rockier, while puddles and squishy mudholes may linger even in dry weather. The trail drops steadily and steeply across talus (especially the middle section, often overgrown with a fern "forest") and through (real) forest for 3.5 miles and almost 2,400 feet. Along the way is a seldom-seen view of Rock Creek, tumbling down a lengthy rock face after its exit from Snow Lake. At 6.8 miles, arrive at a junction with the Middle Fork Trail (#1003) and take a right. This section of trail follows an old road, gaining less than 150 feet of elevation over the next 3 miles. Water is available at Thunder Creek, 1 mile later at an unnamed creek and at Burntboot Creek. Camping is possible near Thunder Creek at 7.8 miles. There is NO water source on the entire climb once you leave Burntboot Creek. A snowpatch lingers well into August near the top, and there is standing water (not an ideal water source) in Red Pond eventually. Make sure you have plenty of water as you begin your climb, especially on a hot day. The key to successfully completing this hike is finding the faint, unsigned trail that leaves the Middle Fork Trail for Red Pass. 9 miles into your hike, you get to Burntboot Creek. The three-log crossing of Burntboot Creek, which led to the Goldmyer Hot Springs property, washed away several years ago. There is a tree with a sign for "Burntboot Creek." The trail follows Burntboot Creek upstream for about 100 ft, then descends to the creek bed. There are multiple faint trails that go further upstream along Burntboot Creek, in the forest.  It meanders along the creek, then drifts away. 400 feet from the Burntboot Creek sign is proof that you are on the right trail: two signs on a tree, one forbidding bicycles (this sign actually fell off the tree and sits at the bottom of the tree) and the other reading "trail not maintained beyond this point." Once you are at this tree, the trail is obvious and shortly after starts climbing. It climbs moderately steeply through lovely old-growth forest. It seems like an endless set of switchbacks as you gain 3,500 feet in just over 3 miles. This part of the trail may have blowdowns when not actively maintained. Enjoy the shade for the first 2 miles, then break out into views seldom seen. At 12 miles from the Snow Lake trailhead, crest over a small pass to an intimidating view of the steep chute leading up to Red Pass. This chute is the only way up to Red Pass other than 5th-class rock. When the snow is melted, switchbacks make this an easy ascent. This steep northeast-facing gully is filled with icy snow well into July. Crampons and an ice axe are often necessary to safely ascend to the pass. It's only 200 vertical feet of ascent, but in June or early July, this is more technically difficult than what you would typically find on the standard routes of any of Washington's volcanoes (not counting crevasse crossings). Know conditions before you go, and don't be afraid to turn around if conditions become dangerous. At Red Pass, located at 12.4 miles and 5,337 feet, going right is a spur trail towards Lundin; taking the trail to the left, you follow the ridge for 0.1 mile before descending a rocky trail down to the plateau holding Red Pond. From there, steep switchbacks take you down into the Commonwealth basin. Drop to 3,875 feet, where your next water stop is available, just under 14 miles from your starting point. At 14.3 miles, go right, where a broken sign on a tree reads "Abandoned." At 14.5 miles, rock-hop or ford Commonwealth Creek, then cross again on a log bridge at 14.7 miles. At 14.9 miles, take the short side trail to a worthwhile view of a waterfall. Continue down the narrow and brushy trail to connect with the Pacific Crest Trail, then go right the final 100 yards to arrive at the Snoqualmie Pass trailhead. To close the loop, walk pavement downhill to Alpental Road, then right to retrace the driving route to the Alpental parking lot, a total of 1.5 pavement miles. Toilet Information Toilet at trailhead Backcountry privy available More information about toilets WTA worked here in 2018! Hike Description Written by Ken Giesbers , WTA Correspondent
column106: I did a loop from Alpental, Snow Lake, Rock Creek trail, Middle fork trail to Burntboot creek, Old PCT to Red Mtn Pass, Red Pond, Commonwealth Basin trail back to Alpental. It was foggy for most of the day, so no Instagram worthy lake pics. Parking: upper lot was almost full at 8:00am on a cloudy / foggy day. Both lots were almost full at 1:30pm. Designated parking spaces are more obvious this year, but it also seems like the total number of available spots is reduced from last year. Get there early on a sunny weekend say. Bathrooms: open, but 5 people in line. Did not use it. Trail to Snow Lake: good shape and snow free on the climb, maybe 15% snow cover remains on the descend to the lake. Not a problem with hiking boots / trail runners. Rock creek trail: a bit overgrown at the top, a lot overgrown in the middle, nice trail lower down. It is narrow and rocky in the upper half, but easy to follow. a few easy to step over rocks and smaller trees down. Given the low use of this trail a log-out can wait until next year when likely additional trees are down. Middle Fork trail to Burntboot creek: typical, 2 small trees down. Biggest challenge is the Thunder creek crossing, but can be rock-hopped at this point. There is no dry crossing of Burntboot creek to Goldmyer at the regular trail crossing location. I did not check if the logjam about 0.1 miles downstream is still there. Old PCT to Red Mtn Pass: The trail start is hard to find if you don't know what to look for. See one of the pics below. There are multiple faint trails that run parallel to Burntboot Creek, on the South side of the Creek, going upstream. It's maybe 0.1 mile where you head away from the Creek and towards the slope of the mountain. There is an old wooden sign on a tree that says: trail not maintained, and a metal "no bikes" sign. (Not sure who in their right mind would attempt a 4000 ft climb on an unmaintained trail with a bike....) Shortly after that sign the trail starts to climb. It's a 4000 ft climb with NO stream crossing. Make sure you fill your bottles at Burntboot Creek. There is usually a snow patch near the top until late summer, but that's still 3700 ft of climbing with no water. The trail is in the best shape I've seen it in the last 10 years, at least. Someone(s) did a LOT of work on this trail. Most of the blowdowns are removed, it is better brushed out than I have seen it in many years, and several hundred feet of treadwork was done. It appears that most of the log removal was done with an ax, and some with a hand saw. At one point they chipped through a 3 ft log with an ax! Very impressive. Thank you to whoever did that!!! And thank you for not bringing a chain saw into the wilderness. Now the warning: I brought an ice ax and microspikes. Big mistake. Should have brought crampons! The last 200 ft of ascent to Red Mtn Pass are an icy, steep snow covered wide gully. I ended up spending a lot of time scratching hundreds of footholds into the snow / ice. The shaft of my ax would often only go 4" in. It's a long run-out into a rock field if you end up sliding down.... About half way up I was able to scramble up in the moat between the rock face and the snow for a bit, and eventually get to a point where I could climb out off the snow on a mix of rock, moss and some shrubs. I'd call that route a class 4 scramble. So if you do this trail in the next 4 weeks, bring crampons. Should be ok without by August. Once melted out, there is a switchback boot path all the way to the top. (As a reference, 2 weeks ago I climbed Eldorado in just trail runners and never felt the need to put my crampons on.) Red Mtn looked completely melted out (I did not go to the top), though there were still some snow patches near Red pond. The rest of the descend was uneventful and the trail back to the Alpental road is in good shape.

column60: I was in the Kettles to see the western larches but the Sherman Peak loop hike still has signage saying it is closed so did Columbia Mountain instead. This hike has some scattered larches as well as aspen and both were at peak color. Great views of the mountains of Sherman Pass covered in golden larches. Intermittent snow on the trail, consistently snow covered the last half mile and over the summit.
column98: Hiking Columbia Mountain One of the most popular hikes on the Colville National Forest is the short but challenging hike to the summit of Columbia Mountain, where vistas of surrounding mountains, wildflowers and one of the oldest fire lookouts in the state await you. The trail wraps around the base of Columbia Mountain, passing through pine forest, aspen groves and even a section of aromatic sagebrush. A variant of the hike will take you around a loop trail around the summit of the mountain. There is water available at springs at approximately 2 miles into the hike, but bring a filter as the springs are used by cattle. Camping is available at both the trailhead and at the summit. The lookout has been restored and is open to the public for camping, but no fires or cook stoves are allowed inside or near the structure. The summit stands at 6,760 feet and has great views to the south and west. Wildflowers abound in the summit meadow in the spring and summer. Hike Description Written by Artie McRae, WTA Community
column106: Summary:  Highly recommend this trail for Western Larches & views.  There was 2 to 3 inches of fresh snow which really made for great photo opportunities.  The Western Larches are so tall that had to remember to occasionally look up! A few of the larches are starting to lose their needles so recommend you go soon if you have energy for one more Larch hike. You could see smoke from the perscribed burn in the distance.  However, could only occasionally smell the smoke.  There were clouds in the valley the entire day. We only encountered one other hiker on this trail which is more than typical for hikes we've done in the region. Trail Condition:  There were a few minor blowdowns on the main trail that were easy to walk over. On the loop section,    there was one major obstacle that required us to remove our packs to get under. Road / Parking:  The trail starts from a large parking lot near Sherman Pass.  The Pass (Highway 20) was in excellent shape.  The parking lot was not plowed but had only 2 or 3 inches of snow.  The facilities at the trail head were clean & stocked with toilet paper.

column8:
Summerland - Panhandle Gap, Indian Bar - Cowlitz Divide, Eastside Loop —
              Oct. 2, 2024 (https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/trip-reports/trip_report-2024-10-02.204059880810)
column60: Wanted to get one last Rainier run in before the weather turns, and the Eastside loop had been on my list for a while. Trail in great condition throughout.  There are a couple of small damaged bridges on the Eastside trail, in addition to the bridge above Summerland which looks to have been removed for the season, but everything is crossable without getting your feet wet by rock-hopping. Plenty of filterable water on Eastside trail, coming down Summerland, and on the climb up Cowlitz, but once you're on the ridge it's dry until Indian Bar. No snow yet, but it was quite cold in the morning, and I expect we're not more than a week away!
column98: Hiking Eastside Loop Peaceful meadows, serene lakes and views of the rugged Cowlitz Chimneys are treats for the eyes on this multiday trek. Start on the Owyhigh Trail , passing Barrier and Buell Peaks to meet up with the Eastside Trail. Turn south and begin passing so many waterfalls, you’ll be glad you brought extra camera batteries. At Stevens Canyon, turn north through huckleberry-laden forest along the Cowlitz Divide until you meet with the Wonderland. Head north where Indian Bar and Summerland will take your breath away with meadowy beauty. Hike Description Written by Tami Asars, WTA Correspondent
column106: Ran/hiked this CW on 9/11/25. Was an incredibly tough day but really amazing views and beautiful countryside. Don’t underestimate it though - ended up clocking 34.5 miles and 9,500’ of elevation gain. Started at 5am and finished by 6pm. Trail was in great shape and work was actively being done near the Cowlitz Divide / Eastside junction. Only 1-2 downed trees and no other obstructions or obstacles along the entire thing. All water crossings had bridges in good shape. Great day out there!

column60: Parked at the grocery store in Arlington and started there. I was on a fat tire ebike. trail work is lightly going on between the Arlington head and the first trestle north about 4 miles out. the first 2 or so miles was very loose gravel, glad I had 4" tires! Some branches and ruts due to the work in progress. After the first trestle it was real good to Darington. Trial is everything from single track gravel to paved, the last mile or so is bumpy into Darington but very passable the whole way.  a tree over the trail about half way to Darington, step over if you are on foot, boost the bike over for me, real easy. One small bridge out by Darington is closed but I found it quite passable, its maybe 20 feet long with an eco block painted orange at each end. I'm certain that if you wanted to there are minor roads to get around it in the area. Awesome trail, sights abound! The OSO Memorial is really well done, lost a buddy in that one. Hardly used on a Tuesday afternoon, real pleasant for a solo, solitude ride. Took some pictures along the way here and there no major stops and it took me about 3.5 hours to round trip it. I was on an Aventon Adventure 2 and it took me 2 batteries to ride out and back. I was riding pretty conservatively in the 2 bottom steps of peddle assist and had 40% left on my return. (not gonna lie to ya, I used the throttle the last mile over the loose gravel! 60 miles was a good trip!)
column98: Hiking Whitehorse Trail The Whitehorse Trail runs for 27 miles along an old railroad grade, connecting the towns of Arlington and Darrington. The route generally follows Highway 530 and the North Fork Stillaguamish River as it approaches the cascade foothills. The trail is intended for hikers, bikers, and horseback riders and makes a great option for strolling away from the traffic of the highway. From Arlington, you can connect to the Centennial Trail . Most visitors choose not to travel the entire length of the trail, instead opting for a couple popular segments: Swede Heaven to Darrington, or Arlington to Trafton.
